urn:contentItem:5XFM-BMH1-F03R-N0TY-00000-00Guidance for businesses still concerned about CCPA2019-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:09ZLexisNexisGuidance for businesses still concerned about CCPA

Nov 07, 2019( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) With the looming compliance date of January 1, 2020, there is still confusion about what CCPA compliance[1] means. The bill meant to enhance privacy rights and consumer protection for residents of California, U.S. Given the size and importance of the state, the bill is of significance to the U.S. as a whole and to most of the world.To explore the impact on businesses, Anne Kimbol[2], Chief Privacy Officer for HITRUST[3] (a data protection standards development and certification organization) looks at how firms can identify and mitigate gaps and risks in their existing programs in order to comply with CCPA. DJ: What are the key points from the CCPA? Anne Kimbol: The CCPA focuses on the sale of personal information by for profit companies that meet certain revenue or records thresholds.

The definition of sale is fairly broad, although there are still questions about its exact applicability. The philosophy behind the law is that individuals should have control over how their data is used when companies are using or sharing it for commercial reasons. Before the Cambridge Analytica and related scandals, most people thought their data was used by companies to provide the particular service they sought and were unaware of the amount or value of disclosures of their personal information. Whether the law works as intended, only time will tell. DJ: Why is HITRUST providing a strong basis for a CCPA assessment to its new release of its information risk and compliance framework? Kimbol: There are two reasons. The first is that almost every for profit business in the United States will have to comply with the CCPA given the number of consumers and size of the economy of California. HITRUST recognizes that in order to assess their compliance, these companies need a comprehensive information risk management framework through which to perform a risk-based analysis of their current privacy and security programs. Additionally, while the CCPA's focus on for profit businesses limits its applicability somewhat, the law is serving as a model for bills filed in other state legislatures and has created an expectation among individuals that they can have access to their data, ask for it to be deleted or corrected, and limit its uses. As is evident in the controls included in the HITRUST CSF, HITRUST believes compliance with laws should be a baseline not the goal of any information risk management program. Even if the CCPA does not apply to a particular business or use of data, that does not mean its requirements should be ignored. Consumer expectations around information risk management are increasing, and businesses must be prepared to answer questions about what measures they are taking to protect the data they hold. DJ: How is HITRUST is helping organizations quickly identify and mitigate gaps and risks in their existing programs? Kimbol: By performing a HITRUST CSF assessment, organizations can identify, using a risk-based approach, the strengths and weaknesses in their information risk management program. This not only identifies for them potential corrective action plans but allows them to prioritize resources to address the most crucial gaps first. While no system is unbreachable, by knowing and addressing its weaknesses, an organization can reduce the risk to its systems and data. DJ: How different is the CCPA - from the EU's GDPR? Kimbol: The CCPA is just different enough from the GDPR to create confusion in terms of compliance. California has a narrower definition of companies to which it applies and has a larger focus on revenue received from the sharing of data than GDPR. California also protects information that is identifiable to a household or device, which is unique and raises complex questions when it comes to the exercise of data subject rights. The exact rights a data subject has under the two fit the same basic description - notice, consent, access, portability, etc. - but the details of the rights themselves and how to exercise them vary substantially. DJ: What work has HITRUST with the EU GDPR? Kimbol: HITRUST began including the GDPR in version 9.1 of the HITRUST CSF. Given its broad application, a substantial number of companies have had to look at complying with EU data protection law for the first time under GDPR. Ensuring that the HITRUST CSF contains GDPR information and helps companies comply with the regulation is key to the HITRUST Approach of Assess Once, Report Many. We are also following the GDPR certification process authorized under the regulation. We have taken part in open comment periods, drafted an application to become an accredited certification body, and submitted an application for the HITRUST CSF to be recognized as proper certification standards for the European Data Protection Seal, a designation made by the European Data Protection Board. While the details of the certification process have not been finalized in the EU, HITRUST is following it closely and is ready to respond when the time is right. DJ: How is HITRUST supporting the development and implementation of the NIST Cybersecurity Framework? Kimbol: HITRUST is a strong supporter of NIST and the work they do to help enhance information protection in the United States and worldwide. The NIST Cybersecurity Framework provides a mechanism for assessing and maturing a cybersecurity program. The HITRUST CSF provides the details needed to implement those objectives and an assurance program to provide a means of objectively demonstrating the implementation of the NIST Cybersecurity Framework. With a HITRUST CSF Validated Assessment Report, clients receive a scorecard comparing their programs with the NIST cybersecurity objectives. If the program is of a certain standard, a HITRUST NIST Cybersecurity Framework certification will be provided. By including the NIST Cybersecurity Framework in the HITRUST CSF, HITRUST acknowledges its importance and value in the field while translating its requirements into implementable and assessable controls.DJ: Where do you see the future of privacy regulations heading? Kimbol: I think we will continue to see individual states in the US and individual countries worldwide developing their own privacy laws, each of which is likely to be just different enough to cause compliance and translation difficulties. Ideally, there would be a strong and enforceable international framework on privacy rights. Each country or division thereof would certainly have its own specific details, based on its own culture and norms, and no country would want to give up its sovereignty on such a key issue. That said, a patchwork of laws does a disservice to individuals and society. Data has immense promise in helping solve some of our greatest problems, including public health issues, which can only be met if individuals feel comfortable sharing their data with entities who know how they can or cannot use it. We have bases for such a framework through the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Privacy Principles, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Privacy Framework, and the Convention for the Protection of Individuals with Regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data (Convention 108). While Convention 108 was recently updated, we need to ensure that any such framework recognizes the weaknesses in the current notice and consent model, which is technically followed by big tech today. While it will never be a simple issue, we can protect people's privacy and use data for good; we just need to work together to make it happen. urn:contentItem:5XGK-0W81-DXKD-J3VN-00000-00Guidelines for proper use of AI explored2019-11-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:09ZLexisNexisGuidelines for proper use of AI exploredChang Jun in San Francisco

Experts at a conference discuss ways to monitor technology and minimize risks

Artificial intelligence, the revolutionary, disruptive and diffuse technology that has been sparking controversy and awe since its inception over 50 years ago, now enters a stage that requires the global community - academia, civil society, government and industry - to orchestrate regulations to have it guided in order to serve the common good.

At its conference on AI's ethics, policy and governance in late October, the Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence's drew hundreds of experts worldwide to a two-day conference to discuss how the major stakeholders can work together to supervise AI research, minimize risks and prohibit unethical AI-enhanced practices.

Unanimously, the attendees agreed that AI has transformed society profoundly. Major progress has been made due to availability of massive data, powerful computing architectures and machine learning advancement. AI is playing an increasing role across domains such as healthcare, education, mobility and smart homes.

However, AI has also caused concerns all over the world, mainly because of a lack of ethical awareness and penetration of individual privacy. For example, the AI applications in facial recognition.

Joy Buolamwini, a computer scientist at the MIT Media Lab, a research laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, presented findings of her research on intersectional accuracy disparities in commercial gender classifications. In her research, Buolamwini showed facial recognition systems developed by tech companies such as Amazon, Microsoft and Google 1,000 faces and asked them to identify gender. The algorithms misidentified Michelle Obama, Oprah Winfrey and Serena Williams, the three iconic dark-skinned women, as male.

The bias in code can lead to discrimination against underrepresented groups and the most vulnerable individuals, Buolamwini said.

She also founded Algorithmic Justice League, a program through which she aims to highlight collective and individual harms that AI can cause - loss of opportunities, social stigmatization, workplace discrimination and inequality - and advocate for changes concerning regulating big tech companies and checking government's application of AI.

One of the key questions around AI governance and ethics, as a majority of attendees agreed, is how to regulate big tech companies.

This "nascent technology will help us build powerful new materials, understand the climate in new ways and generate far more efficient energy - it could even cure cancer," said Eric Schmidt, former Google CEO and current technical advisor to Alphabet Inc.

This is all good, he continued. "I don't want us, in these complicated debates about what we are doing, to forget that the scientists here at Stanford and other places are making progress on problems which were thought to be unsolvable ... because (without AI) they couldn't do the math at scale."

Link to Image

However, Marietje Schaake, a HAI International Policy Fellow and Dutch former member of the European Parliament who worked to pass the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation, argued that AI's potential shouldn't obscure its potential harms, which the law can help mitigate.

Large technology companies have a lot of power, Schaake said. "And with great power should come great responsibility, or at least modesty. Some of the outcomes of pattern recognition or machine learning are reason for such serious concerns that pauses are justified. I don't think that everything that's possible should also be put in the wild or into society as part of this often quoted 'race for dominance'. We need to actually answer the question, collectively, 'How much risk are we willing to take?'"

Like it or not, the age of AI is coming, and fast, and there is plenty to be concerned about, wrote Stanford HAI co-directors Fei-Fei Li and John Etchemendy.

The two believe the real threat lies in the fact that "Most of the world, including the United States, is unprepared to reap many of the economic and societal benefits offered by AI or mitigate the inevitable risks".

Getting there will take decades, they said. "Yet, AI applications are advancing faster than our policies or institutions at a time in which science and technology are being underfunded, under-supported and even challenged. It's a national emergency in the making."

They asked the US government to commit $120 billion in research, data and computing resources, education and startup capital over the next decade to support a bold human-centered AI framework in order to retain America's competence and leading position in this field.

An open dialogue and collaboration among nations regarding AI research and governance is important, attendees said. Given the complexity of cultural differences and motivation variations among international stakeholders, however, it's unrealistic for the whole world to create a single AI vision and a once-and-for-all solution to the problems and issues.

Nevertheless, governments across the continents are in action.

In Europe, the European Union issued its first draft of the ethical guidelines for the development, deployment and use of AI in Dec 2018, an important step toward innovative and trustworthy AI "made in Europe'".

In Feb, the US president signed an executive order revealing the country's cohesive plan for US leadership in AI development. "Continued American leadership in Artificial Intelligence is of paramount importance to maintaining the economic and national security of the United States," he said.

In China, the National New Generation Artificial Intelligence Governance Committee, which is under the Ministry of Science and Technology, in June released the New Generation AI Governance Principles - Developing Responsible AI.

The first official document of its kind issued in China on AI governance ethics, the principles include harmony and friendship, fairness and justice, inclusive and sharing, privacy protection, safety and controllability, shared responsibility, open collaboration and agile governance.

"We want to ensure the reliability and safety of AI while promoting economic, social and ecological sustainable development," said Zhang Xu, deputy director of the strategic planning department under the Ministry of Science and Technology.

"AI is advancing rapidly, but we still have time to get it right - if we act now," said Fei-fei Li.

urn:contentItem:60VG-GMT1-DY2T-632T-00000-00Guilbeault's Facebook snippet war2020-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:10ZLexisNexisFP COMMENTPg. FP10Guilbeault's Facebook snippet warTerence CorcoranNational Post

Steven Guilbeault - former Greenpeace activist, climate warrior, CN Tower climber and now Canada's heritage minister - flew out of the Ottawa policy bat cave earlier this month to spread a little viral commentary on the global corporate malignancies know as Big Tech. Calling Facebook a "bully," "immoral" and the tech equivalent of the "big polluters" and climate killers he fought in the past, Guilbeault seemed to be running advance interference for the Trudeau government's looming plans to tax and regulate Google, Facebook and other tech companies.

Ottawa is expected to outline some aspects of its Big Tech attack in next week's throne speech. The apparent trigger for Guilbeault's multimedia appearances was news from Australia that Facebook would "stop allowing" news publishers and others from sharing local and international news if the government went ahead with its plan to force the social media giant to pay news publishers for the news and other media content that flows over the internet.

In a blog post on Aug. 31, Facebook's managing director in Australia warned that Aussie regulators are drafting a competition policy that would require Facebook to negotiate with a cabal of Australian media corporations over how much money the tech giant should pay as compensation for some of the news content that runs on their platforms. "Assuming this draft code becomes law, we will reluctantly stop allowing publishers and people in Australia from sharing local and international news on Facebook and Instagram," he wrote.

Google Australia did not go that far, but it raised the same objections to the government's plan. The proposed "news media content code," it said, "would put the free services you use at risk in Australia."

Whether Ottawa has plans for a similar money-sharing code isn't known, although Guilbeault's rush to denounce Facebook does suggest something comparable is flying around the Liberal policy bat cave. He attacked Facebook for its "bullying attitudes" and said that Canada stands with Australia and won't tolerate "any form of threats" from the tech industry. He also warned Facebook that if it doesn't go along with governments around the world, it will face serious problems.

So what's all this about? What is this Australian bargaining code that Big Tech opposes and that Canada and other countries are supposedly looking at as one of the ways to fiscally tame the Big Tech monsters? It's a multi-billion-dollar Aussie battle between the tech giants and Australia's news giants, including Rupert Murdoch's News Corp., over snippets. The battle demonstrates the folly of looking at the tech economy through the wonky prism of competition theory and policy.

Snippets include the short extracts of news stories that appear on Facebook and in Google news searches. A Google search for the latest Donald Trump folly will produce a string of snippets, including headlines and one-sentence summaries from scores of media sources. The reader then clicks on the snippet and is taken to the media company's website for access to the full report.

Facebook and Google do not pay for snippets, which are supplied without cost by media companies that seek exposure for their content. Media companies such as News Corp. can sell ads around the full version of the stories that appear on their websites. Or they could charge readers by selling subscriptions.

In Australia, as elsewhere, news organizations argue that Facebook and Google are unfairly grabbing advertising dollars using free snippet content supplied by the media companies. To compensate, the news companies say the tech giants should pay for the use of the snippets. On the other side, theoretically, tech giants could also request payment from media companies for access to their internet platforms.

Enter the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), which operates one of the world's most activist competition enforcement agencies. In July, ACCC chair Rod Sims announced a "draft mandatory code," which would enable Australian media to "bargain with" Google and Facebook to "quickly secure fair payment for news content." To make sure the bargaining takes place fairly and promptly, Sims said a government-appointed arbitrator would move to force a deal after 45 days.

Note the competition policy irony. The proposed bargaining model involves creating a government-mandated cartel of Australian media companies that will be encouraged to collude in their financial negotiations with Facebook and Google - the theory being that the media companies do not have the bargaining power necessary to extract large sums from the tech giants.

And the media companies do want large sums for their snippets. Earlier this year, Australia's major broadcaster suggested that Google and Facebook should pay US$432 million ($570 million) to news organizations in compensation.

On the other side of the negotiations, Facebook estimated that Australian media companies already make big bucks off their free snippets. "Over the first five months of 2020 we sent 2.3 billion clicks from Facebook's News Feed back to Australian news websites at no charge - additional traffic worth an estimated A$200 million ($193 million) to Australian publishers."

Facebook says that the ACCC's mandatory code establishes a system the leaves Facebook with a choice of either removing news entirely from its site, or "accepting a system that let's publishers charge us for as much content as they want at a price with no clear limits."

That's just a snippet of what can be expected to come from Steven Guilbeault and the government in Ottawa as early as next week. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2020 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back.

Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, February 28th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Return of the bears -- the Dow snapping a three-day winning streak yesterday, closing down nearly 300 points. Investors were spooked after Federal Reserve Chairman J. Powell signaled that the strong economy could lead to more interest rate hikes.

Futures indicating the markets are bouncing back a bit today. Take a look. We are basically back at the break-even level.

We've seen a pretty selloff in the last 10 minutes actually. The Dow Industrials now flat, as is the S&P 500. Nasdaq up a point. But again these are well off of the highs of the morning here.

Investors are waiting on the fourth quarter GDP. It's due out in about 90 minutes. Economists are looking for the GDP to show growth of 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter.

In Europe this morning, stocks are lower across the board. Take a look. FT 100, CAC 40, DAX index down between a third of a percent and one-half of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, red across the board. Worst performers were in Hong Kong and Japan, down 1.5 percent apiece.

The battle over gun control back in the U.S. as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today. President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence.

Vice President Mike Pence promised the White House will do all it can to keep students safe.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: No child, no teacher should ever be in danger in an American school. I want to make you a promise. We will not rest until we make our schools safe again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More on the debate coming up this morning.

Meanwhile FISA fight -- the details as Attorney General Jeff Sessions says that the Justice Department will investigate potential abuses of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act by the Obama administration against the Trump campaign.

Then Jim Comey getting cheeky -- listen to this. The former FBI director takes yet another shot at President Trump on Twitter. We'll tell you about that.

Then Bill Gates slamming bitcoin -- why he says the crypto currency is killing people.

And a dangerous viral trend -- how the Cinderella diet is putting people's health at risk.

We've got all those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee chairman, and Fox News contributor Jason Chaffetz; and the "Wall Street Journal's" editorial board member, Fox News contributor Mary Kissel.

Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good morning. Good morning, everybody.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Lots to discuss today.

BARTIROMO: Right.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: That's not cute -- that whole Cinderella thing --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: I don't know.

BARTIROMO: No, that's not cute at all.

CHAFFETZ: I'm just saying. I'm married. I'm happy. But that's not attractive.

MCDOWELL: I want to see Cinderella wearing a bandanna, no makeup, sweating like Richard Nixon with some running shoes on. That's how you stay slim.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well -- all these fads, diets, people believe in them. And yes, you're right. Just sort of -- get back to basics.

KISSEL: Yes. Basics.

BARTIROMO: Eat right and exercise.

KISSEL: Yes and meat and butter. And jettison, you know, all these carbs. Apparently that's a new thing to do.

BARTIROMO: Sugar and flour.

MCDOWELL: Yes, goodbye.

CHAFFETZ: You're making me hungry. I want some pancakes.

BARTIROMO: We had them yesterday. It was National Pancake Day yesterday.

CHAFFETZ: It was -

BARTIROMO: You should have seen the stack we had right here. It was this high.

CHAFFETZ: You invited me on the wrong day.

KISSEL: Wow, National Pancake Day.

CHAFFETZ: You don't get a belly like this by missing pancakes. Come on.

BARTIROMO: All right. We've got a big show this morning -- join us. White House deputy press secretary Hogan Gidley is here. Former RNC chair and Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour is here. Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano is here; along with Dr. Mikhail Varshavski, better known as Dr. Mike. We'll talk about diet and exercise with him.

You don't want to miss a moment of it. So do stay with us.

We kick it off right here this hour. We're taking a look at markets. Futures are flat today now. Markets were edging higher earlier as investors await fourth quarter GDP numbers to come out, roughly 90 minutes from now. We're expecting the economy to show growth of 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter.

My next guest chairs the subcommittee on monetary policy and trade in the House Financial Services Committee. Joining us right now is Kentucky Congressman Andy Barr. Congressman -- it's good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

REP. ANDY BARR (R), KENTUCKY: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: So did what you see in terms of what's happening in the economy today -- did that jibe with what you heard from Mr. Powell yesterday?

BARR: Yes, I think our new chairman of the Federal Reserve reinforced what we're already seeing, which is that tax cuts and the regulatory relief agenda -- that that agenda is working in the economy and that the economic outlook is strong as a result of the fiscal stimulus that congress and the President have injected into the economy. And that gives the Fed greater flexibility to continue its monetary normalization program, which is very important to remove the distortions from our economy.

BARTIROMO: So what did you get from him yesterday? I mean did you get a sense that he's going to raise interest rates four times?

BARR: Well, I was encouraged that Chairman Powell did clearly communicate the monetary policy trajectory. He did indicate that the tax cuts were working in terms of increasing household incomes, increasing wages. The consumer and the business confidence is very, very high.

And as a result, we do expect the Fed to continue to normalize and that's very important, because this Fed chairman has inherited a very unprecedented task and that is the task to unwind a very unconventional balance sheet, a bloated balance sheet that creates risks and also a protracted period of artificially-low rates. We need to return to market- based rates.

That doesn't mean an unpredictable increase, dramatic increase in interest rates. It means a gradual, predictable increase in interest rates, consistent with the growing economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We were talking about that all morning -- $4.5 trillion balance sheet needs to get unwound which is why you asked this question yesterday. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARR: Are there any plans within the balance sheet normalization strategy to roll off longer term assets more quickly, to counteract that flattening yield curve?

JEROME POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: You know, flattening of yield curves in the past has been sort of a precursor of recessions, but largely because in many prior recessions the Fed had to raise rates quickly to hold, you know, to hold inflation down.

That's not the situation we have now. There's always a risk of a recession at any given point in time. I don't see it as at all high at the moment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So were you surprised that the markets reacted so violently after the meeting?

BARR: No. And I'm also not surprised at the general level of volatility. And remember, some of these corrections are very healthy to avoid asset bubbles. We don't want excessive volatility but we also recognize that normalizing monetary policy can be a very sound policy from the standpoint of preventing asset bubbles, making sure that we are realigning valuations and equities according to reality.

So it's not all together a bad thing to recalibrate as the markets continue their overall upward trajectory. Again, we don't want valuations to exceed reality and so some level of correction here and there is a good thing, as the market continues its long-term bull run.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE): I see.

KISSEL: What is Congress going to do -- by the way, this is Mary Kissel here -- if we do see a spike in rates and that interest burden on the government debt goes through the roof? I mean that's a big risk, isn't it. What are you guys doing about it?

BARR: It is a big risk. But it's also important that we don't mask the true problem with artificially low rates that create distortions in the economy and excessive risk. I think it's incumbent upon Congress and the President to get serious about mandatory spending reform.

I would add that some of the critics of tax reform blame tax cuts for larger deficits. I think monetary normalization and unreformed mandatory spending is what is likely to increase deficits.

And so that reinforces the need for us to continue pro-growth policies so that we get revenue, not from tax cuts, but from more taxpayers. And we also reform mandatory spending so that we can force the government to live within its means.

BARTIROMO: We're going to switch gears here. Here's Jason Chaffetz. Go ahead.

CHAFFETZ: Yes, Jason Chaffetz here. It's good to see you -- Andy.

BARR: Hey -- Jason. Good to see you.

CHAFFETZ: I served with Andy in the United States Congress.

I want to ask you about guns. The House of Representatives passed a bill that had the concealed carry reciprocity act coupled with the Fix NICS, the National Instant Background Check System. Do you think the House has an appetite to separate those bills and run independently the Fix NICS legislation? And would that be palatable with what's going on in the Senate?

BARR: Well, I would support that -- Jason. I also support the reciprocity bill. I'm a co-sponsor of the reciprocity bill, our colleague Richard Hudson's bill.

But I also support fixing the NICS and enhancing the NICS system. And I was one of many members of Congress also who signed a letter to the ATF to revisit the bump stock after -- the bump stock regulations after Las Vegas.

CHAFFETZ: So why don't those things pass? I mean if you're as conservative as they get in the House, then why isn't Kevin McCarthy and Paul Ryan pulling up those bills because we could pass both of those, even three bills independently. Why isn't that happening?

BARR: Well, as you know, Jason -- and I'm not sure if you were still in the Congress at the time, but we did pass the fix NICS with the reciprocity bill.

I'm in favor of separating and passing them again. I think the Senate needs to take action. You know, there's a narrative out there that Congress doesn't care or hasn't taken action on these mass murders. That's not true. We passed the Helping Families and Mental Health Crisis Act as part of the 21st Century Cures Act which helped to reform HIPAA with respect to helping family members intervene with loved ones whoa re suffering from mental illness.

We've also taken action on the bump stocks. We passed the Fix NICS program. And I would also be in favor of some federal authority to give local school districts the flexibility and the discretion to make our schools safer and to use resources to either pay for law enforcement officers in the schools, harden schools, metal detectors, even more psychologists or counselors in the schools to monitor kids who have social alienation and warning signs.

And you know, this is personal to me and Jason because our good friend Steve Scalise was the victim last June of a gunman. And you know, the one lesson from that baseball field in Alexandria when many of our colleagues were out there in harm's way, the lesson was that the best defense in a situation like that is a well-armed, well-trained security guard.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BARR: And you know, I think local school districts should be able to direct local decisions with Parent Teachers Associations on whether or not they want to use resources to have security officers in their schools.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You would think so -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Congressman -- I want to ask you what you think about your Senator Rand Paul from your state of Kentucky about his pushback on this Fix NICS bill because you are getting that from some conservatives with the suggestion of how can you appeal if you're flagged in this background check system.

So are some of your colleagues, whether in the House like Congressman Louis Gohmert who we talked to yesterday, and then in the senate, getting in the way of passing a clean bill to beef up a background check system that already exists and works in this country?

BARR: Well, in the case of Texas, where you saw the Air Force fail to provide the information to the NICS system, I think that's exactly what we're trying to fix. And I think we need to make sure that federal agencies are actually providing the information to make the NICS system work.

We can have all the checks in the world. But if you don't have the information in the background check system it doesn't work. And I would add that the Fix NICS bill that we passed out of the House already, that bill actually enhanced some of the due process.

So I agree with Senator Paul. We need procedural due process if the government is, you know, taking away a constitutional right without due process. We need that due process. But we also need to make sure that the NICS system is working and clearly, it's not.

And I would also add in the case of the tragedy in Florida, this young man was showing all of the warning signs --

BARTIROMO: Right.

BARR: -- and clearly there was a failure by law enforcement, our mental health system and the education system to get that information so that that young man was not -- could not purchase a firearm.

BARTIROMO: So you think there will be improvements this year? You think there will be any changes in legislation this year on this?

BARR: Well, of course, we've already passed the bill out of the House.

BARTIROMO: Right. I know.

BARR: We would encourage the Senate to do the same. And I would be in favor of separating those out consistent with my strong, strong support of the Second Amendment. And none of these reforms in my view would in any way compromise our commitment to the Second Amendment.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- let me move on.

Reverend Billy Graham will lie in honor today in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda. He will be the fourth private citizen to lie in honor. Your thoughts on the storied life of Reverend Graham; can you tell us a little about what you're expecting today in terms of the ceremony?

BARR: Well, it's altogether appropriate that the Congress is not in session to honor the legacy and the tremendous contributions and the spiritual leadership of Billy Graham -- Reverend Billy Graham who ministered to so many Americans including U.S. presidents and members of Congress.

We are so -- we're not only appreciative of his ministry but we're grateful for the leadership that he provided to the country in good times and bad times.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let me ask you Congressman, before you go, on Financial Services Committee -- how much of a priority is changing Dodd-Frank? Is that going to be a priority in the coming weeks? When might we expect changes here?

BARR: Well, I'm very optimistic that we have a bipartisan bill that's moving through the Senate. As you know, statutory changes to a law like Dodd-Frank which has been a disaster in terms of clogging up our financial markets -- we need 60 votes in the Senate.

So we have a modest reform bill that fixes some of the overreach from Dodd- Frank. It's moving through the Senate. We've passed a more ambitious bill out of the House. But that gives us a lot of optimism that we can provide regulatory relief for community financial institutions.

BARTIROMO: So it should be coming in the coming weeks, then.

Congressman -- good to see you. Thank you.

BARR: Thank you -- good to see you too.

BARTIROMO: Andy Barr.

We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

A major retailer taking a stand on assault rifles. Lauren Simonetti with the details and headlines now -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Breaking news this morning. Dick's Sporting Goods -- that's one of the country's largest sports retailers, they say they will no longer sell assault-style weapons. They will also no longer sell high-capacity magazines and they will not sell any gun to anyone under the age of 21 years old regardless of what the local laws are.

These are shares not moving just yet in the premarket but this is the one- year chart and you can see they're down 35 percent.

Well, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates had nothing good to say about crypto currencies. He was speaking at an "Ask Me Anything" Reddit event. And he suggested the technology is used by money launderers, terrorists and drug dealers.

Gates said the main value of money like bitcoin is their anonymity which allows users to hide from law enforcement, adding that long-term investments in the virtual currencies are super risky.

Well, McDonald's' Happy Meals will once again have Disney-themed toys in them, all this starting with "The Incredibles 2".

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Honey --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: What?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: -- where is my super suit?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: What?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Where is my super suit?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: McDonald's and Disney are re-launching a multiyear deal. It starts with "The Incredibles 2". "Incredibles 2" -- that hits theaters in June.

Taking a look at shares of McDonald's -- they're up 25 percent from a year ago. Shares of Disney are down about 5 percent from a year ago.

There you go.

All right. This is an interesting story. Barbra Streisand, 75 years old, revealing that two of her three dogs are clones. Miss Scarlet and Miss Violet were actually cloned from cells taken from her 14-year-old dog, Samantha before Samantha died last year. So the dogs look alike but Streisand said she can't wait to see if they share Samantha's personality as well. Apparently she was a serious dog.

If you were wondering, the price to clone is $50,000 per pup. And she dressed them in different colors so she could tell them apart. That's how they got their names -- Scarlet and Violet. Now you know.

BARTIROMO: I don't know if I like the story -- cloning your dog.

MCDOWELL: With all the dogs -- you know what, with all the dogs in shelters that are on at-risk lists that need homes, whether it's the dogs on the streets of Puerto Rico and Miami, New York City, and you pay the money to clone your dog.

BARTIROMO: Why not adopt a dog or puppy that needs you?

MCDOWELL: You've got all that money, you could have 10 and save some lives.

BARTIROMO: Cloning your dogs.

CHAFFETZ: Wasn't she going to move to Canada?

BARTIROMO: She was supposed to move to Canada if President Trump won the election. She says I'm moving to Canada. She is still here.

CHAFFETZ: And cloning dogs.

MCDOWELL: And in an interview she suggests that the reason President Trump won is because of the voting machines got fooled with.

BARTIROMO: She thinks Hillary still won.

MCDOWELL: And that George Bush shouldn't have won either. She thinks there was vote tampering. She literally said that the last few days.

CHAFFETZ: I still want my money back from going to see "Yentl" -- still a craw in my side.

MCDOWELL: You're that old?

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We've got a tweet to tell you about. The President just tweeted this. We'll see what he's thinking about this morning. Here's what he said. "The Heritage Foundation has just stated that 64 percent of the Trump agenda is already done -- faster than even Ronald Reagan. We are blown away, said Thomas Binion of Heritage. President Trump is very active, conservative and very effective. Huge volume and spectrum of issues."

The President just tweeted that.

Do you disagree with that? He's patting himself on the back, definitely. You're right.

CHAFFETZ: Yes. I think things have been going well.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KISSEL: Lots of winning -- Jason. Lots of winning.

BARTIROMO: Hey -- are you tired of winning yet?

CHAFFETZ: Well, get Barbra Streisand to Canada -- that would be winning.

BARTIROMO: Fourth quarter GDP numbers out in about an hour. Back in a minute, we'll preview it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

The fourth quarter GDP is due out in about an hour. Growth is expected to be 2.5 percent, according to Thompson Reuters. This after Federal Reserve Chairman J. Powell testified in front of the House Financial Services Committee yesterday on his outlook for the economy. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

POWELL: It does feel to me that the next couple of years look quite strong and you should see strong demand from consumers. You should see businesses investing and I would expect the next two years on the current path to be, you know, to be good years for the economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: joining us now, Wells Fargo Investment Institute senior global equity strategist Scott Wren. Scott -- good to see you.

SCOTT WREN, SENIOR GLOBAL EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO INVESTMENT INSTITUTE: Hi -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: The next couple years look strong, good growth. What does that mean for you in markets?

WREN: Well, for us I think strong is certainly a relative term. Politicians always want to seem to pump up the growth very high, but if we saw something in the 2.5 percent, 2.8 percent, maybe toward 3 type of range, I think over the next couple of years, inflation stays reasonable. I think stocks can do well in that kind of an environment.

BARTIROMO: How come markets are so nervous about this?

WREN: Well, I would argue that 2018 is all about the central banks and particularly the fed. We've been on a 10 year monetary policy experiment. It's coming to an end.

In any normal cycle the fed usually has trouble backing away. This one's going to be more difficult. So when the market starts finally coming to grips that we're going to have three hikes this year, which I think they have, when in 2017 the stock market I think was mostly in denial, it's some uncertainty.

J. Powell talked yesterday, as you mentioned, talks maybe 4 -- that's a problem. We've argued that 3 is ok, but anything over that is a head wind for the market.

CHAFFETZ: You said reasonable inflation number. What is a reasonable expectation of inflation?

WREN: Well, Jason -- I tell you, we are -- let's say we got out of 2017 with 2, 2.1 CPI type of number. Our number this year is 2.4 so inflation is moving up. That's way below the longer term average. Of course, personal consumption expenditures, PCE has been stuck at 1.5 percent, way below where the Fed wants to see it.

So you know, I think the Fed's probably in the end going to let the economy run a little hot. I mean they've been trying to get inflation for 10 years. They have not been successful. They don't want to just choke it off too quickly.

MCDOWELL: When you talk about the central bank, our Central Bank unprecedented monetary policy over the last 10 years, interest rates could get away from them. They can move on the short end. But in terms of the longer end and as treasury and mortgage securities roll off their balance sheet as they try to reduce it later this year -- that's the great unknown.

You don't really have -- because, again, the market could take over and you've already seen that start to happen with longer term interest rates. They're only at 2.91 percent at the close yesterday on the 10 year but Nevertheless, that's a major worry. That's why people are so fixated on that.

WREN: Well, I think they are -- Dagen. And really we're in uncharted territory. I mean we've never had to roll off this much off a fed balance sheet. So that's more uncertainty. I think any news that has to do with wages, with employment, with inflation, with the fed, the market is going to react meaningfully probably, one way or the other.

Yesterday it was J. Powell's comments. I think on March 9th when the employment data is released, the single most important data point this month or in March, rather, I would argue is what did average hourly earnings do year over year. If that is less than 2.9, let's say it's 2.6 I think the market will rally on that. If it's 3 or 3.1, it's probably going to be an ugly day.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Because those are two important dates. March 1st, we get the PCE indicator; March 9th we get the jobs number with the wages. We'll be watching that.

Real quick what are you telling clients to do right now? Would you put new money to work here?

WREN: Absolutely. I think that what we want our clients doing, industrials, consumer discretionary, health care, financials -- we want them buying on the dips. We've been pounding the table on this thing.

Now, it came and went pretty quick between February 2nd and February 9th. It went down a lot and people were cautious because of the speed it went down. We want our clients in this market though.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Scott -- great to see you.

WREN: Thanks -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. And we should point out that J. Powell testifies part two of that (INAUDIBLE) testimony today in front of the Senate Banking Committee -- tomorrow, rather.

Coming up, a clash over privacy and security -- Microsoft taking its fight to protect customer data to the nation's high court. Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano breaks down the implications of the case.

And then could the "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" get flipped upside down?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILL SMITH, ACTOR: Now this is the story all about how my life got flipped, turned upside down. And I'd like to take a minute, just sit right there, I'll tell you how I became the prince of a town called Bel-Air.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The fresh twist in a reboot reportedly in the works for the hit program that launched Will Smith to fame.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, February 28th; your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Stocks searching for direction this morning, take a look at Futures, very much around the flat-line after a huge selloff yesterday.

Investors are awaiting the second reading of fourth quarter GDP due out about in an hours' time. Economists are looking for the GDP to show growth of 2 1/2 percent in the final month of 2017.

This after markets were rattled yesterday, following the testimony from Fed chair, J. Powell, his comments suggesting that the central bank may raise interest rates more than the three times that we are expecting.

Global markets following the US lower, take a look at the European indices this morning under pressure, FT 100 down just five points but the CAC krone in Paris is down almost half of a percent, 24 points lower in the DAX Index in Germany, down a third of a percent, 41 points lower.

In Asia overnight declines across-the-board with the worst performers in Hong Kong and Japan, down 1 1/2 percent apiece.

Investigating the investigators, Attorney General Jeff Sessions says that the Justice Department will probe alleged abuses by the Obama administration against the Trump transition team.

Former FBI director Jim Comey meanwhile taking a jab at President Trump on Twitter by saying, 'there's a tape.'

'Can you hear me now,' self-service makings its way to the moon, that story coming up this morning.

Then the rise of automation, Levi's is now looking to use lasers instead of people to distress their iconic jeans.

And not living happily after -- ever after all, the new dangerous diet trend that's taking a page out of a fairy tale.

We've got all those stories coming up this morning.

But first this BREAKING NEWS, President Trump is tweeting right now and here's what he saying, "I have decided that sections of the wall that California wants built now will not be built until the whole wall is approved. Big victory yesterday with the ruling from the courts that allows us to proceed. Our country must have border security."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TEXT: I have decided that sections of the wall that California wants built NOW will not be built until the whole Wall is approved. Big victory yesterday with the ruling from the courts that allows us to proceed. OUR COUNTRY MUST HAVE BORDER SECURITY!

(END VIDEO CLIP)

Coming from the president just moments ago.

With tech clashes, big tech is clashing with law enforcement meanwhile, in this case the United States versus Microsoft. The Supreme Court will decide whether the government can search user data if the information is stored overseas.

The case highlights the conflict between protecting customer privacy and giving police the authority to conduct a comprehensive investigation by looking at your data.

Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer, Brad Smith, weighed in on the hearing yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRAD SMITH, PRESIDENT & CHIEF LEGAL OFFICER, MICROSOFT CORPORATION: I certainly come out of the courthouse, if anything, more encore -- encouraged than when we walked in this morning.

Because in fact I think that what this case makes clear and what this morning has further made clear is that we need 21st century laws to protect 21st-century technology.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now, is FOX NEWS Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew NAPOLITANO:

Judge, good to see you?

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on this?

NAPOLITANO: Well it's a very fascinating issue.

In the past three years the American government has in indicted four Swiss bankers who by following Swiss banking law violated American banking law, all four were acquitted.

So, we are now confronted with a similar situation in which if Microsoft obeys American law and surrenders these documents it will be violating the law of the place where the documents are stored.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: So, the comments that he made in my view are the appropriate ones, Congressman Chaffetz understand this.

We need a treaty between the various countries in which the documents are stored that would provide for the movement of them so that by Microsoft complying with a bona fide search warrant, from a federal judge, to deliver these documents, it's got to go to France to get them, it's got to go to Great Britain to get them, it's got to go to Ireland to get them, and by going there and getting them, it's violating local law.

You can't put that burden on business men and women, that complying with the home countries law, they are violating another country's law.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: But just to --

NAPOLITANO: Or they -- or they are exposed to prosecution.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- but just to be clear about this Judge, we're not asking a French company based in France to give up information --

NAPOLITANO: Correct.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- that's stored in Britain we're -

NAPOLITANO: Correct.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- talking about a US-based --

NAPOLITANO: Correct.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- company complying with a US search warrant. The only issue here is that their Cloud so to speak is overseas.

NAPOLITANO: Yes. So, the Supreme Court in my opinion and we talked about this during the break, is -- I just agree with Brad Smith because I wasn't in the courtroom and I didn't hear the oral argument, I'm not employed by his company but I think that the Supreme Court will side with Microsoft.

There is no question that law-enforcement has the - has the right to this but the Supreme Court cannot immunize the Microsoft officials in the foreign country from the consequences of violating the foreign --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. Why should that --

NAPOLITANO: -- country's laws.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- why should that be the US Supreme Court's concern?

NAPOLITANO: Well because you -- it's -- it's -- it's --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. What do they care about --

NAPOLITANO: -- judges don't --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- foreign companies (ph)?

NAPOLITANO: -- judges don't like to for somebody to do something that gets them in trouble when it's not their fault --

BARTIROMO: Hmm!

NAPOLITANO: -- which is why we need legislation.

So, if we had a treaty, then the treaty would immunize the custodians in the foreign countries.

JASON E. CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR & FORMER UTAH CONGRESSMAN: If you could, I want to -- I want to talk two you a little bit about what Mr. Sessions said.

Now that the Inspector General, Michael Horowitz is going to go after Andrew can investigate what's happening with the FISA and the unmasking, where do you see that going?

BARTIROMO: Let's -- let's hear from Sessions first because the attorney - -

CHAFFETZ: OK.

BARTIROMO: -- general told me, the Justice Department will in fact investigate potential abuses of the FISA Act.

Here's what he told me on Sunday when he joined me on SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Are you sir investigating the fact that the FBI used the dossier to get a wiretap against Trump associates and they did not tell the FISA Court that the Democrats and Hillary Clinton paid for that dossier?

JEFFERSON BEAUREGARD "JEFF" SESSIONS III, ATTORNEY GENERAL, DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE: Let me tell you, every FISA warrant based on facts submitted to that court have to be accurate. That will be investigated and looked at and we are not going to participate as the Department of Justice in providing anything less than the proper disclosure to the court before the issue a FISA warrant.

Other than that, I'm not going to talk about the details of it but I'll tell you we are not - allow - we're not going to allow that to happen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, he's investigating --

NAPOLITANO: He's --

BARTIROMO: -- it Judge?

NAPOLITANO: -- he's probably talking about the inspector general investigating it.

I'm a little impatient with that kind of a process because the inspector general can't indict, he can't charge, this is like an investigation before an investigation.

If he gave it to a team of FBI agents and simply said, "Find out what the heck happened here, did your colleagues mislead the court," that kind of investigation can lead to serious charges.

For a lawyer, or an FBI agent to mislead the court can result in criminal prosecution.

CHAFFETZ: I -- but (ph) --

MCDOWELL: They can revoke -- but the inspector general can basically remove someone's security clearance, can't they?

CHAFFETZ: -- well they can make that recommendation --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: -- but they can't remove it.

What I think they should do is that Congress should hear from the judges themselves.

BARTIROMO: Me too.

CHAFFETZ: I just -- I really wish -- we had tried this when I was in the House, on the House Judiciary but they should call of those judges and have them testify about the process, how it works.

We've been told that it's so secret you can't do that.

NAPOLITANO: It would really be a first!

You know, you know, I have a friend who is on the FISA court and when this judge walks into the courthouse, he is patted down; when this judge, not a clerk, a judge --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- leaves the courthouse, he's patted down.

He doesn't have an iPhone with him, he doesn't have a pen or pencil with him, he doesn't have papers with him, he doesn't have a briefcase; that's how secret it is.

The judges do not have records of what they do in that courthouse.

Who has those records?

"The NSA."

What's the NSA?

"The Litigant," that's appearing before the court.

BARTIROMO: But you're -- if you're judge and you're -- you're given information, I mean you have to make sure that that information is accurate.

I mean we want to know why it is that a judge allowed the dossier, only, I don't think there was too much more to actually warrant a search warrant --

NAPOLITANO: It's --

BARTIROMO: -- and --

NAPOLITANO: -- it's so different and Congressman Chaffetz understands this:

(a), it's in secret --

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- as I said, so there's no records. The press doesn't know, we don't have eyes and ears in the courtroom.

(b), just as important, there is no adversary.

If you are presenting a document to me and you're not telling me everything about it, your adversary is going to point that out to me but where there is no adversary it's very easy for you to pull the wool over my eyes.

There was a proposal not too long ago to have a standing adversary in the - -

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- FISA court. The adversary doesn't represent the person whose surveillance is sought but the adversary challenges the government's documents which would force the government to --

BARTIROMO: But --

NAPOLITANO: -- dot every "i" and --

BARTIROMO: -- so nobody --

NAPOLITANO: -- cross every "t" --

BARTIROMO: -- challenges anything?

NAPOLITANO: Correct.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. But if the process is so corrupted Judge, if you have let's say a president Hillary Clinton and her friends at the top of the FBI, if that had happened and you have this process --

NAPOLITANO: They could surveil anybody.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- They could surveil anybody.

NAPOLITANO: Right.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. So, isn't it time to talk about getting rid of this court?

NAPOLITANO: Absolutely.

I've been arguing since 1978, Jason was a little boy but this court has been unconstitutional.

BARTIROMO: Devin Nunes has said that -- he suggested, Luke we need a FISA court but, but, but, I if this kind of abuse of continues we may look to not fund this FISA court.

NAPOLITANO: A, it tampers with the standard that's in the Constitution, from probable cause of crime to probable cause of speaking to a foreign person, that is a radically lower standard.

Congress can change the Constitution and it's purported to do so. B, it meets a secret. C, it's not a real court because there's no adversary in the courtroom.

CHAFFETZ: But Congress just reauthorized it. They reauthorized it and then like 48 hours later --

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: -- they announced all these potential abuses --

NAPOLITANO: I appreciate --

Chef it's: -- of the FISA court.

NAPOLITANO: -- what Devin Nunes is doing but he in my opinion committed a grave wrong by sitting on all this while Congress was debating the reauthorization --

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- of FISA.

He permitted more power in the hands of the very people whom he accused of abusing that power.

BARTIROMO: Why?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. Yes, but there's been no evidence that Section 702 that was reauthorized has been abuse.

My question to you Judge is, what executive would want the FISA court to go away because if that court went away, then the executive branch would be wholly --

NAPOLITANO: Directly responsible --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- responsible, directly responsible --

NAPOLITANO: -- Correct.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- for the surveillance.

BARTIROMO: That's --

NAPOLITANO: It's --

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

NAPOLITANO: -- it's extraordinary power to the executive branch.

BARTIROMO: Wow!

NAPOLITANO: Very difficult to get any entity, Congress or the president to shrink its own power.

BARTIROMO: Wow!

NAPOLITANO: It will take an extremely principled person to do that.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my goodness!

Well we've got to get to this as well because FBI, former FBI director Jim Comey is bashing President Trump, again, ahead of his book release.

Comey tweeted out a picture of himself, recording the audio version of his new tell-all book last night, and wrote, "Lordy, this time there will be a tape; audiobook almost finished."

His caption references president Trump's Tweet last year that conversations between the two men have been recorded.

Judge your reaction to this?

He --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- he keeps poking the president --

NAPOLITANO: -- Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- meanwhile all of this wrong-doing went on, on his watch.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

Yes, and I don't know what he's doing.

I am - he -- my guess he thought it was funny and, in some sense, it might be a little, mildly humorous, 'this time there will be a tape' because when president Trump said "James Comey better hope there isn't a tape,' and then Congress tried to get the tape and then the president said, "OK, there wasn't a tape. I was just suggesting that he better hope that there isn't one."

This is a reference to that. I think it's inside the beltway and inside base (ph) but --

MCDOWELL: He's auditioning for those late-night talk shows --

BARTIROMO: Hmm --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- because he needs those appearances to hump that lousy book --

NAPOLITANO: Correct.

MCDOWELL: -- that's coming out.

NAPOLITANO: Correct. It may be a great book --

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: -- it may be a challenging (ph) book, it may be garbage, I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Guys, we know that Jim Comey leaked something to his friend to get it into "The New York Times" so that they could get a special counsel in place.

Did he commit a felony?

NAPOLITANO: I don't think he did because he prepared the document, it would also depend on what's in the document; I don't believe that there was anything classified in there but that too is being investigated by the inspector general.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well there's a lot of open --

NAPOLITANO: So, --

BARTIROMO: -- investigations now about classified leaks.

Jeff Sessions told me there are 27 open investigations right now of classified leaks.

NAPOLITANO: -- Did he tell you --

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: -- any of them go back into the Clinton -- into the Obama administration?

BARTIROMO: "No."

But --

NAPOLITANO: Who unmasked General Flynn and the ambassador Kislyak --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- in the waning days of the Obama administration?

BARTIROMO: Right. And that was a clear felony which is what Devin Nunes - -

NAPOLITANO: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: -- said on the --

NAPOLITANO: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: -- air as well.

Final word Dagen?

MCDOWELL: No, I was just going to say, the inspector general can find out something - wrongdoing with Jim Comey and nothing happens to him except he is on a book tour where the talk show hosts are genuflecting in his presence.

NAPOLITANO: And he'll make a fortune.

BARTIROMO: Well by the way --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- the inspector general we're expecting it in March?

CHAFFETZ: I think that's -- yes --

MCDOWELL: Yes --

CHAFFETZ: -- I think it's --

MCDOWELL: -- soon.

CHAFFETZ: -- within the next 45 days or so.

The --

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: -- administration will get about a thirty-day heads up, that is the procedure.

They'll give it to him 30 days heads up but then they'll come -- I believe to the Oversight Committee.

BARTIROMO: All right, well 10 people have already been reassigned or fired, leading up to that report so we'll see if there's connection there.

Judge, thank you.

NAPOLITANO: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Judge Napolitano.

We'll be right back.

Stay with us, we're talking about NASA astronauts next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

BREAKING NEWS this morning, big news from the NFL.

Lauren Simonetti on it right now --

SIMONETTI: All right -- Maria, the NFL didn't take long to find a replacement for its pizza sponsor.

As you know, just yesterday, the League broke off its relationship with Papa John's.

And moments ago, it was announced that Pizza Hut is now the official pizza sponsor of the NFL multi-year agreement that will offer Pizza Hut and array of exclusive marketing rights connected with the League.

Shares of Yum! Brands are up more than 20 percent in the past year but you saw what happened to Papa John's shares yesterday, on that news, there were down seven percent in the after-hours.

Well three astronauts are back and earth after 5 1/2 months in space, two NASA astronauts and a Russian cosmonaut, undocked from the international space station and they fell back to earth yesterday, landing safely in the below freezing temperatures of Kazakhstan, closing out their long mission.

A replacement crew including a former teacher will lift off from Kazakhstan on March 21st, and bring the space station backup to a full crew of six.

And the moon -- I never thought I'd say this, the Moon is getting a mobile phone network, Moon, Moon and Nokia are teaming up to build a space network that allows high definition streaming from the moon back to earth.

It will provide communication support for an unmanned mission by scientists, that's scheduled to launch next year.

Here's a look at how Vodafone and Nokia are trading ahead of the opening bell, basically unchanged for both.

Levi's has an easier way to rip its jeans, the holes cost money. The company plans to use lasers to punch holes in fray the fabric instead of relying on human beings who use sandpaper, rotary tools, and chemicals to get the job done in about 20 minutes time; this new laser process takes one minute, 30 seconds.

I personally wonder if the machines will bring down the price because like I said, those holes are expensive.

And a reboot for the "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

Now this is a story all about how My life got flipped, turned upside down And I'd like to take a minute Just sit right there I'll tell you how I became The prince of a town called Bel-Air

(IN VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: The Will Smith sitcom, ran from 1990 to 1996, TMZ is reporting that if there is a reboot, there might be a new heir, not a prince but a princess.

The company that owns the rights to Fresh Prince has reportedly filed a trademark application seeking to lock down rights to 'Fresh Princess.'

I don't know!

I guess he can sell more clothing and accessories --

BARTIROMO: Hmm!

SIMONETTI: -- based on how she dresses, that's true.

BARTIROMO: Look at the business opportunities.

Thanks Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

BARTIROMO: Coming up next, a fairytale diet that could turn into a nightmare for your health, why doctors are warning about the so-called Cinderella Weight Challenge, wait until you hear this, 'Doctor Mike up next.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well a dangerous new dieting trend, the Cinderella Weight goal has people aiming for a target that the Department of Health and Human Services says is, 'underweight.'

Joining me now is Dr. Mikhail Varshavski, better known as 'Doctor Mike.'

'Doctor Mike' tell us about this diet?

DR. MIKHAIL VARSHAVSKI, DO, FAMILY MEDICINE PRACTICING FAMILY PRACTITIONER, ATLANTIC HEALTH SYSTEM & FAMILY MEDICINE RESIDENT OVERLOOK MEDICAL CENTER IN SUMMIT, NEW JERSEY: This is -- it just gets crazier and crazier, all these things that you see on social media. First, we had the 'Tide Pod Challenge' which is insane in --

BARTIROMO: Ridiculous.

VARSHAVSKI: -- its own right and now this diet trend, it's not even a diet, it's a weight goal for kids to look like Cinderella which is not a healthy way.

The formula that they give these kids to calculate what their weight should be would put them at a BMI of underweight, that category of being underweight, and basically what this is doing is, fueling our already insane -- fetish -- it's really a fetish, for being underweight and creating eating disorders.

BARTIROMO: But why is it so dangerous?

What -- I mean, I --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- understand the goal to get that thin is actually underweight --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but what specifics are there --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

Bartiromo: -- in this diet that --

VARSHAVSKI: When --

BARTIROMO: -- so dangerous?

VARSHAVSKI: -- when you go on a crash diet, on a fat diet, and you try and become underweight, what happens is you get kidney damage, you get cardiac --

BARTIROMO: Hmm!

VARSHAVSKI: -- damage, you get depressed immune function, early-onset osteoporosis, and your bones get more fragile.

And what happens is, when you develop an eating disorder, it's not just about your immune system or cardiac function, which is of course important but it's a complex system of obsession, anxiety, depression.

And luckily right now this week is the National Eating Disorder Awareness Week and this is the time that we need to take a story like this and put it out there that we need to remove the stigma of talking about eating disorders.

MCDOWELL: I don't, I --

VARSHAVSKI: Well anybody can have an eating --

MCDOWELL: -- well I'll say it, I had an eating disorder for years and I had bulimia and it is -- it is dangerous because you develop habits.

The younger you develop them whether it starving yourself or binging and purging, that you will carry for the rest of your life and it does massive damage to your body but it also psychologically -- these are patterns that are very difficult to break.

VARSHAVSKI: Very difficult.

Thirty million people in the United States will have an issue with this so I'm - I'm glad you're sharing --

MCDOWELL: No. I've never --

VARSHAVSKI: -- your story, this is --

MCDOWELL: -- have never said that publicly, there's -- there's nobody outside of my --

VARSHAVSKI: Thank you for that (ph).

MCDOWELL: -- family who knows that but I will add this, I don't get on scales, I haven't been on a scale even in the doctor's office, I just don't --

BARTIROMO: But you're very healthy now, you're healthy -- you're a healthy eater and you exercise -- MCDOWELL: -- Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- regularly?

MCDOWELL: I'm - I'm a vegan and I ran -I've run 30 miles in the last four days so there you go.

VARSHAVSKI: The -- again, I applaud you for that because we need more people like you to come out and talk about this because what happens is, you see on social media all these crazy body figures and its really Photoshop, CGI --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARSHAVSKI: -- plastic surgery, and kids --

MCDOWELL: And I --

VARSHAVSKI: -- look at this and they think this is --

BARTIROMO: They think --

VARSHAVSKI: -- real

BARTIROMO: -- it is --

VARSHAVSKI: -- they think this is realistic.

BARTIROMO: -- natural.

MCDOWELL: And the parents do ignore the warning signs.

You have to watch particularly young women, there are warning signs --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- like sneaky behavior, not eating at the dinner table, eating too much, there are a lot of things that the parents need to kind of open their eyes to.

VARSHAVSKI: Listen a hundred percent, that's why -- I work at Overlook Medical Center and the Atlantic Health System and we have an adolescent center for eating disorders and the best thing, the evidence-based treatment that we focus on is family-based therapy.

Because it's --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

VARSHAVSKI: -- about parents who spend the most of their time with their children, who are the ones around during the meals that have to take action, with the help of a therapist and someone else from the hospital.

BARTIROMO: So, the healthiest of weight (ph) eat and exercise is?

VARSHAVSKI: Talk to your doctor, figure out what's best for you because there's no individual thing that works for everybody.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, 'Doctor Mike' always great advice from you. Thank you.

VARSHAVSKI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: 'Doctor Mike' there.

Still ahead, Amazon has a nice ring to it, the technology chain buying the makers of the Smart Doorbell, how the -- how the deal could change the way you get your deliveries, next hour, right here, on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday, it is Wednesday, February 28th; your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Economic boom, economists are awaiting the second reading on the fourth quarter GDP, that's zero 1030 minutes, we will have the numbers as soon as they hit the tape; economists are expecting the GDP to come in and show growth of 2 1/2 percent.

urn:contentItem:5RS4-Y6V1-DXH2-61G1-00000-00Gun Control Debate; Interview with Andy Barr; Gates Slams Crypto; McDonald's and Disney Launch Happy Meal Partnership; Investors Are Awaiting The Second Reading Of Fourth Quarter GDP; Attorney General Jeff Sessions Says That The Justice Department Will Probe Alleged Abuses By The Obama Administration Against The Trump Transition Team2018-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:09ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTAndy Barr, Scott Wren, Mikhail VarshavskiNEWSFinancial022802cb.231Gun Control Debate; Interview with Andy Barr; Gates Slams Crypto; McDonald's and Disney Launch Happy Meal Partnership; Investors Are Awaiting The Second Reading Of Fourth Quarter GDP; Attorney General Jeff Sessions Says That The Justice Department Will Probe Alleged Abuses By The Obama Administration Against The Trump Transition TeamMaria Bartiromo, Mary Kissel, Dagen McDowell, Jason Chaffetz, Lauren Simonetti, Andrew Napolitano

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back.

Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, February 28th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Return of the bears -- the Dow snapping a three-day winning streak yesterday, closing down nearly 300 points. Investors were spooked after Federal Reserve Chairman J. Powell signaled that the strong economy could lead to more interest rate hikes.

Futures indicating the markets are bouncing back a bit today. Take a look. We are basically back at the break-even level.

We've seen a pretty selloff in the last 10 minutes actually. The Dow Industrials now flat, as is the S&P 500. Nasdaq up a point. But again these are well off of the highs of the morning here.

Investors are waiting on the fourth quarter GDP. It's due out in about 90 minutes. Economists are looking for the GDP to show growth of 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter.

In Europe this morning, stocks are lower across the board. Take a look. FT 100, CAC 40, DAX index down between a third of a percent and one-half of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, red across the board. Worst performers were in Hong Kong and Japan, down 1.5 percent apiece.

The battle over gun control back in the U.S. as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today. President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence.

Vice President Mike Pence promised the White House will do all it can to keep students safe.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: No child, no teacher should ever be in danger in an American school. I want to make you a promise. We will not rest until we make our schools safe again.
