MCDOWELL: They can revoke -- but the inspector general can basically remove someone's security clearance, can't they?

CHAFFETZ: -- well they can make that recommendation --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: -- but they can't remove it.

What I think they should do is that Congress should hear from the judges themselves.

BARTIROMO: Me too.

CHAFFETZ: I just -- I really wish -- we had tried this when I was in the House, on the House Judiciary but they should call of those judges and have them testify about the process, how it works.

We've been told that it's so secret you can't do that.

NAPOLITANO: It would really be a first!

You know, you know, I have a friend who is on the FISA court and when this judge walks into the courthouse, he is patted down; when this judge, not a clerk, a judge --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- leaves the courthouse, he's patted down.

He doesn't have an iPhone with him, he doesn't have a pen or pencil with him, he doesn't have papers with him, he doesn't have a briefcase; that's how secret it is.

The judges do not have records of what they do in that courthouse.

Who has those records?

"The NSA."

What's the NSA?

"The Litigant," that's appearing before the court.

BARTIROMO: But you're -- if you're judge and you're -- you're given information, I mean you have to make sure that that information is accurate.

I mean we want to know why it is that a judge allowed the dossier, only, I don't think there was too much more to actually warrant a search warrant --

NAPOLITANO: It's --

BARTIROMO: -- and --

NAPOLITANO: -- it's so different and Congressman Chaffetz understands this:

(a), it's in secret --

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- as I said, so there's no records. The press doesn't know, we don't have eyes and ears in the courtroom.

(b), just as important, there is no adversary.

If you are presenting a document to me and you're not telling me everything about it, your adversary is going to point that out to me but where there is no adversary it's very easy for you to pull the wool over my eyes.

There was a proposal not too long ago to have a standing adversary in the - -

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- FISA court. The adversary doesn't represent the person whose surveillance is sought but the adversary challenges the government's documents which would force the government to --

BARTIROMO: But --

NAPOLITANO: -- dot every "i" and --

BARTIROMO: -- so nobody --

NAPOLITANO: -- cross every "t" --

BARTIROMO: -- challenges anything?

NAPOLITANO: Correct.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. But if the process is so corrupted Judge, if you have let's say a president Hillary Clinton and her friends at the top of the FBI, if that had happened and you have this process --

NAPOLITANO: They could surveil anybody.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- They could surveil anybody.

NAPOLITANO: Right.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. So, isn't it time to talk about getting rid of this court?

NAPOLITANO: Absolutely.

I've been arguing since 1978, Jason was a little boy but this court has been unconstitutional.

BARTIROMO: Devin Nunes has said that -- he suggested, Luke we need a FISA court but, but, but, I if this kind of abuse of continues we may look to not fund this FISA court.

NAPOLITANO: A, it tampers with the standard that's in the Constitution, from probable cause of crime to probable cause of speaking to a foreign person, that is a radically lower standard.

Congress can change the Constitution and it's purported to do so. B, it meets a secret. C, it's not a real court because there's no adversary in the courtroom.

CHAFFETZ: But Congress just reauthorized it. They reauthorized it and then like 48 hours later --

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: -- they announced all these potential abuses --

NAPOLITANO: I appreciate --

Chef it's: -- of the FISA court.

NAPOLITANO: -- what Devin Nunes is doing but he in my opinion committed a grave wrong by sitting on all this while Congress was debating the reauthorization --

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- of FISA.

He permitted more power in the hands of the very people whom he accused of abusing that power.

BARTIROMO: Why?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE. Yes, but there's been no evidence that Section 702 that was reauthorized has been abuse.

My question to you Judge is, what executive would want the FISA court to go away because if that court went away, then the executive branch would be wholly --

NAPOLITANO: Directly responsible --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- responsible, directly responsible --

NAPOLITANO: -- Correct.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: -- for the surveillance.

BARTIROMO: That's --

NAPOLITANO: It's --

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

NAPOLITANO: -- it's extraordinary power to the executive branch.

BARTIROMO: Wow!

NAPOLITANO: Very difficult to get any entity, Congress or the president to shrink its own power.

BARTIROMO: Wow!

NAPOLITANO: It will take an extremely principled person to do that.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my goodness!

Well we've got to get to this as well because FBI, former FBI director Jim Comey is bashing President Trump, again, ahead of his book release.

Comey tweeted out a picture of himself, recording the audio version of his new tell-all book last night, and wrote, "Lordy, this time there will be a tape; audiobook almost finished."

His caption references president Trump's Tweet last year that conversations between the two men have been recorded.

Judge your reaction to this?

He --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- he keeps poking the president --

NAPOLITANO: -- Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- meanwhile all of this wrong-doing went on, on his watch.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

Yes, and I don't know what he's doing.

I am - he -- my guess he thought it was funny and, in some sense, it might be a little, mildly humorous, `this time there will be a tape' because when president Trump said "James Comey better hope there isn't a tape,' and then Congress tried to get the tape and then the president said, "OK, there wasn't a tape. I was just suggesting that he better hope that there isn't one."

This is a reference to that. I think it's inside the beltway and inside base (ph) but --

MCDOWELL: He's auditioning for those late-night talk shows --

BARTIROMO: Hmm --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- because he needs those appearances to hump that lousy book --

NAPOLITANO: Correct.

MCDOWELL: -- that's coming out.

NAPOLITANO: Correct. It may be a great book --

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: -- it may be a challenging (ph) book, it may be garbage, I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Guys, we know that Jim Comey leaked something to his friend to get it into "The New York Times" so that they could get a special counsel in place.

Did he commit a felony?

NAPOLITANO: I don't think he did because he prepared the document, it would also depend on what's in the document; I don't believe that there was anything classified in there but that too is being investigated by the inspector general.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well there's a lot of open --

NAPOLITANO: So, --

BARTIROMO: -- investigations now about classified leaks.

Jeff Sessions told me there are 27 open investigations right now of classified leaks.

NAPOLITANO: -- Did he tell you --

(CROSSTALK)

NAPOLITANO: -- any of them go back into the Clinton -- into the Obama administration?

BARTIROMO: "No."

But --

NAPOLITANO: Who unmasked General Flynn and the ambassador Kislyak --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: -- in the waning days of the Obama administration?

BARTIROMO: Right. And that was a clear felony which is what Devin Nunes - -

NAPOLITANO: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: -- said on the --

NAPOLITANO: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: -- air as well.

Final word Dagen?

MCDOWELL: No, I was just going to say, the inspector general can find out something - wrongdoing with Jim Comey and nothing happens to him except he is on a book tour where the talk show hosts are genuflecting in his presence.

NAPOLITANO: And he'll make a fortune.

BARTIROMO: Well by the way --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- the inspector general we're expecting it in March?

CHAFFETZ: I think that's -- yes --

MCDOWELL: Yes --

CHAFFETZ: -- I think it's --

MCDOWELL: -- soon.

CHAFFETZ: -- within the next 45 days or so.

The --

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: -- administration will get about a thirty-day heads up, that is the procedure.

They'll give it to him 30 days heads up but then they'll come -- I believe to the Oversight Committee.

BARTIROMO: All right, well 10 people have already been reassigned or fired, leading up to that report so we'll see if there's connection there.

Judge, thank you.

NAPOLITANO: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Judge Napolitano.

We'll be right back.

Stay with us, we're talking about NASA astronauts next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

BREAKING NEWS this morning, big news from the NFL.

Lauren Simonetti on it right now --

SIMONETTI: All right -- Maria, the NFL didn't take long to find a replacement for its pizza sponsor.

As you know, just yesterday, the League broke off its relationship with Papa John's.

And moments ago, it was announced that Pizza Hut is now the official pizza sponsor of the NFL multi-year agreement that will offer Pizza Hut and array of exclusive marketing rights connected with the League.

Shares of Yum! Brands are up more than 20 percent in the past year but you saw what happened to Papa John's shares yesterday, on that news, there were down seven percent in the after-hours.

Well three astronauts are back and earth after 5 1/2 months in space, two NASA astronauts and a Russian cosmonaut, undocked from the international space station and they fell back to earth yesterday, landing safely in the below freezing temperatures of Kazakhstan, closing out their long mission.

A replacement crew including a former teacher will lift off from Kazakhstan on March 21st, and bring the space station backup to a full crew of six.

And the moon -- I never thought I'd say this, the Moon is getting a mobile phone network, Moon, Moon and Nokia are teaming up to build a space network that allows high definition streaming from the moon back to earth.

It will provide communication support for an unmanned mission by scientists, that's scheduled to launch next year.

Here's a look at how Vodafone and Nokia are trading ahead of the opening bell, basically unchanged for both.

Levi's has an easier way to rip its jeans, the holes cost money. The company plans to use lasers to punch holes in fray the fabric instead of relying on human beings who use sandpaper, rotary tools, and chemicals to get the job done in about 20 minutes time; this new laser process takes one minute, 30 seconds.

I personally wonder if the machines will bring down the price because like I said, those holes are expensive.

And a reboot for the "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

Now this is a story all about how My life got flipped, turned upside down And I'd like to take a minute Just sit right there I'll tell you how I became The prince of a town called Bel-Air

(IN VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: The Will Smith sitcom, ran from 1990 to 1996, TMZ is reporting that if there is a reboot, there might be a new heir, not a prince but a princess.

The company that owns the rights to Fresh Prince has reportedly filed a trademark application seeking to lock down rights to `Fresh Princess.'

I don't know!

I guess he can sell more clothing and accessories --

BARTIROMO: Hmm!

SIMONETTI: -- based on how she dresses, that's true.

BARTIROMO: Look at the business opportunities.

Thanks Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Sure.

BARTIROMO: Coming up next, a fairytale diet that could turn into a nightmare for your health, why doctors are warning about the so-called Cinderella Weight Challenge, wait until you hear this, `Doctor Mike up next.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well a dangerous new dieting trend, the Cinderella Weight goal has people aiming for a target that the Department of Health and Human Services says is, `underweight.'

Joining me now is Dr. Mikhail Varshavski, better known as `Doctor Mike.'

`Doctor Mike' tell us about this diet?

DR. MIKHAIL VARSHAVSKI, DO, FAMILY MEDICINE PRACTICING FAMILY PRACTITIONER, ATLANTIC HEALTH SYSTEM & FAMILY MEDICINE RESIDENT OVERLOOK MEDICAL CENTER IN SUMMIT, NEW JERSEY: This is -- it just gets crazier and crazier, all these things that you see on social media. First, we had the `Tide Pod Challenge' which is insane in --

BARTIROMO: Ridiculous.

VARSHAVSKI: -- its own right and now this diet trend, it's not even a diet, it's a weight goal for kids to look like Cinderella which is not a healthy way.

The formula that they give these kids to calculate what their weight should be would put them at a BMI of underweight, that category of being underweight, and basically what this is doing is, fueling our already insane -- fetish -- it's really a fetish, for being underweight and creating eating disorders.

BARTIROMO: But why is it so dangerous?

What -- I mean, I --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- understand the goal to get that thin is actually underweight --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but what specifics are there --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

Bartiromo: -- in this diet that --

VARSHAVSKI: When --

BARTIROMO: -- so dangerous?

VARSHAVSKI: -- when you go on a crash diet, on a fat diet, and you try and become underweight, what happens is you get kidney damage, you get cardiac --

BARTIROMO: Hmm!

VARSHAVSKI: -- damage, you get depressed immune function, early-onset osteoporosis, and your bones get more fragile.

And what happens is, when you develop an eating disorder, it's not just about your immune system or cardiac function, which is of course important but it's a complex system of obsession, anxiety, depression.

And luckily right now this week is the National Eating Disorder Awareness Week and this is the time that we need to take a story like this and put it out there that we need to remove the stigma of talking about eating disorders.

MCDOWELL: I don't, I --

VARSHAVSKI: Well anybody can have an eating --

MCDOWELL: -- well I'll say it, I had an eating disorder for years and I had bulimia and it is -- it is dangerous because you develop habits.

The younger you develop them whether it starving yourself or binging and purging, that you will carry for the rest of your life and it does massive damage to your body but it also psychologically -- these are patterns that are very difficult to break.

VARSHAVSKI: Very difficult.

Thirty million people in the United States will have an issue with this so I'm - I'm glad you're sharing --

MCDOWELL: No. I've never --

VARSHAVSKI: -- your story, this is --

MCDOWELL: -- have never said that publicly, there's -- there's nobody outside of my --

VARSHAVSKI: Thank you for that (ph).

MCDOWELL: -- family who knows that but I will add this, I don't get on scales, I haven't been on a scale even in the doctor's office, I just don't --

BARTIROMO: But you're very healthy now, you're healthy -- you're a healthy eater and you exercise -- MCDOWELL: -- Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- regularly?

MCDOWELL: I'm - I'm a vegan and I ran -I've run 30 miles in the last four days so there you go.

VARSHAVSKI: The -- again, I applaud you for that because we need more people like you to come out and talk about this because what happens is, you see on social media all these crazy body figures and its really Photoshop, CGI --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARSHAVSKI: -- plastic surgery, and kids --

MCDOWELL: And I --

VARSHAVSKI: -- look at this and they think this is --

BARTIROMO: They think --

VARSHAVSKI: -- real

BARTIROMO: -- it is --

VARSHAVSKI: -- they think this is realistic.

BARTIROMO: -- natural.

MCDOWELL: And the parents do ignore the warning signs.

You have to watch particularly young women, there are warning signs --

VARSHAVSKI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- like sneaky behavior, not eating at the dinner table, eating too much, there are a lot of things that the parents need to kind of open their eyes to.

VARSHAVSKI: Listen a hundred percent, that's why -- I work at Overlook Medical Center and the Atlantic Health System and we have an adolescent center for eating disorders and the best thing, the evidence-based treatment that we focus on is family-based therapy.

Because it's --

MCDOWELL: Yes.

VARSHAVSKI: -- about parents who spend the most of their time with their children, who are the ones around during the meals that have to take action, with the help of a therapist and someone else from the hospital.

BARTIROMO: So, the healthiest of weight (ph) eat and exercise is?

VARSHAVSKI: Talk to your doctor, figure out what's best for you because there's no individual thing that works for everybody.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, `Doctor Mike' always great advice from you. Thank you.

VARSHAVSKI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: `Doctor Mike' there.

Still ahead, Amazon has a nice ring to it, the technology chain buying the makers of the Smart Doorbell, how the -- how the deal could change the way you get your deliveries, next hour, right here, on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Wednesday, it is Wednesday, February 28th; your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Economic boom, economists are awaiting the second reading on the fourth quarter GDP, that's zero 1030 minutes, we will have the numbers as soon as they hit the tape; economists are expecting the GDP to come in and show growth of 2 1/2 percent.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Market there taking a cue from yesterday's performance on Wall Street and that is lower. FT-100 down a third of a percent, CAC Quarante in Paris down one half of one percent, and the DAX Index in Germany down a third of a percent, forty points lower.

In Asia overnight, we're right across the board, take a look. Worst performer there, Japan. Nikkei Average down almost one and a half percent.

The battle over gun control, as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today, President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence. I'll speak with one of the students from Marjory Stone Douglas High School about his return to school later this hour.

And the debate is having a major impact on the business world as well. The latest as several states including New York, Ohio, court -- Delta Airlines following Georgia lawmaker's threat to end any tax benefits for Delta over its decision to cut ties with the NRA.

A health scare in the Virginia Military Base, the details as 11 people fall ill after opening a letter containing an unknown substance. We'll bring you the latest.

And a deal at their doorstep, Amazon putting a ring on it, acquiring the smart doorbell maker for $! Billion, what it means for your deliveries, coming up this morning.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowelll. Former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee Chairman and Fox News Contributor, Jason CHaffetz. And the "Wall Street Journal's" Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel is here. Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning Maria, thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good morning to you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: When I saw the guests was yesterday, "I can't wait to hear what Mary and Jason have to say. So that means I'm going to stifle.

BARTIROMO: No, we don't want that. We don't want -- but it's true, we're grateful that you're both here this morning. What's on your mind? What's most important in your mind right now?

CHAFFETZ: I'm still reeling over what the republicans have done to run up government spending. I see a lot of good economic news, the GDP but the government component in the run up and spending, I think it's going to hamper the economy, I really do.

KISSEL: Hey, even Warren Buffet is coming around to the -- to the benefits of the tax reform. I never thought you'd see that.

BARTIROMO: Well, he got a huge benefit for his company, didn't he?

KISSEL: Yes, he sure did. Don't we underestimate the benefit of tax cuts? We always underestimate the benefits.

MCDOWELL: No, I agree, I don't think it's going to be, well, it cost a trillion dollars but I do think that there's certain pockets that are good of the economy like housing that are going to get hurt by this.

BARTIROMO: By the way, we should point out that this GDP number is decelerating from what we saw in the third-quarter. I mean, in the third- quarter, we had growth of 3.2 percent. And in the fourth quarter, the initial reading was 2.6 percent. So, anyway you look at it, things have slowed down a bit in the couple of -- in the last couple of months.

MCDOWELL: But this was before the tax reform goes --

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Right. Yes, it was.

MCDOWELL: So, that's before the tax reform and spending.

BARTIROMO: Exactly, yes.

MCDOWELL: So, in this -- in this, you will see -- you will see it pick up steam.

BARTIROMO: We want to -- we want to get the White House reaction to this number. Hogan Gidley is the Deputy White House Press Secretary. He's joining us right now, and of course, we also want to talk about students returning to class at Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida exactly two weeks after 17 people were killed. In Washington, the President is set to meet with a bipartisan congressional group on school safety today, trying to make progress on legislation to combat gun violence.

Joining us right now from the White House, Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley. Hogan, thanks very much for joining us this morning. Before we get into the return to school, let me get your take on what's happening in the economy right now because the GDP is just out, and it shows a growth number of 2.5 percent but that's down from 3-1/4 percent in the third- quarter what's going on, things have decelerated.

HOGAN GIDLEY, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: Well, they have, but the overall economy is strong, and as I just heard, Dagen, I think pointed out and she's absolutely right, that's before the tax cuts even took effect. We had some massive hurricanes, unprecedented amounts of damage, but also destruction that occurred in so many places across the country.

BARTIROMO: Wait a second, all of this -- all of this is before the tax plan. We're talking about the fourth-quarter. So, the tax plan went into effect the beginning of '18.

GIDLEY: But I'm saying -- right, but I'm saying expectations are that that will actually go up, it's still much higher obviously than President Barack Obama's economy which he said 1.9 percent was the new norm. We're on the way up, most economists say we're going to be hovering close to potentially four percent, as this year continues on, and that's where we expect to be. The economy is strong, businesses are coming back to this country, as you well know, consumer confidence is at all-time high, and we expect that to continue to grow even more into the new year.

BARTIROMO: Well, in terms of economic policy, what are the President's priorities at this point, Hogan? Because, I know that he wants to work on Dodd-Frank, and he's been rolling back regulations in a big way since the start of his presidency. That should add further spice to this market. What's the priority in terms of economic policy in the coming six or eight months?

GIDLEY: It will, but look, let's talk about those regulations and their rollback. The big way kind of doesn't begin to describe it. Look, he said that he would cut two regulations for every one that he put into place. He far exceeded that, and he's cutting 22 regulations for every one that gets put into place. Obviously, that spurs on consumer confidence but also security and stabilization in business growth, and that's what this President is all about, as you know. And the rapid turnaround of this economy is no coincidence.

It's because we have someone in office who understands the economy, who's going to push to make this tax cut permanent for individuals as he did with the corporate tax rate cut, but there's a pattern emerging here with this President, and that is he's taking on topics and issues that haven't been addressed in the better part of 30 to 40 years. He's coming in in a year's time, he's accomplishing record-setting things, and recording setting time, and he's growing this economy, something that the government quite frankly, has been crippling under the last eight years.

BARTIROMO: Right. So, are you expecting movement on Dodd-Frank in the coming few months?

GIDLEY: We'll see. I don't want to get ahead of what President is going to say or do, but we obviously know that that's what the President wants to be, he wants to eliminate all hindrances to economic well-being in this country. He wants to prop up middle America, as you saw with the tax cuts, it didn't just effect the corporate tax rate that people have been talking about for 30 or 40 years, but it also cut taxes for the middle-income people in this country, and that's where he's going to continuing to go.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, we're getting a report this morning that the President is looking to roll back the Volcker Rule, for example, and this is a rule, obviously where proprietary trading firms do -- cannot do proprietary trading and just trade for customers but not their own, so is that something that's going to be changed over the near-term, the Volcker Rule.

GIDLEY: Again, I can't get ahead of what the President is going to say or do. He's going to talk also about trade today. He's going to make some announcements on that as well. That should impact the economy, too, because, look, for far too long, what we've been talking about in this country, politicians as you know, for decades, go out on a campaign trail and what they say is we want free and fair trade.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GIDLEY: Well, the free trade is always there. It's the fair part that politicians seem to ignore once they get in office. And this President comes in and says, no more. This has been dogging our country for decades. It's going to stop now and it's going to stop on my watch, and so, we'll see what he announces later today.

BARTIROMO: On trade, is the U.S. going to re-enter TPP.

GIDLEY: Again, I can't get ahead of what the President is going to say or do, Maria. I appreciate you pushing me that direction but the President has some ideas to how to fix this economy. He's done a masterful job so far and we expect that to continue.

BARTIROMO: Hogan, the President obviously has been spending a lot of time on efforts to try to come up with solutions for gun safety, school safety, really. The President is hoping to jumpstart some real action on background checks or other plans. Tell me where that stands right now, and what does need to be done, in terms of background checks?

GIDLEY: Donald Trump is not just the President of the United States. He's also a father and he's also a grandfather. And what he wants is what everybody in this country wants, which is safety and security for our children when they go to school, that's just the bottom line. Legislation can't just feel good, it actually has to do good. And that's what the President is trying to get to the bottom of now when he's talking to all the relevant stakeholders. The country was privy to a meeting he had with grieving families, from the Parkland shooting, other relative stakeholders from around the Washington, D.C. area, parents, teachers, students --

BARTIROMO: Right.

GIDLEY: -- just pouring out their heart, they were angry, they were upset. They were upset --

BARTIROMO: Yes. No, that was a -- that was a good idea we did the listening session.

GIDLEY: Right. But they were also hopeful that something would get done. So, the President then went met with local law enforcement, then he met with governors, people who were on the frontlines of all these issues and how they can be impacted at the local level because, as you know, state and federal partnerships are key if we're going to actually accomplish something here. But when he meets with the Congressional leaders today from individual congressional districts, bipartisan, bicameral, they've got to come up with solutions that actually protect children. We can't just talk about it anymore. The American people deserve better.

BARTIROMO: So, is he -- is he prepared to put forth an executive order bypassing Congress to raise the age limit for getting a gun?

GIDLEY: Well, it depends on what happens after the talks, it depends on what Congress decides to do and also with the local areas decide to do as well. The President sees that there's obviously a gaping hole in security. There was a systematic failure here at every level of government, whether it was the FBI, whether it was the county sheriff, and then the deputy sitting outside the school that were trained and had a gun and still didn't go inside to protect those kids. Obviously, failures exist, the audit continues, and once we get that information, the President will make recommendations this week on what he feels should be done to protect students in our schools.

BARTIROMO: What do you make of all these companies waiting into this issue? Dick's Sporting Goods this morning says that it's no longer going to sell automatic-style weapons. It's going to require consumers to be 21 years old to purchase any firearm, regardless of the law of the land, Dick's Sporting Goods says. What do you -- what do you make of the private sector making these changes? Is that legal?

GIDLEY: Yes, I don't know if it's legal or not, I'm not an attorney, but it doesn't seem to match up with federal law. But I mean, look, we've got states all over the country, deciding to thumb their nose at the federal government and the laws on the books whether it's California and sanctuary cities, for example. But look, these businesses have made decisions based on pressure from outside groups. I guess they have the right to do that, I guess groups have the right to protest, but the bottom line is we have, you know, 6 million gun owners that are members of the NRA that are law-abiding citizens. This President supports the second amendment, supports the NRA and their efforts to keep our country safe. And we have a constitutional right in this country to keep and bear arms. And so, if a business decides that they're going to kowtow to pressure from outside groups, I guess they can do that, but then they're going to have to suffer the consequences should other side come out and put pressure on them as well.

BARTIROMO: Hogan, let me ask you about that big announcement from the President yesterday, announcing that his digital strategist, Brad Prascale will run the Trump 2020 campaign. Why did the president make this announcement now, telling everybody he is in fact running for re-election?

GIDLEY: I love you keep asking me questions I really can't talk about. That's a campaign issue.

BARTIROMO: Why not?

GIDLEY: Well, it's a campaign issue, I have to refer you over to the campaign to have that discussion. But look, the President is going to have a myriad of successes to run on in the 2020 election. As you know, the Heritage Foundation just put out a survey basically saying that this President has already accomplished 64 percent of his agenda, Ronald Reagan, the standard bearer of our party for a long time and of government success for the Republicans was only at 47 percent at this time. So, as I mentioned before, it's record-setting accomplishments and record-setting time for Donald Trump. And whoever the campaign manager is for this President, they'll have a lot to push moving into the election cycle.

BARTIROMO: All right. Hogan, great stuff, thanks so much for joining us this morning.

GIDLEY: Thanks so much, Maria. Have a great day.

BARTIROMO: Hogan Gidley joining us there. Thank you. We'll be right back. Back in a minute. Markets at the highs right now up 50 points on the GDP number. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Lowe's under pressure this morning, reporting earnings as well. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Nic, good morning to you.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. So, we are seeing Lowe's under extreme pressure this morning. We see the Dow Futures higher but Lowe's will be to the downside and likely to be one of the biggest losers here on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, down 70-1/4 percent right now, the quarterly numbers. What happened to Lowe's when Home Depot six quarters in a row beat? Well, Lowe's missed. They missed on their quarterly profit, the growth margin, all a miss. Same-store sales growth going forward to guidance. Well, that's going to slow, too. They said they've been spending a lot in order to fend off big competition, so it's clear at this time that Home Depot is really king in the home improvement retailing.

And then we take a look at Amazon. Amazon, a new acquisition, and this is Ring. $1 billion. Ring is home security. Everybody has been seeing the commercials or video doorbells, that is the idea, it adds to Blink which is what they got last year. And it takes on some of the other guys. Well, ADT is to the downside this morning. Alphabet's home unit, a home -- smart home security unit. So, if this is just Amazon expanding beyond and now that it'll also contribute to Amazon Key where they actually have a smart lock, and you go in, you have your package or your fresh food drops up. So, that's big acquisition, they're buying the start-up Ring for $1 billion, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much. Technology titans facing a boycott for ties to the National Rifles Association. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney weighing in. Stu, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. This seems to be three separate things going on here. You have the news this morning that Dick's Sporting Goods is not going to sell these assault-style rifles to anybody under 21. We got that piece of news. I think that's their business, it's their policy. Do as you will, Dick's Sporting Goods. Then there is the Boycott NRA Movement, like against Delta, United Airlines, that kind of thing. I'm worded about that because it's the politicization of business. When I buy a product or a service, I buy according to price and quality, not according to the politics of the company selling me that product or service.

But the most pernicious attack on free speech, in my opinion, comes from this attempt to silence the NRA on Amazon, Google, Roku, and Apple. Those organizations run videos of the NRA from the NRA, and there is now a serious movement to ban them from all those outlets. That is deliberately stomping on free speech. The left does not like guns, so shut up the NRA. I think that's absolutely flat-out wrong. There is no question. This is an ongoing story as businesses forced to react to the ongoing problem with guns.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I'm surprised that so many businesses have reacted this way, Dagen. I mean, I am. I --

MCDOWELL: And I want to get see people get mad that Planned Parenthood is now reportedly involved in these -- helping these Parkland, Florida students organize.

VARNEY: Yes, you know --

MCDOWELL: So how the wise Planned Parenthood involved in gun control laws? Just asking.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: I'd just like to know how we get rifles out of the hands of demented 19-year-olds. If you could do that, you solve a lot of problems.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point.

VARNEY: But I don't have an answer.

BARTIROMO: Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes. Thank you. "VARNEY & COMPANY" top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Another milestone for LeBron. Jared Max with sports headlines now. Jared?

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: Good morning, Maria. First time in LeBron's 15-year career, he has averaged a triple-double for every game in one month. Double digits, three statistical categories. LeBron became the oldest player in NBA history to accomplish this eclectic feet when he helped the Cavalier beat the Nets last night, LeBron also the first NBA player to total more than 30,000 points, 8,000 rebounds, 8,000 assists. LeBron thinks the NBA can assist teenage athletes who have the talent to become pro-basketball players but don't feel suited or interested in playing NCAA ball but don't want to go overseas to play.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LEBRON JAMES, AMERICAN BASKETBALL PLAYER: NCAA is historic. We know it. I'm sorry. It's going to make headlines that (INAUDIBLE) sign at 14 but they get put into this farm system where they'll able to grow and be around other professionals for three or four years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: LeBron says the NCAA is corrupt. Wants to see the NBA create a farm system.

Move over Papa John's, here comes Pizza Hut. The new official sponsor of the NFL for pizza. Multi-year deal includes collected use of 32 NFL team trademarks to facilitate local exclusive team partnerships. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell says, we're thrilled to have Pizza Hut as a partner.

Let's take a look at Pizza Hut's parent Yum! Brands on the stock board. Now, Pizza Hut assumes Papa John's role as the official pizza of the NFL. Papa John's came under fire last season when the company founder John Schnatter suggested sales were down because of the NFL's mishandling of players kneeling for the anthem. The two mutually decided to part ways yesterday.

As Major League Baseball rosters fill out with younger, less expensive talent, some high-priced free agents are still looking for work. And so, the players association has filed a grievance against four baseball teams: the Marlins, the Rays, the Pirates, and the A's. All accused of failing to appropriately spend revenue sharing money to improve their clubs.

Hey, do you see the mascots that were chosen for the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo? Students from 16,769 elementary schools in Japan chose the mascots and the winner was drawn by a graduate of Cabrillo College in California, Ryo Taniguchi. One student who voted for the design said it looks futuristic but also represents Japan traditions. Some of the (INAUDIBLE) that didn't quite make the cut are these guys. Plus, it could work as Olympic mascots.

BARTIROMO: Cool. What are you expecting from Tokyo 2020?

MAX: Hopefully, a little bit more fun and less controversy than these Olympics. Where it's just strictly about the game and maybe two years from now, we get to a different point where people can make comments about each other and we keep the politics outside of sports.

BARTIROMO: Did you watch it?

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. You did, we did.

KISSEL: I love the Olympics. Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: OK. OK.

KISSEL: Watch it every year. Oh, I love to win.

(CROSSTALK)

CHAFFETZ: The women who won the cross-country, that --

MAX: Awesome.

CHAFFETZ: That was --

MAX: The (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: But the ratings were not what past Olympics were. That's why I asked because it wasn't as much of a must watch as in past.

KISSEL: Oh, our figure skaters stink but our snowboarders are amazing.

MAX: Snowboard cross. I would watch it every night. Snowboard cross.

KISSEL: It's incredible what they do.

MAX: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Jared. Jared Max. Catch his sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7 or Sirius XM 115. We're back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Great panel today. Thank you so much Mary Kissel, Jason Chaffetz, it's great to see you.

CHAFFETZ: (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Dagen McDowell, great show. We will see you tomorrow, everybody. Here's "VARNEY & COMPANY". Stuart, over to you.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Market there taking a cue from yesterday's performance on Wall Street and that is lower. FT-100 down a third of a percent, CAC Quarante in Paris down one half of one percent, and the DAX Index in Germany down a third of a percent, forty points lower.

In Asia overnight, we're right across the board, take a look. Worst performer there, Japan. Nikkei Average down almost one and a half percent.

The battle over gun control, as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today, President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence. I'll speak with one of the students from Marjory Stone Douglas High School about his return to school later this hour.

And the debate is having a major impact on the business world as well. The latest as several states including New York, Ohio, court -- Delta Airlines following Georgia lawmaker's threat to end any tax benefits for Delta over its decision to cut ties with the NRA.

A health scare in the Virginia Military Base, the details as 11 people fall ill after opening a letter containing an unknown substance. We'll bring you the latest.

And a deal at their doorstep, Amazon putting a ring on it, acquiring the smart doorbell maker for $! Billion, what it means for your deliveries, coming up this morning.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowelll. Former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee Chairman and Fox News Contributor, Jason CHaffetz. And the "Wall Street Journal's" Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel is here. Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning Maria, thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good morning to you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

KISSEL: I mean, essentially, the administration is betting that the tax cut and the benefits from the tax cuts are going to run for a long time, that and also cutting the red tape, that will somehow outrun or at least stave off this interest rate scare that people are so worried about that you're talking about.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: The tax reform did reduce the amount of mortgage and interest deduction, you can say.

KISSEL: Hey, even Warren Buffet is coming around to the -- to the benefits of the tax reform. I never thought you'd see that.

BARTIROMO: Well, he got a huge benefit for his company, didn't he?

KISSEL: Yes, he sure did. Don't we underestimate the benefit of tax cuts? We always underestimate the benefits.

MCDOWELL: No, I agree, I don't think it's going to be, well, it cost a trillion dollars but I do think that there's certain pockets that are good of the economy like housing that are going to get hurt by this.

BARTIROMO: By the way, we should point out that this GDP number is decelerating from what we saw in the third-quarter. I mean, in the third- quarter, we had growth of 3.2 percent. And in the fourth quarter, the initial reading was 2.6 percent. So, anyway you look at it, things have slowed down a bit in the couple of -- in the last couple of months.

MCDOWELL: But this was before the tax reform goes --

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Right. Yes, it was.

MCDOWELL: So, that's before the tax reform and spending.

BARTIROMO: Exactly, yes.

MCDOWELL: So, in this -- in this, you will see -- you will see it pick up steam.

BARTIROMO: We want to -- we want to get the White House reaction to this number. Hogan Gidley is the Deputy White House Press Secretary. He's joining us right now, and of course, we also want to talk about students returning to class at Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida exactly two weeks after 17 people were killed. In Washington, the President is set to meet with a bipartisan congressional group on school safety today, trying to make progress on legislation to combat gun violence.

Joining us right now from the White House, Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley. Hogan, thanks very much for joining us this morning. Before we get into the return to school, let me get your take on what's happening in the economy right now because the GDP is just out, and it shows a growth number of 2.5 percent but that's down from 3-1/4 percent in the third- quarter what's going on, things have decelerated.

HOGAN GIDLEY, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: Well, they have, but the overall economy is strong, and as I just heard, Dagen, I think pointed out and she's absolutely right, that's before the tax cuts even took effect. We had some massive hurricanes, unprecedented amounts of damage, but also destruction that occurred in so many places across the country.

BARTIROMO: Wait a second, all of this -- all of this is before the tax plan. We're talking about the fourth-quarter. So, the tax plan went into effect the beginning of '18.

GIDLEY: But I'm saying -- right, but I'm saying expectations are that that will actually go up, it's still much higher obviously than President Barack Obama's economy which he said 1.9 percent was the new norm. We're on the way up, most economists say we're going to be hovering close to potentially four percent, as this year continues on, and that's where we expect to be. The economy is strong, businesses are coming back to this country, as you well know, consumer confidence is at all-time high, and we expect that to continue to grow even more into the new year.

BARTIROMO: Well, in terms of economic policy, what are the President's priorities at this point, Hogan? Because, I know that he wants to work on Dodd-Frank, and he's been rolling back regulations in a big way since the start of his presidency. That should add further spice to this market. What's the priority in terms of economic policy in the coming six or eight months?

GIDLEY: It will, but look, let's talk about those regulations and their rollback. The big way kind of doesn't begin to describe it. Look, he said that he would cut two regulations for every one that he put into place. He far exceeded that, and he's cutting 22 regulations for every one that gets put into place. Obviously, that spurs on consumer confidence but also security and stabilization in business growth, and that's what this President is all about, as you know. And the rapid turnaround of this economy is no coincidence.

It's because we have someone in office who understands the economy, who's going to push to make this tax cut permanent for individuals as he did with the corporate tax rate cut, but there's a pattern emerging here with this President, and that is he's taking on topics and issues that haven't been addressed in the better part of 30 to 40 years. He's coming in in a year's time, he's accomplishing record-setting things, and recording setting time, and he's growing this economy, something that the government quite frankly, has been crippling under the last eight years.

BARTIROMO: Right. So, are you expecting movement on Dodd-Frank in the coming few months?

GIDLEY: We'll see. I don't want to get ahead of what President is going to say or do, but we obviously know that that's what the President wants to be, he wants to eliminate all hindrances to economic well-being in this country. He wants to prop up middle America, as you saw with the tax cuts, it didn't just effect the corporate tax rate that people have been talking about for 30 or 40 years, but it also cut taxes for the middle-income people in this country, and that's where he's going to continuing to go.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, we're getting a report this morning that the President is looking to roll back the Volcker Rule, for example, and this is a rule, obviously where proprietary trading firms do -- cannot do proprietary trading and just trade for customers but not their own, so is that something that's going to be changed over the near-term, the Volcker Rule.

GIDLEY: Again, I can't get ahead of what the President is going to say or do. He's going to talk also about trade today. He's going to make some announcements on that as well. That should impact the economy, too, because, look, for far too long, what we've been talking about in this country, politicians as you know, for decades, go out on a campaign trail and what they say is we want free and fair trade.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GIDLEY: Well, the free trade is always there. It's the fair part that politicians seem to ignore once they get in office. And this President comes in and says, no more. This has been dogging our country for decades. It's going to stop now and it's going to stop on my watch, and so, we'll see what he announces later today.

BARTIROMO: On trade, is the U.S. going to re-enter TPP.

GIDLEY: Again, I can't get ahead of what the President is going to say or do, Maria. I appreciate you pushing me that direction but the President has some ideas to how to fix this economy. He's done a masterful job so far and we expect that to continue.

BARTIROMO: Hogan, the President obviously has been spending a lot of time on efforts to try to come up with solutions for gun safety, school safety, really. The President is hoping to jumpstart some real action on background checks or other plans. Tell me where that stands right now, and what does need to be done, in terms of background checks?

GIDLEY: Donald Trump is not just the President of the United States. He's also a father and he's also a grandfather. And what he wants is what everybody in this country wants, which is safety and security for our children when they go to school, that's just the bottom line. Legislation can't just feel good, it actually has to do good. And that's what the President is trying to get to the bottom of now when he's talking to all the relevant stakeholders. The country was privy to a meeting he had with grieving families, from the Parkland shooting, other relative stakeholders from around the Washington, D.C. area, parents, teachers, students --

BARTIROMO: Right.

GIDLEY: -- just pouring out their heart, they were angry, they were upset. They were upset --

BARTIROMO: Yes. No, that was a -- that was a good idea we did the listening session.

GIDLEY: Right. But they were also hopeful that something would get done. So, the President then went met with local law enforcement, then he met with governors, people who were on the frontlines of all these issues and how they can be impacted at the local level because, as you know, state and federal partnerships are key if we're going to actually accomplish something here. But when he meets with the Congressional leaders today from individual congressional districts, bipartisan, bicameral, they've got to come up with solutions that actually protect children. We can't just talk about it anymore. The American people deserve better.

BARTIROMO: So, is he -- is he prepared to put forth an executive order bypassing Congress to raise the age limit for getting a gun?

GIDLEY: Well, it depends on what happens after the talks, it depends on what Congress decides to do and also with the local areas decide to do as well. The President sees that there's obviously a gaping hole in security. There was a systematic failure here at every level of government, whether it was the FBI, whether it was the county sheriff, and then the deputy sitting outside the school that were trained and had a gun and still didn't go inside to protect those kids. Obviously, failures exist, the audit continues, and once we get that information, the President will make recommendations this week on what he feels should be done to protect students in our schools.

BARTIROMO: What do you make of all these companies waiting into this issue? Dick's Sporting Goods this morning says that it's no longer going to sell automatic-style weapons. It's going to require consumers to be 21 years old to purchase any firearm, regardless of the law of the land, Dick's Sporting Goods says. What do you -- what do you make of the private sector making these changes? Is that legal?

GIDLEY: Yes, I don't know if it's legal or not, I'm not an attorney, but it doesn't seem to match up with federal law. But I mean, look, we've got states all over the country, deciding to thumb their nose at the federal government and the laws on the books whether it's California and sanctuary cities, for example. But look, these businesses have made decisions based on pressure from outside groups. I guess they have the right to do that, I guess groups have the right to protest, but the bottom line is we have, you know, 6 million gun owners that are members of the NRA that are law-abiding citizens. This President supports the second amendment, supports the NRA and their efforts to keep our country safe. And we have a constitutional right in this country to keep and bear arms. And so, if a business decides that they're going to kowtow to pressure from outside groups, I guess they can do that, but then they're going to have to suffer the consequences should other side come out and put pressure on them as well.

BARTIROMO: Hogan, let me ask you about that big announcement from the President yesterday, announcing that his digital strategist, Brad Prascale will run the Trump 2020 campaign. Why did the president make this announcement now, telling everybody he is in fact running for re-election?

GIDLEY: I love you keep asking me questions I really can't talk about. That's a campaign issue.

BARTIROMO: Why not?

GIDLEY: Well, it's a campaign issue, I have to refer you over to the campaign to have that discussion. But look, the President is going to have a myriad of successes to run on in the 2020 election. As you know, the Heritage Foundation just put out a survey basically saying that this President has already accomplished 64 percent of his agenda, Ronald Reagan, the standard bearer of our party for a long time and of government success for the Republicans was only at 47 percent at this time. So, as I mentioned before, it's record-setting accomplishments and record-setting time for Donald Trump. And whoever the campaign manager is for this President, they'll have a lot to push moving into the election cycle.

BARTIROMO: All right. Hogan, great stuff, thanks so much for joining us this morning.

GIDLEY: Thanks so much, Maria. Have a great day.

BARTIROMO: Hogan Gidley joining us there. Thank you. We'll be right back. Back in a minute. Markets at the highs right now up 50 points on the GDP number. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Lowe's under pressure this morning, reporting earnings as well. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Nic, good morning to you.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. So, we are seeing Lowe's under extreme pressure this morning. We see the Dow Futures higher but Lowe's will be to the downside and likely to be one of the biggest losers here on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, down 70-1/4 percent right now, the quarterly numbers. What happened to Lowe's when Home Depot six quarters in a row beat? Well, Lowe's missed. They missed on their quarterly profit, the growth margin, all a miss. Same-store sales growth going forward to guidance. Well, that's going to slow, too. They said they've been spending a lot in order to fend off big competition, so it's clear at this time that Home Depot is really king in the home improvement retailing.

And then we take a look at Amazon. Amazon, a new acquisition, and this is Ring. $1 billion. Ring is home security. Everybody has been seeing the commercials or video doorbells, that is the idea, it adds to Blink which is what they got last year. And it takes on some of the other guys. Well, ADT is to the downside this morning. Alphabet's home unit, a home -- smart home security unit. So, if this is just Amazon expanding beyond and now that it'll also contribute to Amazon Key where they actually have a smart lock, and you go in, you have your package or your fresh food drops up. So, that's big acquisition, they're buying the start-up Ring for $1 billion, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much. Technology titans facing a boycott for ties to the National Rifles Association. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney weighing in. Stu, good morning to you.

STUART VARNEY, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. This seems to be three separate things going on here. You have the news this morning that Dick's Sporting Goods is not going to sell these assault-style rifles to anybody under 21. We got that piece of news. I think that's their business, it's their policy. Do as you will, Dick's Sporting Goods. Then there is the Boycott NRA Movement, like against Delta, United Airlines, that kind of thing. I'm worded about that because it's the politicization of business. When I buy a product or a service, I buy according to price and quality, not according to the politics of the company selling me that product or service.

But the most pernicious attack on free speech, in my opinion, comes from this attempt to silence the NRA on Amazon, Google, Roku, and Apple. Those organizations run videos of the NRA from the NRA, and there is now a serious movement to ban them from all those outlets. That is deliberately stomping on free speech. The left does not like guns, so shut up the NRA. I think that's absolutely flat-out wrong. There is no question. This is an ongoing story as businesses forced to react to the ongoing problem with guns.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I'm surprised that so many businesses have reacted this way, Dagen. I mean, I am. I --

MCDOWELL: And I want to get see people get mad that Planned Parenthood is now reportedly involved in these -- helping these Parkland, Florida students organize.

VARNEY: Yes, you know --

MCDOWELL: So how the wise Planned Parenthood involved in gun control laws? Just asking.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: I'd just like to know how we get rifles out of the hands of demented 19-year-olds. If you could do that, you solve a lot of problems.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good point.

VARNEY: But I don't have an answer.

BARTIROMO: Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes. Thank you. "VARNEY & COMPANY" top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Another milestone for LeBron. Jared Max with sports headlines now. Jared?

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: Good morning, Maria. First time in LeBron's 15-year career, he has averaged a triple-double for every game in one month. Double digits, three statistical categories. LeBron became the oldest player in NBA history to accomplish this eclectic feet when he helped the Cavalier beat the Nets last night, LeBron also the first NBA player to total more than 30,000 points, 8,000 rebounds, 8,000 assists. LeBron thinks the NBA can assist teenage athletes who have the talent to become pro-basketball players but don't feel suited or interested in playing NCAA ball but don't want to go overseas to play.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LEBRON JAMES, AMERICAN BASKETBALL PLAYER: NCAA is historic. We know it. I'm sorry. It's going to make headlines that (INAUDIBLE) sign at 14 but they get put into this farm system where they'll able to grow and be around other professionals for three or four years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: LeBron says the NCAA is corrupt. Wants to see the NBA create a farm system.

Move over Papa John's, here comes Pizza Hut. The new official sponsor of the NFL for pizza. Multi-year deal includes collected use of 32 NFL team trademarks to facilitate local exclusive team partnerships. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell says, we're thrilled to have Pizza Hut as a partner.

Let's take a look at Pizza Hut's parent Yum! Brands on the stock board. Now, Pizza Hut assumes Papa John's role as the official pizza of the NFL. Papa John's came under fire last season when the company founder John Schnatter suggested sales were down because of the NFL's mishandling of players kneeling for the anthem. The two mutually decided to part ways yesterday.

As Major League Baseball rosters fill out with younger, less expensive talent, some high-priced free agents are still looking for work. And so, the players association has filed a grievance against four baseball teams: the Marlins, the Rays, the Pirates, and the A's. All accused of failing to appropriately spend revenue sharing money to improve their clubs.

Hey, do you see the mascots that were chosen for the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo? Students from 16,769 elementary schools in Japan chose the mascots and the winner was drawn by a graduate of Cabrillo College in California, Ryo Taniguchi. One student who voted for the design said it looks futuristic but also represents Japan traditions. Some of the (INAUDIBLE) that didn't quite make the cut are these guys. Plus, it could work as Olympic mascots.

BARTIROMO: Cool. What are you expecting from Tokyo 2020?

MAX: Hopefully, a little bit more fun and less controversy than these Olympics. Where it's just strictly about the game and maybe two years from now, we get to a different point where people can make comments about each other and we keep the politics outside of sports.

BARTIROMO: Did you watch it?

CHAFFETZ: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. You did, we did.

KISSEL: I love the Olympics. Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: OK. OK.

KISSEL: Watch it every year. Oh, I love to win.

(CROSSTALK)

CHAFFETZ: The women who won the cross-country, that --

MAX: Awesome.

CHAFFETZ: That was --

MAX: The (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: But the ratings were not what past Olympics were. That's why I asked because it wasn't as much of a must watch as in past.

KISSEL: Oh, our figure skaters stink but our snowboarders are amazing.

MAX: Snowboard cross. I would watch it every night. Snowboard cross.

KISSEL: It's incredible what they do.

MAX: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Jared. Jared Max. Catch his sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7 or Sirius XM 115. We're back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Great panel today. Thank you so much Mary Kissel, Jason Chaffetz, it's great to see you.

CHAFFETZ: (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Dagen McDowell, great show. We will see you tomorrow, everybody. Here's "VARNEY & COMPANY". Stuart, over to you.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Market there taking a cue from yesterday's performance on Wall Street and that is lower. FT-100 down a third of a percent, CAC Quarante in Paris down one half of one percent, and the DAX Index in Germany down a third of a percent, forty points lower.

In Asia overnight, we're right across the board, take a look. Worst performer there, Japan. Nikkei Average down almost one and a half percent.

The battle over gun control, as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today, President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence. I'll speak with one of the students from Marjory Stone Douglas High School about his return to school later this hour.

And the debate is having a major impact on the business world as well. The latest as several states including New York, Ohio, court -- Delta Airlines following Georgia lawmaker's threat to end any tax benefits for Delta over its decision to cut ties with the NRA.

A health scare in the Virginia Military Base, the details as 11 people fall ill after opening a letter containing an unknown substance. We'll bring you the latest.

And a deal at their doorstep, Amazon putting a ring on it, acquiring the smart doorbell maker for $! Billion, what it means for your deliveries, coming up this morning.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowelll. Former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee Chairman and Fox News Contributor, Jason CHaffetz. And the "Wall Street Journal's" Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel is here. Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning Maria, thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good morning to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Kyle. We appreciate you joining us this morning. We all send love --

KASHUV: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: and support to you and all of your friends and colleagues at the school. Kyle, good luck going back today, thank you.

KASHUV: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kyle Kashuv, joining us there. Coming up, immigration crackdown despite a heads up from the mayor, ICE officials has arrested more than 150 illegal immigrants in a sweep in a California Sanctuary City. We're going to talk about that and why she gave the heads up to the criminals, and then, a major new milestone for the world's largest plane, details, coming up, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, TSA, Transportation Security Administration, testing technology, now, in New York City that detects suicide vests, Lauren Simonetti with all the details, now, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Pretty unbelievable, Maria, those tests taking place this week with Amtrak at New York's Penn Station, the move, coming after that failed pipe bomb attempt in a subway passage way back in December. That was just a couple blocks from Penn station. This vest detection technology uses special cameras that can scan for explosive devices, but the TSA says the equipment can see through clothing, no privacy concerns because the image is animated.

Well, a massive ICE sweep in Northern California, more than 150 illegal immigrants taken into custody despite warnings from the mayor of Oakland. The top ice officials said the mayor's warning lightly gave criminals a chance to escape. The agency is now asking the Department of Justice to look into whether she violated any laws with that warning.

Meanwhile, big win for President Trump and his border wall. A federal judge ruling against an environmental challenge to the wall, saying Congress and the President share responsibilities to protect the country. Border wall construction plans can now move forward.

While there is a chance that the U.S. may rejoin the Transpacific Partnership or the TPP. Treasury Secretary, Steve Mnuchin, says renegotiation is on the table and that he's been in talks with other countries about what it would take for the us to recommit. President Trump as you know, withdrew from President Obama's signature trade agreement last year but Secretary Steve Mnuchin adding rejoining is not a priority for the administration at the moment.

And a new way to launch satellite into outer space, now the Strata Launch - - the world's largest airplane which can reach a speed of 46 miles an hour on the taxiway, that's a big deal. It's has a wingspan of 385 feet. It can carry 100,000 pounds. It's designed to bring rockets to the stratosphere for a more affordable launch for a low orbit satellites. The Strata Launch could make its first test flight by next year. And of course, Maria, Microsoft Co-Founder, Paul Allen, is backing this. This is his company.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. Lauren, thank you so much. I want to talk about this testing at Penn Station. What do you thinL?

CHAFFETZ: Coincidentally I was at Penn Station, and I saw them doing this testing. I think it's good technology. Let's remember that the Pentagon spent more than $20 billion trying to figure out how to identify, improvised explosive devices. And you know what, the single best way to do it is, dogs. We can have all the technology we want, we need more dogs, because dogs can find these things, they're mobile, and they're the best deterrent that we have.

BARTIROMO: We now have smart dogs or so, yes, I agree with that.

KISSEL: Should we be more concerned about the TSA? And I was looking at some of these tests that they do, where they try to get bombmaking materials through the security at airports, and they fail the majority of the time, the overwhelming majority of the time. Is that an agency that needs more congressional oversight?

CHAFFETZ: It does and they need to look at the priority. Because you know what, dogs, they don't have lobbyists, but the people that sell these machines, by the hundreds of millions of dollars, they do have lobbyists. And often times, they're deploying technology that doesn't work. The Pentagon doesn't send this technology overseas, they don't have this technology at the White House. When you walk in to go into the oval office, you don't go through this machine, you walk by a dog. That's why they use them it's because they're the most effective things.

MCDOWELL: Very deterrent, but by the way, I know you know this but $0.60 of the TSA fee that we pay when we fly, $0.60 of the $5.60 goes to deficit reduction. There is a billion-and-a half-dollars-plus being diverted for deficit reduction rather than it being spent on actual airport security every year.

KISSEL: You wonder where all that money goes, you know, when you go through JFK or LaGuardia, you see all these people standing around, are they really looking out for our security? Is that a crack force that's going to find the next bomb?

CHAFFETZ: Security badges that airports biggest thing. There are 13,000 people with a security badge at Dulles airport in Washington D.C. One of those people slipping by at the wrong time, and you got a real problem.

MCDOWELL: And a TSA agent smacked my dog in the face by an accident, because he messing with it in August.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

MCDOWELL: Yes, so, that's what they're busy doing. Hitting fluffy, little 15-pound animals.

BARTIROMO: That was Charlie.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I'm not joking.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry to hear that. We'll take break. When we come back, the rise of the new Silicon Valley; how the Middle East is giving its California tech mecca a run for its money and market share. We're going to take a look. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Now, the latest in Silicon Valley, Apple shares hitting all- time high yesterday. Take a look, 178.50 is where the stock is now, up 30 percent this past year. Netflix is still driving the so-called fang stocks already up better than 45 percent this year. Joining us right now to talk more about tech and where the growth in the world is today is Chemi Peres, Chairman of the Peres Center for Peace and Innovation, and Managing General Partner of Pitango Venture Capital. Chemi, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

CHEMI PERES, CHAIRMAN, PERES CENTER FOR PEACE AND INNOVATION AND MANAGING GENERAL PARTNER OF PITANGO VENTURE CAPITAL: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Tell us what you're doing at Pitango and where you see growth in terms of innovation in the world today. You've been investing in a number of areas in tech.

PERES: For the best 25 years, we've been investing in Israeli technology, we're investing at growth stage, at early-stage, and incubation. And I think that the great thing that we're seeing; number one, probably, is cybersecurity, where it is a great concern around the world. Terrorism is globalized, so we are taking care of that. Secondly, there's tremendous innovation in A.I., machine learning, and deep learning to connect devices and machines to the Internet, to create new services. Thirdly, most likely is a precision medicine to help us get better and earlier.

And probably, I would say, in addition to those kinds of innovations, we're seeing also the attempt to decentralize the currency systems, to give it more freedom through blockchain technologies. And I think that what you've seen right now in terms of the share prices, you see that the greatest companies today in the world are technology companies pushing away, you know, oil, and gas, and chemicals, and construction. So, we are moving to a new world.

BARTIROMO: We sure are.

CHAFFETZ: Artificial intelligence is a big promise. There's a lot of good that can be done, there's also a lot of bad that can be done with artificial intelligence. So, where do you see that going, and how do we control it or does it need to be controlled?

PERES: So, first of all, you are very much right. Technology without moral values is very dangerous, so we have to develop more values. One of the trends that we're seeing also in the investment space, is that people are trying to achieve double bottom line, make progress on technology, but at the same time, make the world safer by using technology for the better. And I think this is a great challenge that human beings are facing in the next 10 to 20 years.

KISSEL: Chemi, should we be thinking about Israel is the second Silicon Valley? And for investors out there that are sick of the fang stocks here in the United States, you know, what are the companies that they should be looking at over there?

PERES: So, I think you shouldn't look at it as a second Silicon Valley, you should look at it as a first innovation nation. It's a nation that both created not from the land but from the mind. Everything that happen in Israel was not build upon the land. We cannot use the land for natural resources for food or water. Everything that we do, state foundation, security, economy, and peace-building is only with our brain. So, you should think of Israel as an empire of the mind, as a model for nations that would like to transition themselves from the old world where they rely on the land, to the new world which is limitless based on the brain power. That's the way you need to look at it.

KISSEL: Companies? Any companies?

PERES: Companies, probably the biggest company now emerging is Technologies Checkpoint, which is doing security, and other great company, I would say, is the company that Intel-acquired Mobile Eye, which now is turning to be a center for autonomous driving in Israel. But you know, we have 7,000 companies in Israel, and probably five percent of them are emerging as new, great ideas. And I think that in the next 10 years, we'll see tremendous number of Israeli companies really changing the world.

BARTIROMO: Your father used to talk about this a lot. The late great Shimon Peres, which talks about Israel as this hub for innovation. Why is that? Why has Israel been able to really compete with the best of the best in terms of innovation and technology growth?

PERES: So, as I said there, Maria, basically, you cannot build anything, because we have -- on the land, because our land is so small, it does not provide any shelter, no food, no water. So, we had to build everything on our brain power. So, number one is necessity, and the second thing I think is the notion that Israel wants to make the world better, to change the world for better. My father would say, most likely, that our biggest contribution for human beings is dissatisfaction; we're never satisfied with everything. So, we need to check everything with technology.

BARTIROMO: I like that. Great.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: By the way, the president announced, obviously, his future plans with the City of Jerusalem back in December of 2017 to move the embassy to Jerusalem. You're happy with this decision, obviously?

PERES: Obviously, I'm very happy. Not everything that is done for Israel is necessarily bad for other people. That should've been done in 1947 when Israel was established as a nation. Celebrating our 70th anniversary. I think it's a great present to fix what was wrong. It should have been, from day one, our capital.

BARTIROMO: Chemi, it's good to see you.

PERES: Good to see you, too. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Chemi Peres. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, February 28th.

END
