urn:contentItem:5RSD-8B81-JBHT-D44Y-00000-00Gun Control Debate; Military Base Scare; Stocks Down After Powell Comments Raise Expectations for 4th Rate Hike; Parkland Shooting Survivor2018-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:09ZLexisNexisGun Control Debate; Military Base Scare; Stocks Down After Powell Comments Raise Expectations for 4th Rate Hike; Parkland Shooting SurvivorLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Market there taking a cue from yesterday's performance on Wall Street and that is lower. FT-100 down a third of a percent, CAC Quarante in Paris down one half of one percent, and the DAX Index in Germany down a third of a percent, forty points lower.

In Asia overnight, we're right across the board, take a look. Worst performer there, Japan. Nikkei Average down almost one and a half percent.

The battle over gun control, as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today, President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence. I'll speak with one of the students from Marjory Stone Douglas High School about his return to school later this hour.

And the debate is having a major impact on the business world as well. The latest as several states including New York, Ohio, court -- Delta Airlines following Georgia lawmaker's threat to end any tax benefits for Delta over its decision to cut ties with the NRA.

A health scare in the Virginia Military Base, the details as 11 people fall ill after opening a letter containing an unknown substance. We'll bring you the latest.

And a deal at their doorstep, Amazon putting a ring on it, acquiring the smart doorbell maker for $! Billion, what it means for your deliveries, coming up this morning.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowelll. Former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee Chairman and Fox News Contributor, Jason CHaffetz. And the "Wall Street Journal's" Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel is here. Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning Maria, thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good morning to you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: When I saw the guests was yesterday, "I can't wait to hear what Mary and Jason have to say. So that means I'm going to stifle.

BARTIROMO: No, we don't want that. We don't want -- but it's true, we're grateful that you're both here this morning. What's on your mind? What's most important in your mind right now?

CHAFFETZ: I'm still reeling over what the republicans have done to run up government spending. I see a lot of good economic news, the GDP but the government component in the run up and spending, I think it's going to hamper the economy, I really do.

BARTIROMO: $300 billion in spending.

CHAFFETZ: It's a ridiculous number, you can't justify it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, we'll talk more about that. Mary, how about you?

KISSEL: Yes. Well I think they're on a shirt high because as you said, you've got the four quarter GDP number coming out and say goodbye to the new normal of two percent that turns out that America can grow much faster than that.

But I think unfortunately republicans are taking that message to as you say give back on the sugar high of government spending, not a good idea.

BARTIROMO: No. We've been talking about that a lot for sure because now we're talking about $1 trillion deficits from here on out.

KISSEL: Yes we are.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KISSEL: And we'll talk about it as the morning rolls on too.

MCDOWELL: Again, watching those yields, those yields going up to close and above 2.9 percent yesterday on that testimony from Jay Powell.

BARTIROMO: Tough day. We expected what he said though, so I don't know why the markets were surprised. We knew he was going to talk about higher interest rates and the return of inflation.

MCDOWELL: Maybe sometimes investors need a hammer over the head so to speak and that was it.

BARTIROMO: We'll see about that. Three hundred points lower yesterday, this morning a bit of a bounce.

Joining the conversation this morning, the CEO of Bayer is with me, Werner Baumann is here talking about lots of news this morning in the drug industry. White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley is with us. Former RNC Chair and Founding Partner of the DGR Group, Haley Barbour joins us. Kentucky Congressman Andy Barr is here. And Dr. Mikhail Varshavski AKA Dr. Mike also joining us this morning.

You don't want to miss moments of it so do stay with us. And we kick it off here with the top story, markets taking a hit yesterday after a new Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell delivered an upbeat assessments of the U.S. economy on Capitol Hill leading investors to expect higher interest rates. Of course, the biggest economic news on the DACA today is the second estimate of fourth quarter GDP.

It's expected to come in at two and a half percent, that would be down 0.1 of a percent from the initial expectation. Your reaction to what we heard from Jay Powell yesterday Mary in terms of what he said, what that means from where we are today.

KISSLER: Well the Federal Reserve always underestimates GDP growth in the economy and they always under estimate the impact of tax cuts Maria. They're also always behind the curve when it comes to inflation expectations.

Jay Powell was not picked because he was an aggressive Fed chairman, Jay Powell was picked because he was somebody that the White House liked and thought wouldn't rock the boat. So I think what you're going to see out of him is, again, a very reasonable and predictable rate rise. Whether or not that leads them behind the curve, who knows, the bigger challenge and Dagen and I were talking about this off air is what they're going to do with this mega balance sheet that the Federal Reserve has accumulated?

We've never seen that in the history of the Federal Reserve before, it's a big experiment and the question is, can the Federal Reserve get rid of that balance sheet without turning the market upside down.

BARTIROMO: The idea of unwinding $4.5 trillion Dagen. We've talked about it before, $50 billion a month, at some point we'll get there.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Coupled with the idea that we may see now four interest rate hikes spook in markets.

MCDOWELL: Right. The market yesterday began fact -- this has been discussed widely about four interest rate hikes this year but Futures contracts linked to the Central Bank's rate policies yesterday showed one third of a probability that it's going to move four times this year.

But it's the great unknown of the Fed -- I think the balance sheet will shrink about $400 billion this year, $420 billion with the final quarter at $50 billion will be rolling off in mortgage and Treasury securities. But this has put even more pressure on markets and on the Federal Reserve because of what the republicans have done.

I don't disagree with the tax reform, I don't believe that it's going to cost north of a $1 trillion. I think because of the faster growth, because of the higher tax receipts you've already seen in January. However, republicans make this pressure on the Fed worst and on the bond market because they increased spending by $300 billion over to your period. You're ramping up the supply of Treasury debt at a time when one major source of the demand over the last 10 years is going away and that's problematic.

BARTIROMO: Yes. When Paul Ryan joined me two weeks ago Jason, one thing he kept saying is, "You've got to give to get." Well you were in that seat before, what would you have done had you been faced with a situation of, "OK, we need to spend this money on the military. We need new money on -- for military and recover what's been happened from sequestration but, I'm being held hostage by doing all this other stuff spending elsewhere."

CHAFFETZ: Well look, if you look at what Chuck Schumer got, he got everything that he wanted. What did the republicans get in that deal? They didn't get anything. There was a 13 percent increase in domestic spending and Rand Paul was absolutely right when he said, "When we had $1 dollar deficits and it was Obama in the White House, we were all up and arms." And suddenly, now it's President Trump and we're OK with it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: They didn't do anything to curve that and for Paul Ryan to say, "Well now we're going to turn our attention to entitlement reform." Come on, there's no way you're getting this 60 votes on entitlement reform.

BARTIROMO: Not this year.

CHAFFETZ: No. There's no way to do it.

BARTIROMO: But some of the things that they put money to, Dagen, you mentioned it, what, the abstinence spending.

MCDOWELL: $150 billion -- excuse me, million dollars for abstinence education (INAUDIBLE) with social conservatives but it was billions of dollars a year for child care, for health --

BARTIROMO: Community centers.

MCDOWELL: For community health centers. And I'll point to this because this is in the news today, I think it was $6 billion to fight the opioid crisis --

KISSEL: Yes, that's it.

MCDOWELL: -- when they had poultry little evidence of how that money has been spend, it's already been allocated and how this be spent. Like the -- you need proof of outcomes when you start throwing billions of dollars at a problem.

KISSEL: Yes. But, again, I wonder about the political environment here because President Trump wants to do a deal and I feel like Paul Ryan's biggest worry is that democrats are going to go to the president and say, "Just spend a little more. You'll be more popular. We can do a deal together."

And so Paul Ryan just took over what's in front of him because he didn't want something that was even worst.

CHAFFETZ: But I -- when did it become the new normal and totally acceptable that for every dollar rise in defense spending, you have to raise domestic spending. There was no justification to raise the domestic spending, you could make a case on the military but, again, I don't think we went out and said, "Hey, we need a new carrier group, we have to have missile defense." We never had that discussion in this country. That bill came about three and a half days.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well let's worry now and like I said to Paul Ryan, now it's in your face in terms of markets reacting to higher interest rates, what that means for the debt.

CHAFFETZ: And they still have to fund the government on March 23rd. So remember, they funded part of the military but they still have to go back and actually pass a funding pill later in March.

MCDOWELL: And to -- we'll talk about the "Wall Street Journal" Editorial page, Mary Kissel, because, again, it's -- the fact republicans won't fix the entitlements that we have where one in five Americans is on Medicaid, Medicare, and Social Security.

But now you have the likes of Senators Mike Lee and Marco Rubio talking about this new entitlement joining arms with Ivanka Trump on paid family leave federally mandated. So, again, to call yourself a conservative is a joke.

KISSEL: Yes. And rating the entitlements by the way propose (INAUDIBLE) entitlements to pay for that.

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE)

KISSEL: There's a free lunch entitlement according to those two senators which was just ridiculous. Look Dagen, I think it's very disheartening, republicans had a chance to have a major entitlement reform last week with healthcare but they simply couldn't explain what the program was.

They had gone out and actually, I don't know, had three bullet points and said, "Hey America, do you want to make entitlements to give into the people who actually need them instead of able bodied adults? I think Americans would have gotten behind that.

BARTIROMO: Because most people recognize this is where the growth and spending and that these programs are going out of business. They are -- they're going broke.

KISSLER: Yes, they are -- it's entitlements.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to take a break. When we comeback, students are returning to school in Florida. This morning, we're going to speak with one of the students, a survivor.

Then scary moments out of Virginia Military Base after the contents of mysterious envelops causes several people to get sick, we got the details on that investigation.

Then a first on Fox Business interview, I'm one-on-one with Bayer CEO Werner Baumann. We will talk about the company's $8 billion for U.S. investment. Back in a moments right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Another police officer shot in the line of duty, this time in Idaho. Lauren Simonetti with the details and headlines now, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN REPORTER: Good morning Maria. The suspected gunman was shot and killed in the shootout. Police say the shooter had a felony warrant for his arrest, began firing at officers when they approached him.

All this happened near the Idaho, Washington state line, east of Spokane. The officer hit with the bullet went into surgery, the police chief says he was up and talking with other officers.

Well, 11 people including several marines sickened yesterday after a suspicious letter was opened at Marine Corps headquarters near the Pentagon. Three people were taken to the hospital listed in stable condition. The envelope which contained an unknown substance was mailed to joint base Myer Henderson in Virginia. It's been sent to the FBI's lab and Quantico for testing. The building was evacuated, it is not clear at this point who sent that letter.

Well, evidence now emerging that North Korea is profiting from the civil war in Syria. "Confidential United Nations" report says that North Korea shipped 50 tons of supplies to Syria for using building, what it suspected to be a chemical weapons factory. The U.S. has accused Syria of using chemical weapons in rebel controlled areas including recently in a suburb of Damascus.

Meanwhile, take a look at these new satellite photos. They show Iran establishing another base in Syria. Intelligence sources telling Fox News that the base outside of Syria's capital is complete with hangers used to store missiles capable of hitting Israel.

And in business, Amazon is buying a ring in a deal reportedly valued at over $1 billion. Amazon is expanding its home security business. Ring makes Wi-Fi connected cameras and doorbells. This coming after Amazon launched its own security carmeras which worked with its -- boy, this isn't Alexa. Ring devices capture a video that can be screened on smart phones. And I guess you can tell if someone's going to steal your packages when they're at your doorstep.

Look at Amazon shares, they're moving up half a percent, 15.19 in the premarket, this is the stock that's up in the past year almost 80 percent, Maria.

urn:contentItem:5RS4-Y6V1-DXH2-61FY-00000-00Gun Control Debate; Military Base Scare; Stocks Down After Powell Comments Raise Expectations for 4th Rate Hike; Parkland Shooting Survivor Speaks Out in Support of Second Amendment2018-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:09ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTWerner Baumann, Kyle Kashuv, Chemi PeresNEWSFinancial022801cb.231Gun Control Debate; Military Base Scare; Stocks Down After Powell Comments Raise Expectations for 4th Rate Hike; Parkland Shooting Survivor Speaks Out in Support of Second AmendmentMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Jason Chaffetz, Mary Kissel, Lauren Simonetti

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Market there taking a cue from yesterday's performance on Wall Street and that is lower. FT-100 down a third of a percent, CAC Quarante in Paris down one half of one percent, and the DAX Index in Germany down a third of a percent, forty points lower.

In Asia overnight, we're right across the board, take a look. Worst performer there, Japan. Nikkei Average down almost one and a half percent.

The battle over gun control, as the students in Parkland, Florida return to school today, President Trump is set to host a bipartisan meeting with lawmakers as they work to end gun violence. I'll speak with one of the students from Marjory Stone Douglas High School about his return to school later this hour.

And the debate is having a major impact on the business world as well. The latest as several states including New York, Ohio, court -- Delta Airlines following Georgia lawmaker's threat to end any tax benefits for Delta over its decision to cut ties with the NRA.

A health scare in the Virginia Military Base, the details as 11 people fall ill after opening a letter containing an unknown substance. We'll bring you the latest.

And a deal at their doorstep, Amazon putting a ring on it, acquiring the smart doorbell maker for $! Billion, what it means for your deliveries, coming up this morning.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowelll. Former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee Chairman and Fox News Contributor, Jason CHaffetz. And the "Wall Street Journal's" Editorial Board Member, Fox News Contributor, Mary Kissel is here. Great to see you.

MARY KISSEL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning Maria, thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, good morning to you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: When I saw the guests was yesterday, "I can't wait to hear what Mary and Jason have to say. So that means I'm going to stifle.

BARTIROMO: No, we don't want that. We don't want -- but it's true, we're grateful that you're both here this morning. What's on your mind? What's most important in your mind right now?

CHAFFETZ: I'm still reeling over what the republicans have done to run up government spending. I see a lot of good economic news, the GDP but the government component in the run up and spending, I think it's going to hamper the economy, I really do.

BARTIROMO: $300 billion in spending.

CHAFFETZ: It's a ridiculous number, you can't justify it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, we'll talk more about that. Mary, how about you?

KISSEL: Yes. Well I think they're on a shirt high because as you said, you've got the four quarter GDP number coming out and say goodbye to the new normal of two percent that turns out that America can grow much faster than that.

But I think unfortunately republicans are taking that message to as you say give back on the sugar high of government spending, not a good idea.

BARTIROMO: No. We've been talking about that a lot for sure because now we're talking about $1 trillion deficits from here on out.

KISSEL: Yes we are.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KISSEL: And we'll talk about it as the morning rolls on too.

MCDOWELL: Again, watching those yields, those yields going up to close and above 2.9 percent yesterday on that testimony from Jay Powell.

BARTIROMO: Tough day. We expected what he said though, so I don't know why the markets were surprised. We knew he was going to talk about higher interest rates and the return of inflation.

MCDOWELL: Maybe sometimes investors need a hammer over the head so to speak and that was it.

BARTIROMO: We'll see about that. Three hundred points lower yesterday, this morning a bit of a bounce.

Joining the conversation this morning, the CEO of Bayer is with me, Werner Baumann is here talking about lots of news this morning in the drug industry. White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley is with us. Former RNC Chair and Founding Partner of the DGR Group, Haley Barbour joins us. Kentucky Congressman Andy Barr is here. And Dr. Mikhail Varshavski AKA Dr. Mike also joining us this morning.

You don't want to miss moments of it so do stay with us. And we kick it off here with the top story, markets taking a hit yesterday after a new Federal Reserve chairman Jay Powell delivered an upbeat assessments of the U.S. economy on Capitol Hill leading investors to expect higher interest rates. Of course, the biggest economic news on the DACA today is the second estimate of fourth quarter GDP.

It's expected to come in at two and a half percent, that would be down 0.1 of a percent from the initial expectation. Your reaction to what we heard from Jay Powell yesterday Mary in terms of what he said, what that means from where we are today.

KISSLER: Well the Federal Reserve always underestimates GDP growth in the economy and they always under estimate the impact of tax cuts Maria. They're also always behind the curve when it comes to inflation expectations.

Jay Powell was not picked because he was an aggressive Fed chairman, Jay Powell was picked because he was somebody that the White House liked and thought wouldn't rock the boat. So I think what you're going to see out of him is, again, a very reasonable and predictable rate rise. Whether or not that leads them behind the curve, who knows, the bigger challenge and Dagen and I were talking about this off air is what they're going to do with this mega balance sheet that the Federal Reserve has accumulated?

We've never seen that in the history of the Federal Reserve before, it's a big experiment and the question is, can the Federal Reserve get rid of that balance sheet without turning the market upside down.

BARTIROMO: The idea of unwinding $4.5 trillion Dagen. We've talked about it before, $50 billion a month, at some point we'll get there.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Coupled with the idea that we may see now four interest rate hikes spook in markets.

MCDOWELL: Right. The market yesterday began fact -- this has been discussed widely about four interest rate hikes this year but Futures contracts linked to the Central Bank's rate policies yesterday showed one third of a probability that it's going to move four times this year.

But it's the great unknown of the Fed -- I think the balance sheet will shrink about $400 billion this year, $420 billion with the final quarter at $50 billion will be rolling off in mortgage and Treasury securities. But this has put even more pressure on markets and on the Federal Reserve because of what the republicans have done.

I don't disagree with the tax reform, I don't believe that it's going to cost north of a $1 trillion. I think because of the faster growth, because of the higher tax receipts you've already seen in January. However, republicans make this pressure on the Fed worst and on the bond market because they increased spending by $300 billion over to your period. You're ramping up the supply of Treasury debt at a time when one major source of the demand over the last 10 years is going away and that's problematic.

BARTIROMO: Yes. When Paul Ryan joined me two weeks ago Jason, one thing he kept saying is, "You've got to give to get." Well you were in that seat before, what would you have done had you been faced with a situation of, "OK, we need to spend this money on the military. We need new money on -- for military and recover what's been happened from sequestration but, I'm being held hostage by doing all this other stuff spending elsewhere."

CHAFFETZ: Well look, if you look at what Chuck Schumer got, he got everything that he wanted. What did the republicans get in that deal? They didn't get anything. There was a 13 percent increase in domestic spending and Rand Paul was absolutely right when he said, "When we had $1 dollar deficits and it was Obama in the White House, we were all up and arms." And suddenly, now it's President Trump and we're OK with it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: They didn't do anything to curve that and for Paul Ryan to say, "Well now we're going to turn our attention to entitlement reform." Come on, there's no way you're getting this 60 votes on entitlement reform.

BARTIROMO: Not this year.

CHAFFETZ: No. There's no way to do it.

BARTIROMO: But some of the things that they put money to, Dagen, you mentioned it, what, the abstinence spending.

MCDOWELL: $150 billion -- excuse me, million dollars for abstinence education (INAUDIBLE) with social conservatives but it was billions of dollars a year for child care, for health --

BARTIROMO: Community centers.

MCDOWELL: For community health centers. And I'll point to this because this is in the news today, I think it was $6 billion to fight the opioid crisis --

KISSEL: Yes, that's it.

MCDOWELL: -- when they had poultry little evidence of how that money has been spend, it's already been allocated and how this be spent. Like the -- you need proof of outcomes when you start throwing billions of dollars at a problem.

KISSEL: Yes. But, again, I wonder about the political environment here because President Trump wants to do a deal and I feel like Paul Ryan's biggest worry is that democrats are going to go to the president and say, "Just spend a little more. You'll be more popular. We can do a deal together."

And so Paul Ryan just took over what's in front of him because he didn't want something that was even worst.

CHAFFETZ: But I -- when did it become the new normal and totally acceptable that for every dollar rise in defense spending, you have to raise domestic spending. There was no justification to raise the domestic spending, you could make a case on the military but, again, I don't think we went out and said, "Hey, we need a new carrier group, we have to have missile defense." We never had that discussion in this country. That bill came about three and a half days.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well let's worry now and like I said to Paul Ryan, now it's in your face in terms of markets reacting to higher interest rates, what that means for the debt.

CHAFFETZ: And they still have to fund the government on March 23rd. So remember, they funded part of the military but they still have to go back and actually pass a funding pill later in March.

MCDOWELL: And to -- we'll talk about the "Wall Street Journal" Editorial page, Mary Kissel, because, again, it's -- the fact republicans won't fix the entitlements that we have where one in five Americans is on Medicaid, Medicare, and Social Security.

But now you have the likes of Senators Mike Lee and Marco Rubio talking about this new entitlement joining arms with Ivanka Trump on paid family leave federally mandated. So, again, to call yourself a conservative is a joke.

KISSEL: Yes. And rating the entitlements by the way propose (INAUDIBLE) entitlements to pay for that.

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE)

KISSEL: There's a free lunch entitlement according to those two senators which was just ridiculous. Look Dagen, I think it's very disheartening, republicans had a chance to have a major entitlement reform last week with healthcare but they simply couldn't explain what the program was.

They had gone out and actually, I don't know, had three bullet points and said, "Hey America, do you want to make entitlements to give into the people who actually need them instead of able bodied adults? I think Americans would have gotten behind that.

BARTIROMO: Because most people recognize this is where the growth and spending and that these programs are going out of business. They are -- they're going broke.

KISSLER: Yes, they are -- it's entitlements.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to take a break. When we comeback, students are returning to school in Florida. This morning, we're going to speak with one of the students, a survivor.

Then scary moments out of Virginia Military Base after the contents of mysterious envelops causes several people to get sick, we got the details on that investigation.

Then a first on Fox Business interview, I'm one-on-one with Bayer CEO Werner Baumann. We will talk about the company's $8 billion for U.S. investment. Back in a moments right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Another police officer shot in the line of duty, this time in Idaho. Lauren Simonetti with the details and headlines now, Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN REPORTER: Good morning Maria. The suspected gunman was shot and killed in the shootout. Police say the shooter had a felony warrant for his arrest, began firing at officers when they approached him.

All this happened near the Idaho, Washington state line, east of Spokane. The officer hit with the bullet went into surgery, the police chief says he was up and talking with other officers.

Well, 11 people including several marines sickened yesterday after a suspicious letter was opened at Marine Corps headquarters near the Pentagon. Three people were taken to the hospital listed in stable condition. The envelope which contained an unknown substance was mailed to joint base Myer Henderson in Virginia. It's been sent to the FBI's lab and Quantico for testing. The building was evacuated, it is not clear at this point who sent that letter.

Well, evidence now emerging that North Korea is profiting from the civil war in Syria. "Confidential United Nations" report says that North Korea shipped 50 tons of supplies to Syria for using building, what it suspected to be a chemical weapons factory. The U.S. has accused Syria of using chemical weapons in rebel controlled areas including recently in a suburb of Damascus.

Meanwhile, take a look at these new satellite photos. They show Iran establishing another base in Syria. Intelligence sources telling Fox News that the base outside of Syria's capital is complete with hangers used to store missiles capable of hitting Israel.

And in business, Amazon is buying a ring in a deal reportedly valued at over $1 billion. Amazon is expanding its home security business. Ring makes Wi-Fi connected cameras and doorbells. This coming after Amazon launched its own security carmeras which worked with its -- boy, this isn't Alexa. Ring devices capture a video that can be screened on smart phones. And I guess you can tell if someone's going to steal your packages when they're at your doorstep.

Look at Amazon shares, they're moving up half a percent, 15.19 in the premarket, this is the stock that's up in the past year almost 80 percent, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good line that you can watch if anyone is trying to steal your packages. It's true, you're right.

SIMONETTI: Get off my door step.

BARTIROMO: It's an interesting acquisition. I like this company. I've always liked the idea that you can just go on your phone and see who's at your doorbell. What do you think Dagen?

MCDOWELL: I think that they've done a great job of advertising where the millennials are. You will hear these ring advertisements on Podcasts galore.

BARTIROMO: Really?

MCDOWELL: And I'm a voracious consumer of Podcast. So they've done an incredible job and they've been able to grow their business despite some naysayers.

BARTIROMO: Amazon keeps on expanding.

CHAFFETZ: I use the vivid system (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: You do? OK.

CHAFFETZ: And I can watch right now, I can see what's going on and it automatically takes clips. Somebody who rings my doorbell, they walk up and it buzzes me on my phone, so I know anytime.

BARTIROMO: I like that.

CHAFFETZ: And my kids realized when you have a system like this, it's not as much about keeping people from the outside getting in, as it is also to keeping them inside from getting out. And we have a teenager, that's a good system.

BARTIROMO: That is great.

MCDOWELL: I don't -- I don't think I want to know what's going on in Brooklyn in the middle of the night, actually. So, I do not have one of these systems.

BARTIROMO: Well, it looks good. I think it's the whole technology around safety and security and being able to look at all your doors that on your phone is pretty interesting. And it's interesting that Amazon is acquiring it.

All right, we are going to take a break. When we come back, students at Stoneman Douglas high school returning to class today. Exactly, two weeks after 17 people were killed. I will talk to one of the students on his thoughts about going back and the expectations for school safety now.

The investors are expecting growth of 2.5 percent when we get the second quarter -- the second reading for the fourth quarter GDP later this morning. We will see how the markets react. Futures right now, indicating a gain at the start of trading. These are the high of the morning right here, up 50 points on the Dow Jones Industrial average. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, fourth-quarter earnings from Bayer just out this morning. The German drug maker and agriculture giant misexpectations on revenue due in part to a head from U.S. tax reform. The stock sell to a 15 month low on the news. And joining us right now, for the first time on FOX NEWS's interview is the CEO of Bayer, Werner Baumann. Werner, it's good to have you on the program this morning. Thank you so much.

WERNER BAUMANN, CEO, BAYER: Hi, Maria. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Let me kick it off with the quarter. Can you tell us what growth -- the growth in the quarter, what would you say was the standout this last three months?

BAUMANN: Well, we've seen -- as we've seen in the entire year. A very good performance in pharma, so sales in pharma advanced again by roughly four percent. If you look at our key growth product, so blood thinner, Xarelto, Eylea, then some of our cancer products, all of them have done well both in quarter four but for also the entire year. So, our pharma business had another record here. Quite frankly, the other businesses, things did not go down well in 2017.

So consumer is a difficult business in particular in the U.S. and then in crop we had significant oversupply in the market in Brazil that our crop protection products as our competitors as well. We had to cleanse the situation in quarter two and have since made very good progress I have to say in getting the situation under control and actually advancing again. So we are quite optimistic for our crop business going into 2018.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I want to talk about the consumer business. You say that it was -- it was a little under pressure in the U.S. That's interesting to know, given that the economics in the U.S. have been improving. But let me start with you $66 billion deal to acquire Monsanto. We are waiting on approvals from European regulators and the U.S. The company's hoping this deal will close this year. But I guess, are you expecting the approval in the second quarter? From the E.U.?

BAUMANN: Yes, Maria. Based on where we are right now, we've seen very, very good progress. This by now, roughly half of the 30 approvals we need. They are in very good discussions after say that the European Commission making good progress there and also that the DOJ. Even though with the DOJ, we are a little bit behind the process where we are with the European Commission. But overall, as you have mentioned, that we are quite confident, that we are going to close this on section in the second quarter. And that we will also obtain the approvals necessary to do so.

BARTIROMO: Well, as we wait for the E.U. approval sometime in the second quarter, what are the plans in terms of divestitures, in terms of raising money once you get that approval? Are you expecting to do a secondary offering of right to issue once you get that approval?

BAUMANN: Yes, Maria. First of all, looking at the divestitures we have already announced actually in October -- mid-October last year, that a very large part of our buyers, seat business and our non-selective herbicides platform. Delivered to link product lines are going to be divested to BISF. Of course, always contingent on the over transaction coming to a closing. And we continue to be in discussion so that, with some select further areas that are in the interest of the regulators also to strengthen overall competition, also innovation competition in our industry. That discussion is over all regardless whether you look at the Europeans or the Department of Justice. Very constructive, we have recently announced also today in our call that we are now also going to divest of our vegetable seeds business. I cannot at this point in time say that this is what's it going to be because these discussions are still on going.

On the same question regarding the financing, this is going to be a mix of equity and debt. So that we have already mentioned that based on the very good sales proceeds on the divestiture of our (INAUDIBLE) at stake, the -- these need less equity than we had expected, but there's still will be a rise offering here.

BARTIROMO: I see, I see. Now you and several other European business leaders took part in a round table discussion with President Trump in Davos last month. I know the President said that he is a fan of the company, but let me ask you this, in terms of your expectations in terms of investments in the United States, tell us what that looks like and what do you think is behind this weakness that you just mentioned in terms of the consumer in the U.S?

BAUMANN: Well, first of all, we have been in the U.S. for more than 150 years and we have great interest in also advancing on business but the overall economy in the U.S. and we will do our fair share in contributing. Regarding with my encounters with President Trump, I have to say that both party were very well-informed and well briefed. Got a good discussion along the lines of what we have already communicated on hat this combination is going to be about and of course he's a very loyal customer of the aspirin, which is always nice to see.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. And -- but did you say that the consumer business is weak in the U.S. right now?

BAUMANN: Yes, the consumer business overall is actually impact that the cross actually also our competitors business by fairly dramatic and record change in consumer behaviors. The stronger advance of online buying with that less (INAUDIBLE) if you look at the you know, stationary retail, DR, abducting to live. We need to do this faster. We also need to step up our innovation capabilities and that is what we are working on. But clearly 2017 was not a good year for our consumer business.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Werner, and it's good to have you on the program. Great to see you, thanks so much for joining us this morning.

BAUMANN: Thank you, thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Werner Baumann there, CEO at Bayer. Coming up, TSA bomb detection goes from airports to underground. The agency testing new equipment for train stations that could detect a potential suicide bomber. This coming after a failed attack in a New York subway last year.

And then Apple and Amazon they are the undisputed leaders in the tech industry in the market. But who's up next? You might be surprised by what and where the next big tech titan comes from. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, February 28th, your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Stocks looking to rebound this morning, take a look at Futures, indicating a gain at the start of trading of about 40 points, NASDAQ, S&P 500, also positive. We are waiting on the second reading of the fourth quarter GDP.

Economists are looking for growth of 2 1/2 percent in the GDP, for the final month of 2017, this, after markets were rattled yesterday, following testimony from Federal Reserve Chairman, Jake Powell. His comments suggesting that the Central Bank may raise interest rates more than the three times that are expected. As a result, markets plummeted. Dow Industrials, yesterday, down 300 points better than one percent, NASDAQ, S&P 500 also down one and a quarter percent.

Global markets are taking a cue from the U.S. this morning and trading lower, FT 100, down a quarter of a percent, CAC Quarante in Paris, down a third of a percent, DAX Index in Germany down one quarter of a percent. Similar story in Asia overnight, declines across the board, worst performer was Hong Kong, down 1 1/2 percent on the Hang Seng.

A new layer of security to report, the TSA is now testing new technology to detect suicide vests, how it works, coming up. President Trump, one step closer to fulfilling another campaign promise.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Do not worry. We are going to build the wall, OK? Don't worry. Don't even think about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: A judge ruling in favor of the administration, allowing construction plans to begin for the border wall. And the White House changing its tune on trade, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, now suggesting President Trump may negotiate a return to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, the details, coming up. Then, the world's largest plane, one step closer to its first passenger flight, more on the latest milestone for the jet that's backed by Paul Allen, all that coming up.

But first, this top story this half an hour, students will return to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School this morning, two weeks, after the shooting, 17 students and teachers were killed on that Valentine's Day massacre. Joining me right now is a survivor of the shooting, Junior Kyle Kashuv, Kyle, thank you so much for being with us this morning.

KYLE KASHUV, JUNIOR, MARJORY STONEMAN DOUGLAS HIGH SCHOOL: Thank you for having me, Maria.

BARTIROMO: First, we all want to say our condolences. Our hearts go out to you and your families and all of your friends and colleagues there at High School. How do you feel about going back to school today?

KASHUV: I mean, it's really sad coming back to school, but then, it's also really exciting to meet my peers and to be able to connect once again at school. I am optimistic that -- I'm optimistic going back to school.

BARTIROMO: You're optimistic about going back to school? Have you spoken to your friends about it? I mean, do you think it's the right time now? It's two weeks.

KASHUV: I think it's the right time. I mean, everyone is still saddened by what happened but, we understand that. We still have to return to school and there's no other time better than now, to do so.

BARTIROMO: Of course, of course. Now, the calls for Sheriff Scott Israel's resignation are growing louder. What's your take on this? The Broward County Sheriff has said, he will not step down. Listen to what he said. I want to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCOTT ISRAEL, SHERIFF, BROWARD COUNTY: I can only take responsibility for what I knew about. I exercise my due diligence. I've given amazing leadership to this age --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Amazing leadership?

ISRALE: I've worked -- yes. And, of course, I won't resign.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Kyle?

KASHUV: I this it's a completely -- I think it's completely, like, understandable that we realize that how (INAUDIBLE) it is that the Broward Sheriff's Department failed on so many different levels and they didn't act properly. And I think that it is a representation of his leadership. He has to be held accountable for the inaction of the Broward Sheriff's Department.

BARTIROMO: Jason Chaffetz.

CHAFFETZ: Kyle, hi, this is Jason Chaffetz. God bless you. I can't imagine what it's like for you and your, you know, fellow students to go back to school, but, you know, there are --

KASHUV: Thank you.

CHAFFETZ: In different schools, they have people that you, kind of, really worried about and concerned about. Do you think that video games and stuff that you see in the media and the movies, do you think that affects some of your classmates there?

KASHUV: No, I really don't think that video games have a, somewhat, even slightly an effect on children and the way they act, they really don't, because we can clearly tell reality from video games, there's a clear divide.

KISSEL: Kyle, it's Mary Kissel here. I just want to echo what Maria and Jason said that our thoughts and prayers are with you and the other students. A lot of the talk has been about things like gun control and school safety, that yet, it's clear that there were breakdowns on many levels, particularly in the mental health system, very, very difficult for someone like the shooter, to get the help that he needs. I think he even called and asked for help at one point. Has that been part of the discussion between you and your classmates? Is that gaining any traction down there?

KASHUV: It is. I figured we definitely understand that we have a lacking in the department for emotional support at our schools. And right now, we clearly see a lot of movement and legislation that trying to enact that. I'm -- right now, I'm working on an app developing, to allow moms to, maybe, volunteer at schools for emotional support and since we're so understaffed.

MCDOWELL: Kyle, it's Dagen McDowell, has this school stepped up and said that they're going to provide counselling to you and your fellow students if you want it, having been traumatized, obviously, going through such a traumatic event that most of us can't even -- can't even comprehend?

KASHUV: Really, the entire community has stepped up, and there were support counselling at the Portland YMCA, and it was really helpful to a lot of my friends.

BARTIROMO: And Kyle, you've called yourself a conservative, right? And as a supporter --

KASHUV: Yes, Ma'am.

BARTIROMO: of the second amendment? Has this impact --

KASHUV: Yes, Ma'am.

BARTIROMO: Has this incident impacted your views?

KASHUV: It's only slightly. I still believe in the second amendment and its importance to our nation. I really -- it's dissatisfying to see the Never Again Movement, slightly switched from simply making sure that this will never happen again to gun control, but at the end of the day, I still think that the entire community and the Never Again Movement, is still heavily pushing to make sure that school shootings will be a thing in the past. And I really -- I'm really happy to see the entire community come together as a bipartisan issue to work for a better change.

BARTIROMO: Yes, especially since there were so many signs and signals that were there and were missed. Do -- had you ever seen or heard about Nikolas Cruz? And obviously, he was told don't come back (INAUDIBLE)

KASHUV: Up until this incident --

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry?

KASHUV: Up until, like, the school shooting, I had never known of his existence but my friends did. I had some friends that were in class with him, and they always told -- they told me now, that they always knew something was off about him.

BARTIROMO: What did they say about him? What did -- what did people know about him?

KASHUV: They said that he was -- he was an outcast. He wasn't really understood. They considered him somewhat of a weirdo, if I could quote. He didn't have a lot of friends, but no one ever thought that he would do such a thing.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, the Governor, Rick Scott, has some proposals on the table for the state, including arming teachers, administrators. Listen to this. I want to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOV. RICK SCOTT (R), FLORIDA: My plan is to spend $500 million to make our school safe, to invest dollars in mental illness to make sure this never happens again. We need to increase the collaboration between our local sheriffs, our police departments, our schools, Department of Children and Families and DJJ. We have got to make sure we have an increased law enforcement presence in all of our schools.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So Kyle, what do you think about those ideas? I mean, a minute ago, you said you would like to see mothers volunteer. Would you want to see teachers armed?

KASHUV: I think, that simply proposing that, here -- I think it's really complex issue. And in certain counties, there's a response time of maybe, like. 15 minutes for the police to reach the school. And studies show that the first shots in a school shooting, only in five minutes, so practically, the school is unarmed for 15 minutes and unable to defend themselves, and simply, like, giving teachers the opportunity to, like, defend their students, is a good thing. And all levels of the school system in that county, have to allow the teacher, and the teacher himself or herself has to voluntarily do the training to be able to carry a gun at school.

BARTIROMO: Kyle, where were you when you first learned there was an active shooter in school?

KASHUV: I was in a very close adjacent building. And in the beginning, I thought that it was -- it didn't sound like gun shots at all because they were so muffled, but I later realized that because it's in the freshman building, they sounded muffled.

BARTIROMO: And what happened? What did you -- what were you told? Can you walk us through it?

KASHUV: Yes, ma'am. So, I was in my last period class, and there was a fire drill, so I was gradually walking out, and then, I didn't want to leave the classroom and then I heard (INAUDIBLE) announcement saying, evacuate immediately. We evacuated immediately into the main hallway, and then we heard two pops. I didn't think it was gunshots.

People started panicking, so I want to run back into my teacher's classroom, and he closed the door on me. He closed the door on, like, a few of my fellow students and he wouldn't let us in, which he followed a procedure, he did. He feels terrible for what he did but it's completely understandable because he had no idea who the shooter was.

So, then we quickly ran to another teacher's room and she piled us in there. We then -- we hid in the closet for two hours and then constantly, we were getting feeds from our friends and our family were contacting us and everyone was hysterically crying, and I was trying to calm everyone down. Then, it took a while for SWAT to come get us because we've such a big campus. They had to take a while to clear it.

BARTIROMO: How do think things change at the school now?

KASHUV: Can you repeat that?

BARTIROMO: How do you think things will change now, at the school?

KASHUV: I think, now, a little -- like, as of right now, there's going to be a bigger police presence on campus, but sadly, I don't think that anything is going to really change in the next coming week. I think everything is going to stay the same. I don't think that we're going to have -- the only thing -- the only difference, we're going to have increased security by police office. I don't think that anything, specifically, other than that, will change in the security at our school.

BARTIROMO: All right, Kyle. We appreciate you joining us this morning. We all send love --

KASHUV: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: and support to you and all of your friends and colleagues at the school. Kyle, good luck going back today, thank you.

KASHUV: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kyle Kashuv, joining us there. Coming up, immigration crackdown despite a heads up from the mayor, ICE officials has arrested more than 150 illegal immigrants in a sweep in a California Sanctuary City. We're going to talk about that and why she gave the heads up to the criminals, and then, a major new milestone for the world's largest plane, details, coming up, back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, TSA, Transportation Security Administration, testing technology, now, in New York City that detects suicide vests, Lauren Simonetti with all the details, now, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Pretty unbelievable, Maria, those tests taking place this week with Amtrak at New York's Penn Station, the move, coming after that failed pipe bomb attempt in a subway passage way back in December. That was just a couple blocks from Penn station. This vest detection technology uses special cameras that can scan for explosive devices, but the TSA says the equipment can see through clothing, no privacy concerns because the image is animated.

Well, a massive ICE sweep in Northern California, more than 150 illegal immigrants taken into custody despite warnings from the mayor of Oakland. The top ice officials said the mayor's warning lightly gave criminals a chance to escape. The agency is now asking the Department of Justice to look into whether she violated any laws with that warning.

Meanwhile, big win for President Trump and his border wall. A federal judge ruling against an environmental challenge to the wall, saying Congress and the President share responsibilities to protect the country. Border wall construction plans can now move forward.

While there is a chance that the U.S. may rejoin the Transpacific Partnership or the TPP. Treasury Secretary, Steve Mnuchin, says renegotiation is on the table and that he's been in talks with other countries about what it would take for the us to recommit. President Trump as you know, withdrew from President Obama's signature trade agreement last year but Secretary Steve Mnuchin adding rejoining is not a priority for the administration at the moment.

And a new way to launch satellite into outer space, now the Strata Launch - - the world's largest airplane which can reach a speed of 46 miles an hour on the taxiway, that's a big deal. It's has a wingspan of 385 feet. It can carry 100,000 pounds. It's designed to bring rockets to the stratosphere for a more affordable launch for a low orbit satellites. The Strata Launch could make its first test flight by next year. And of course, Maria, Microsoft Co-Founder, Paul Allen, is backing this. This is his company.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right. Lauren, thank you so much. I want to talk about this testing at Penn Station. What do you thinL?

CHAFFETZ: Coincidentally I was at Penn Station, and I saw them doing this testing. I think it's good technology. Let's remember that the Pentagon spent more than $20 billion trying to figure out how to identify, improvised explosive devices. And you know what, the single best way to do it is, dogs. We can have all the technology we want, we need more dogs, because dogs can find these things, they're mobile, and they're the best deterrent that we have.

BARTIROMO: We now have smart dogs or so, yes, I agree with that.

KISSEL: Should we be more concerned about the TSA? And I was looking at some of these tests that they do, where they try to get bombmaking materials through the security at airports, and they fail the majority of the time, the overwhelming majority of the time. Is that an agency that needs more congressional oversight?

CHAFFETZ: It does and they need to look at the priority. Because you know what, dogs, they don't have lobbyists, but the people that sell these machines, by the hundreds of millions of dollars, they do have lobbyists. And often times, they're deploying technology that doesn't work. The Pentagon doesn't send this technology overseas, they don't have this technology at the White House. When you walk in to go into the oval office, you don't go through this machine, you walk by a dog. That's why they use them it's because they're the most effective things.

MCDOWELL: Very deterrent, but by the way, I know you know this but $0.60 of the TSA fee that we pay when we fly, $0.60 of the $5.60 goes to deficit reduction. There is a billion-and-a half-dollars-plus being diverted for deficit reduction rather than it being spent on actual airport security every year.

KISSEL: You wonder where all that money goes, you know, when you go through JFK or LaGuardia, you see all these people standing around, are they really looking out for our security? Is that a crack force that's going to find the next bomb?

CHAFFETZ: Security badges that airports biggest thing. There are 13,000 people with a security badge at Dulles airport in Washington D.C. One of those people slipping by at the wrong time, and you got a real problem.

MCDOWELL: And a TSA agent smacked my dog in the face by an accident, because he messing with it in August.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

MCDOWELL: Yes, so, that's what they're busy doing. Hitting fluffy, little 15-pound animals.

BARTIROMO: That was Charlie.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I'm not joking.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry to hear that. We'll take break. When we come back, the rise of the new Silicon Valley; how the Middle East is giving its California tech mecca a run for its money and market share. We're going to take a look. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Now, the latest in Silicon Valley, Apple shares hitting all- time high yesterday. Take a look, 178.50 is where the stock is now, up 30 percent this past year. Netflix is still driving the so-called fang stocks already up better than 45 percent this year. Joining us right now to talk more about tech and where the growth in the world is today is Chemi Peres, Chairman of the Peres Center for Peace and Innovation, and Managing General Partner of Pitango Venture Capital. Chemi, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

CHEMI PERES, CHAIRMAN, PERES CENTER FOR PEACE AND INNOVATION AND MANAGING GENERAL PARTNER OF PITANGO VENTURE CAPITAL: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Tell us what you're doing at Pitango and where you see growth in terms of innovation in the world today. You've been investing in a number of areas in tech.

PERES: For the best 25 years, we've been investing in Israeli technology, we're investing at growth stage, at early-stage, and incubation. And I think that the great thing that we're seeing; number one, probably, is cybersecurity, where it is a great concern around the world. Terrorism is globalized, so we are taking care of that. Secondly, there's tremendous innovation in A.I., machine learning, and deep learning to connect devices and machines to the Internet, to create new services. Thirdly, most likely is a precision medicine to help us get better and earlier.

And probably, I would say, in addition to those kinds of innovations, we're seeing also the attempt to decentralize the currency systems, to give it more freedom through blockchain technologies. And I think that what you've seen right now in terms of the share prices, you see that the greatest companies today in the world are technology companies pushing away, you know, oil, and gas, and chemicals, and construction. So, we are moving to a new world.

BARTIROMO: We sure are.

CHAFFETZ: Artificial intelligence is a big promise. There's a lot of good that can be done, there's also a lot of bad that can be done with artificial intelligence. So, where do you see that going, and how do we control it or does it need to be controlled?

PERES: So, first of all, you are very much right. Technology without moral values is very dangerous, so we have to develop more values. One of the trends that we're seeing also in the investment space, is that people are trying to achieve double bottom line, make progress on technology, but at the same time, make the world safer by using technology for the better. And I think this is a great challenge that human beings are facing in the next 10 to 20 years.

KISSEL: Chemi, should we be thinking about Israel is the second Silicon Valley? And for investors out there that are sick of the fang stocks here in the United States, you know, what are the companies that they should be looking at over there?

PERES: So, I think you shouldn't look at it as a second Silicon Valley, you should look at it as a first innovation nation. It's a nation that both created not from the land but from the mind. Everything that happen in Israel was not build upon the land. We cannot use the land for natural resources for food or water. Everything that we do, state foundation, security, economy, and peace-building is only with our brain. So, you should think of Israel as an empire of the mind, as a model for nations that would like to transition themselves from the old world where they rely on the land, to the new world which is limitless based on the brain power. That's the way you need to look at it.

KISSEL: Companies? Any companies?

PERES: Companies, probably the biggest company now emerging is Technologies Checkpoint, which is doing security, and other great company, I would say, is the company that Intel-acquired Mobile Eye, which now is turning to be a center for autonomous driving in Israel. But you know, we have 7,000 companies in Israel, and probably five percent of them are emerging as new, great ideas. And I think that in the next 10 years, we'll see tremendous number of Israeli companies really changing the world.

BARTIROMO: Your father used to talk about this a lot. The late great Shimon Peres, which talks about Israel as this hub for innovation. Why is that? Why has Israel been able to really compete with the best of the best in terms of innovation and technology growth?

PERES: So, as I said there, Maria, basically, you cannot build anything, because we have -- on the land, because our land is so small, it does not provide any shelter, no food, no water. So, we had to build everything on our brain power. So, number one is necessity, and the second thing I think is the notion that Israel wants to make the world better, to change the world for better. My father would say, most likely, that our biggest contribution for human beings is dissatisfaction; we're never satisfied with everything. So, we need to check everything with technology.

BARTIROMO: I like that. Great.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: By the way, the president announced, obviously, his future plans with the City of Jerusalem back in December of 2017 to move the embassy to Jerusalem. You're happy with this decision, obviously?

PERES: Obviously, I'm very happy. Not everything that is done for Israel is necessarily bad for other people. That should've been done in 1947 when Israel was established as a nation. Celebrating our 70th anniversary. I think it's a great present to fix what was wrong. It should have been, from day one, our capital.

BARTIROMO: Chemi, it's good to see you.

PERES: Good to see you, too. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Chemi Peres. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, February 28th.
