In Asia overnight, mixed performances, Korea was closed for a holiday but the Japan market, the Nikkei Average was the worst performer, down 1 1/2 percent.

Well it is that time of the year, tax season upon us, the Treasury Department is here to help. The agency has rolled out a new tax-cut calculator, how it works, coming up this morning.

Martin Shkreli's mea culpa, he calls himself now, `a fool,' when asking the judge for leniency in sentencing.

A new look for Lacoste, the company replacing its iconic alligator with endangered species, we'll tell you about it.

And talk about throwback Thursday, Levi's newest product will let you smell like Albert Einstein, whatever that smells like what we will tell you about it.

All that coming up this morning.

But first this, a bipartisan meeting on gun control, President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence gathered with lawmakers yesterday and weighed in on how to make communities safer, in the wake of the Florida school shooting, watch?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Take the firearms first and then go to court because that's another system because a lot of times by the time you go to court it takes so long to go to court to get the due process procedures, I like taking the guns early like in this crazy man's case.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL RICHARD "MIKE" PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: You could literally give families the tools, law enforcement, as my state has done, as other states have done, to be able to take action to remove those weapons for either a set period of time or longer to make sure that person can't be a threat.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And like many people this morning Republican Senator Ben Sasse is questioning president Trump's comments on due process, releasing a statement that reads in part, this, "We're not ditching any constitutional protection simply because the last person the president talked to today doesn't like them."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TEXT: "We're not ditching any Constitutional protection simply because the last person the President talked to today doesn't like them."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Americans for Tax Reform, President, Grover Norquist.

Grover good -

GROVER GLENN NORQUIST, FOUNDER AND PRESIDENT, AMERICANS FOR TAX REFORM & PRIMARY PROMOTER "TAXPAYER PROTECTION PLEDGE": Hi.

BARTIROMO: - to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

NORQUIST: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So, you're a board member of the NRA, yes?

NORQUIST: I am, yes.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on this?

NORQUIST: Well, let me speak for myself because the NRA has spokesmen.

When the president said, "Taking people's property without due process was another system.'

He's quite right, it is another system, it's not the American system and he has been very consistent in his campaign, in his commitment to the American people that he would protect the Second Amendment and that he would fight for lower crime by making it easier for people to have "concealed carry" reciprocity across state lines.

There are a lot of things we can do to reduce the damage that somebody like this can do; he broke several laws, he should've been arrested earlier, that would've kept him from being able to buy a gun.

It was a failure of the Florida local police department, the exact people who have been on TV saying, "Please look at something else."

So, we need to focus on things that will work.

I understand when you're sitting and batting around ideas with congressmen and senators you can say things that aren't particularly what you meant to say and that's why we have a House and a Senate, and the opportunity to move forward to make real progress, dealing with people who are a danger to themselves and others, not go after law-abiding citizens.

BARTIROMO: So, I the cameras were rolling, so you say -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - when you're just sitting around batting ideas you think he just - made a mistake when he said that?

NORQUIST: Yes. I do not -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - believe the president wanted to throw the Constitution in the trash container -

BARTIROMO: I would think not -

NORQUIST: - then the throw away comment.

BARTIROMO: - Dagen!

NORQUIST: - yes. When these thoughts stepped (ph) through, he's actually been consistent and very serious about both fighting real crime -

BARTIROMO: He has.

NORQUIST: - and protecting -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - honest citizens.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: "Take the guns first go through due process second," -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - that was a quote and he said it's essentially -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - more than once, Grover.

Number one -

NORQUIST: Yes -

MCDOWELL: - number -

NORQUIST: - I know.

MCDOWELL: - two he seemed to -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - come out against `concealed carry' reciprocity which the Republicans have been in favor of, at least in the short run to separate that from fixing the -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - background check system and also expanding background checks at the federal level to gun shows making a universal background check.

Why do you think he did that and do you think he'll come back around on pushing `concealed carry' reciprocity?

NORQUIST: Well he made that commitment to the American people when he ran for office and he's been very good about being consistent, saying that he's going to keep his word when he ran - when he ran for office.

The argument that we need reciprocity so that when you fly through New York they can't go through your luggage and arrest you, even you know, even if you never get off in New York, they've been going after people who have hunting and other gear in their carry - not in their carry-on luggage but in their checked luggage.

So, it's really outrageous what has happened, we need to protect these rights for all citizens.

And the president's made that commitment and he will keep that commitment.

MCDOWELL: But he was also - but he was also against -- he was for -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - an assault weapons ban years ago?

NORQUIST: Right.

MCDOWELL: He was -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - for it!

BARTIROMO: I think -

NORQUIST: He made a promise -

BARTIROMO: - the president wants -

NORQUIST: - (INAUDIBLE), yes.

BARTIROMO: - wants to show so much that he's a moderate and wants to effect change -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - that that's - I think that's why he's trying so hard to come across as look, `I'm here and I'm not going to be handcuffed by any rules that were in place before. I want to look at this with a fresh eye.'

MCDOWELL: But as a -

NORQUIST: Yes, yes.

MCDOWELL: - but as a member of the NRA, I want to add - I want to push back on what we heard from the president because anybody who has listened to liberals over the years, Grover, they don't want to just take away semi- automatic sporting rifles.

They want -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - to take away semi-automatic handguns in this country, handguns commit - they are involved in most of your firearms death in this country -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - that's why people who are proponents of the Second Amendment and who honor it, that's why they're concerned by this.

BARTIROMO: Isn't it 80 percent Dagen?

MCDOWELL: It's - the vast majority of firearm deaths in this country are actually by suicide -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - and it's less than a thousand homicides are committed or firearm homicides are committed by long guns.

MCSHANE: Let me just make one quick point in this, is that we've seen this before.

I mean what we're seeing - but I don't know about taxes but definitely on immigration, that we've seen all of this before, the president makes a point like this and you know, what's interesting, it's an interesting discussion to have but I don't know how much it matters -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCSHANE: - in a - in a forum like this -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCSHANE: - because the - you know, whatever legislation is put forward, again, that -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCSHANE: - exactly what happened on immigration.

It was really the president who stood in the way at the end of the day on the bipartisan compromise kind of reversing himself with the comments that he made in that meeting.

And he could easily reverse himself on -

BARTIROMO: And -

MCSHANE: - the comments he made yesterday.

BARTIROMO: - and it was Kevin McCarthy who said," Wait Mr. President" -

MCSHANE: Right.

BARTIROMO: - yes, in that -

MCSHANE: (INAUDIBLE) -

BARTIROMO: - immigration -

MCSHANE: - (INAUDIBLE) -

BARTIROMO: - I remember the meeting -

MCSHANE: - it could be like -

BARTIROMO: - exactly.

MCSHANE: - a replay.

BARTIROMO: You want to say something on this?

FREEMAN: Yes. He tweets and says a lot, you want to look at the results.

So, I guess so, I wonder from Grover, how do you think this ends up?

Is it just focused on keeping the mentally ill from guns, what comes of all this?

NORQUIST: Right. That's a very interesting question because having people who have mental health challenges that makes them a danger to themselves and others, that should've been in NICS (ph).

And it was the Democrats who kept it out, back in the 1990s, the National Rifle Association and Republicans thought it was a good idea but the other guys thought it was stigmatizing people to tell this young man in Florida, you - we think there's a problem with you.

You don't want to hurt his feelings, that's the Democrat problem. For decades we've lived with their mistake both the National Rifle Association and Republicans have always been willing to change that and the Democrats are trying to tell you to look someplace else.

Let's fix that problem and let's -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - not have gun free zones that make students a target because parents and administrators don't have the ability to `carry concealed' in schools, to make them safer.

We want safer schools, the left just wants gun control; that's why the conversation is so odd.

We're talking about how to make school safe -

BARTIROMO: Right.

NORQUIST: - and they just want to steal people's guns and they've been at it for decades so we kind of -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - know where they're going.

BARTIROMO: And that's a conversation right now, gun control, even though we know how many times the -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - signals and the signs were there, particularly about Nikolas Cruz -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - and there was a massive failure on the part of the FBI and the local police.

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We can't have you on without talking about tax reform and growth, Grover.

So, I've got to ask you -

NORQUIST: That's what I assumed that we were talking -

BARTIROMO: Sorry -

NORQUIST: - about here.

BARTIROMO: - about that Grover. You know, we have to get into the -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - issue of the day.

Let me ask you about your thoughts on growth.

Companies are reportedly buying back their stock at a quicker pace following the cut in corporate taxes.

"The Journal" says -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - that share buybacks from US businesses has exceeded $300 billion in the past three months.

What do you think about that?

And also, look at this, Atlanta Fed going from 5.4 percent growth, now they are at 2 1/2 percent growth, that they're expecting.

We also saw our GDP number that came down from the third quarter, now we're talking about growth of 2 1/2 percent.

Has your expectation changed of economic growth of four percent in `18 and where we are right now?

NORQUIST: No. I think we're looking very - moving forward very well.

The really good news is that companies are doing stock buybacks.

Why does that matter?

That means the companies are looking at bringing billions of dollars back from overseas and they say, `what's the best way I could spend a billion dollars, buying another company, starting a new line of business, or is our business is so good that we want to invest in us.'

Now that money doesn't disappear, they buy those stocks from somebody and the new investor reinvests that money to his or her highest and best value.

So, the money doesn't disappear in a buyback it moves between investors and it's a company saying, `we think we're the best game in town.'

I want to be invested in a firm whose management thinks the best thing you can do with a billion dollars is invest it in yourself because they think the future looks so good.

FREEMAN: We should note in that Journal story on - from the new side of our paper, it did note that a lot of CEOs along with planning buybacks also talking about more capital investment Grover, which is -

NORQUIST: Yes.

FREEMAN: - really that's going to be the test of this tax reform right.

It's higher investment because we're - we're rewarding more investment in the United States.

NORQUIST: We're bringing more capital in from overseas and more from the United States per worker, that gives you productivity increases, that gives your higher wages.

BARTIROMO: All right site sounds like you're still positive on this tax plan Grover?

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Good to -

NORQUIST: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: - see you sir. Thank you so -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - much.

Grover Norquist there.

Stay with us, we'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New questions this morning about why the FBI let a suspected hacker flee the country.

Lauren Simonetti with the details. Lauren?

SIMONETTI: "The Daily Caller" is reporting that the FBI apprehended the suspected hacker as she was trying to board a plane to Pakistan, carrying what appeared to be an illegal amount of cash.

Here's her husband, Imran Awan, he's awaiting charges on trial of fraudulent procurement as well as bank fraud but he's also suspected of hacking the computers of numerous House Democrats. He's due back in court next Thursday.

Well self-proclaimed "Pharma Bro" Martin Shkreli is now asking the judge for mercy and admitting to being `a fool.'

The judge ruled this week that Shkreli was responsible for $10 1/2 million dollars in losses in its securities fraud scheme, Shkreli reading a letter that he wrote, "I was wrong. I was a fool. I should've known better. I have learned a harsh lesson. The trial and six months in a maximum- security prison has been a frightening wake-up call. I now understand how I need to change."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TEXT: "I was wrong, I was a fool. I should've known better. I have learned a harsh lesson. The trial and six months in a maximum security prison has been a frightening wake-up call. I now understand how I need to change."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: He was convicted of cheating investors in two failed hedge funds back in August. He remains in jail and faces up to 20 years in prison; he is (ph) sentenced March the 9th.

Well Lacoste is throwing the power of its brand behind endangered species. The company making a limited-edition polo shirt that replaces the iconic crocodile logo, the alligator, with 10 endangered species including the California Condor, the Javan rhino, and the Sumatran Tiger.

Sales will go towards conservation efforts.

And how to smell like a genius!

A perfume company New York claims they've come up with the scent of Albert Einstein, here's the catch, you actually have to buy a replica of the Levi's brown leather jacket that he wore.

The - he - Levi's acquired the original jacket two years at action for more than a hundred and fifty thousand dollars and now the perfume and the jacket can be yours for 1,200 bucks; interesting!

BARTIROMO: Well it can't - it can't possibly still smell!

SIMONETTI: Or it could but -

BARTIROMO: I mean -

SIMONETTI: - I don't think we want to smell like whatever it does smell like at this point.

BARTIROMO: - OK.

Smell like a genius!

SIMONETTI: I'll just go you know, stand by you guys on the panel, you'll smell like a genius.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Lauren.

Still ahead, growing a dream. I'll talk with country star and Army Vet, Craig Morgan about his new dream project, "The Gallery at Morgan Farms" in his new series.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: That was great. It was a clip from, "Morgan Family Strong," the new series featuring Country Music Star and US Army Veteran, Craig Morgan and his family at home, on tour, and coming together to build their dream project, "The Gallery at Morgan Farms."

It premieres tonight, 9:30 p.m. Eastern on "Up TV."

Joining me right now is a man himself, and his daughter, Craig and his daughter Aly Morgan Beaird.

(BEGIN AUDIOTAPE)

Great to see you both - guys. Thank you so much for joining us.

CRAIG MORGAN GREER, COUNTRY MUSIC STAR, AWARD-WINNING TV HOST, "MORGAN FAMILY STRONG" STAR & US ARMY VET: Thank you.

ALY MORGAN BEAIRD, SINGER, SONGWRITER, MUSICAL ARTIST & "MORGAN FAMILY STRONG" STAR: Thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations. Tell us about "The Gallery at Morgan Farms" Craig?

MORGAN: It's - it's funny because it's not what you would think, the - we've - we've had so many people email us on Facebook was asking when we'll have our tomatoes out and those kinds of things.

It's not that type of a story, it really is a gallery, we feature art, artistic pieces, artisan pieces; all of the wood pieces I do myself and it's all -

BARTIROMO: Wow!

MORGAN: - handmade from repurposed, reclaimed -

BARTIROMO: Fantastic!

MORGAN: - (INAUDIBLE) wood.

And I tell people we don't just sell bowls and spoons and centerpieces we sell stories.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: Every piece of wood has a story, we know where it came from; some of the pieces are - that are featured are made from a tree that Jim Ed Brown, Country Music Hall of Fame, Grand Ole Opry member, he planted that tree. It died, he had to cut it down and I got some of the wood and I made something out of it -

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) -

MORGAN: - thanks to his daughter.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

And how do you like working with your father on this?

MORGAN BEAIRD: Oh, it's awesome.

The fact - you know, running a family business is really cool anyway but running a family business in light of his career makes it a little more challenging.

But it's really cool, everything in the store is made by somebody in the family and that's - it's really cool that we can bring our talents together and distribute them.

BARTIROMO: Which is why it's - it's getting such a great reception.

So, Morgan Farms came together around the tragic loss of your son?

MORGAN: It did.

BARTIROMO: Craig, tell us about that, Jerry, rather than turning to music, you turned to woodworking?

MORGAN: That's a fact.

Music is a big part of my life obviously but I don't know there's something - there's something very spiritual about us, time with yourself, with a knife and a piece of wood, just whittling something out or carving out or -

BARTIROMO: It's therapeutic!

MORGAN: - it is very therapeutic -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: - you know, a lot of our veterans make walking canes, they have a program at Fort - BARTIROMO: Wow!

MORGAN: - Campbell and they make - they carve out different things on walking canes.

And I don't know why but that's what I went to.

We had this idea and I knew that it was important in light of this tragedy that my family focus on something, we - aside from our faith and we are very, very spiritual family and very tight-knit family but I knew we needed focus on something else collectively.

And so, I created the brand `Morgan Farms' and between Alex and myself we started this brick-and-mortar store; the two of us started it and we're the two doing the least amount of work.

MORGAN BEAIRD: That's true (ph).

BARTIROMO: And you can get this wine there?

MORGAN: You can order the wine off Lot18.com -

BARTIROMO: OK.

MORGAN: - we have a - we have a set up where you can order it through - from the store, through the store but look you can do it at your house is well, it's easier.

BARTIROMO: You should - you know, having a family business is fun to start with but working day-in and day-out with the family, I mean it's got to be important to you to actually see this is not just fun but you're actually creating profits and it's a business.

MORGAN BEAIRD: Oh, for sure and I think some of us keep that in mind more than others you know.

But it's been fun to kind of learn how to run a business and then how to run a business together; it's two totally different things and so you know, sometimes the bills gets pushed aside and you get it last day, you've got to run those, to get them paid (INAUDIBLE).

MORGAN: (INAUDIBLE) pay (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: But you still got - you still got the music career, alive and -

MORGAN: We do.

BARTIROMO: - strong.

MORGAN BEAIRD: Yes.

MORGAN: Yes. I'm very blessed with the - with the career that I've had - still having the music business; in the process of working on a new music right now, just got out of the studio last week, working on a new album so.

But it's exciting, there's a lot going on and I'm - I'm very fortunate to be able to share it with my family.

BARTIROMO: We love this, Craig, Aly, great to see you both. Thanks so much for joining us.

Tech Crackdown; People are Spending Upwards of 60 Percent of their Income on Rent; President Trump Says it's Time for Lawmakers to Come Together on the Issue; The Dow and the S&P 500 Seeing Their Worst Month of Decline Since January 2016; President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence Gathered with Lawmakers Yesterday and Weighed in on How to Make Communities Safer2018-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:09ZLexisNexisGun Debate; White House Shakeup; E.U. Tech Crackdown; People are Spending Upwards of 60 Percent of their Income on Rent; President Trump Says it's Time for Lawmakers to Come Together on the Issue; The Dow and the S&P 500 Seeing Their Worst Month of Decline Since January 2016; President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence Gathered with Lawmakers Yesterday and Weighed in on How to Make Communities SaferLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday -- March 1.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The winning streak was snapped, the Dow ending February on a sour note falling nearly 400 points yesterday. It was the worst month since January 2016 for both the Dow and the S&P 500 which snapped 10-month winning streaks for both indices. That was the longest streak, by the way, since 1959. So should investors beware of the ides of March?

Futures showing the markets will open lower this morning. This is the low of the morning so far. We're looking at a decline of 131 points on the Dow Industrials, that's one-half of 1 percent, down 12 points on the S&P and down 28 on the Nasdaq.

Investors are watching key remarks today from Federal Reserve chairman J. Powell once again as he testifies today before the Senate Banking Committee this morning.

In Europe, right across the board, we're looking at declines there as well with the FT 100, the CAC 40 and the DAX index down between 1 percent and one and two-thirds percent.

In Asia overnight mixed performances. South Korea was closed for a holiday but the worst performer was Japan, Nikkei average down 1.5 percent.

Getting tough on guns -- President Trump telling lawmakers yesterday they need to come together on gun control regardless of outside pressure.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This is not a popular thing to say in terms of the NRA, but I'm saying it anyway. I'm going to have to say it.

You can't buy -- think of it. You can buy a handgun. You can't buy one, you have to wait until you're 21, but you can buy the kind of weapon used in the school shooting at 18. I think it's something you have to think about. But lot of people don't even want to bring it up because they're afraid to bring it up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The debate comes as companies take matters into their own hands. Wal-Mart, for example, taking a lead from Dick's Sporting Goods. Wal-Mart says it will stop selling guns to anyone under the age of 21. More on the major changes retailers are making, coming up.

And a shootout caught on tape. Look at this. The shocking scene as over 60 bullets are fired in just 15 seconds in a gunfight between police and a suspect.

Then YouTube bias -- the technology giant says moderators mistakenly pulled right wing channels from the site. What a surprise.

Martin Shkreli begs for mercy, saying he was a fool. His plea to the judge as he faces up to 10 years in prison.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Fox Business Network's Connell McShane and the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman. Great to see everybody.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN HOST: Nobody will argue with Shkreli that he's a fool, I guess.

BARTIROMO: You're not going to go against that.

MCSHANE: It's an important story --

BARTIROMO: You're not going to take the other side on that -- James?

FREEMAN: I was trying to think of an opposite argument but --

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: this is something one of our viewers raised yesterday. But I'm waiting to a see a constitutional challenge to a Wal- Mart or a Dick's that if you're going to deny the purchase of a rifle or shotgun to someone under the age of 21 when legally it's still the national law that the age is 18 at the federal level for these weapons.

By the way, this was virtue signaling and some attempted good PR yesterday from Wal-Mart and particularly Dick's. Dick's stopped selling these assault style rifles six years ago. Wal-Mart stopped selling them back in 2015.

MCSHANE: But still sold them in one of their affiliates -- right.

MCDOWELL: It was like 30 some odd stores that Dick's sold them in but broadly speaking, the chain nationally hasn't sold them in six years. So - -

BARTIROMO: Wal-Mart may get pressure from customers or you know, anti-gun people saying look, Dick's Sporting Goods just did that, what are you going to do? I mean a lot of these companies are getting pressure from their customers, also.

MCDOWELL: And by the way -- Dick's we should say sold a shotgun to the Parkland, Florida killer Nikolas Cruz back in November. It was not used in the shooting at the high school but nevertheless, this is nothing but public relations.

They can act like it's something about morality but it's not. It's virtue signaling.

FREEMAN: I think there are a lot of customers and they talk about the NRA like it's some special interest representing the gun industry. It has power because there are millions and millions of Americans who treasure their Second Amendment rights. You get rid of the NRA -- that would not change. There would be another vehicle to express that feeling that is broadly held in the United States.

But speaking of public relations, Martin Shkreli does seem to be someone who could use improved public relations. Maybe he could be Hope Hicks' first client.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MCSHANE: Very good.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: We're talking about Hope Hicks coming up.

Joining the conversation this morning: the counselor to the President Kellyanne Conway is with us this morning; country music icon, military vet and award-winning TV host Craig Morgan with us as well. Lots to talk about on both of those cases.

You don't want to miss a moment of it so do stay with us.

We kick it off this hour though with this. President Trump expected to take action this afternoon by rolling out a package aimed at making schools safer. The President took to Twitter earlier this morning, writing this. "Many ideas, some good, some not so good, emerged from our bipartisan meeting on school safety yesterday at the White House. Background checks, a big part of the conversation; gun-free zones, a proven target of killers. After many years a bill should emerge. Respect the Second Amendment."

This comes after he publicly sparred with Republicans yesterday over concealed carry and NRA influence. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We can do that with an executive order. I'm going to write the bump stock, essentially write it out. So you won't have to worry about bump stocks. Shortly that will be gone. We can focus on other things.

Joe and Pat, in your bill, what do you think about the 18 to 21?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We need to change that.

TRUMP: Ok. Are you going to leave that? A lot of people don't even want to bring it up because they're afraid to bring it up.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We didn't address it, Mr. President. But I think --

TRUMP: You know why? Because you're afraid of the NRA.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Let's bring in RNC national spokesperson Kayleigh McEnany. Kayleigh -- good to see you. Thanks very much for joining us this morning.

So you just heard the President there.

KAYLEIGH MCENANY, RNC NATIONAL SPOKESPERSON: Thanks -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Are Republicans too afraid to act because of the NRA? Are they afraid of the NRA? Is that what it is?

MCENANY: Well, look, I think the NRA's obviously a powerful lobbying group and the President was pointing that out and it's not just Republicans. There are moderate Democrats too.

And you know, he was pointing out that we need to have one special interest and that's the American people. That's the square focus of this. That's President Trump's square focus and he's saying that no lobbying group should keep us away from meaningful compromise when it comes to guns.

MCSHANE: When a Republican president though looks at a Republican senator and says you're afraid to act because you're afraid of the NRA, how does that go over. How is that going over with Republicans that you've spoken with since those comments?

MCENANY: Well, since then the senators came out -- Senator Toomy and said I don't think President Trump was meaning that directly towards me. He was saying it more generally that the NRA has a lot of influence over a lot of elected officials. So no Republicans are too upset about it.

I think right now we're just trying to find solutions for those kids to make sure that this never ever happens again in this country.

FREEMAN: Kayleigh -- I'm wondering, is there any effort here in the administration to fix what went wrong at the FBI in this case? It seems to me when credible reports come in with a specific name and a specific warning about a specific action that is going to be taken, you would hope they would respond.

MCENANY: Oh, absolutely. There will be multiple, multiple investigations into that. President Trump has said it's inexcusable that the ball was dropped there. Likewise, the local police department.

We need to have meaningful warning signs that we look into and that we pursue vigorously. But what President Trump has said, we need to make sure that we can actually take these weapons away from individuals who are mentally ill.

That's so important. Because there can be a million warning signs but unless we have the means and the statutory tools to make change, then those warning signs will really fall on deaf ears.

MCDOWELL: But Kayleigh -- it's Dagen McDowell -- he said take the firearms first, then go to court. Take the gun first, due process second. That's a violation of the Fifth Amendment. So what did he mean by that?

Because it seemed he was getting in a back and forth with Vice President Pence who was talking about these gun violence restraining orders which it gives families, law enforcement, prosecutors a way to get weapons out of the hands of people who are potentially a threat to themselves or someone else but there is due process. You have to go to court.

And President Trump said take the guns, due process second. Did he misspeak?

MCENANY: No, Dagen. I think this was -- look, this was a discussion. Most of the time the media isn't let in on these conversations. We were let in on it to see this discussion and these ideas bouncing around.

Today we'll get the official proposals. Everything that's done will be constitutional. It will be above board. But I think President Trump is expressing frustration that we knew this individual wanted to be a school shooter. He said it himself.

The police had gone there. And yet, he still has these weapons and still wreaks havoc on society and ends multiple lives. So I think it was just a free-flowing discussion. Today we will get the official proposals.

But I'm glad the media was let in on that. I'm glad the American people saw that serious discussion happen.

BARTIROMO: Did you get a lot of comments from Republicans, the GOP? What did they say about that comment?

MCENANY: Well look, we're happy about what we saw yesterday because finally we have a president that's putting politics aside --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCENANY: -- and just having a pragmatic discussion. That's what we need is a pragmatic discussion. And what you saw yesterday was the ultimate deal maker, the ultimate pragmatist in President Trump bringing the two sides together. So our party was thrilled about that.

MCDOWELL: I just need to add something, they didn't see that as a pragmatic discussion. They saw it as someone that was chucking the constitution and was talking about confiscating people's weapons without even a court order. That's what a lot of people heard. And people were outraged. People who were Trump supporters were very upset by that.

MCENANY: This was just a discussion though. What we saw yesterday --

BARTIROMO: Well, the cameras were rolling.

MCENANY: This was not laying out the legislative -- sure it was not laying out the official legislative solutions. But President Trump is frustrated. Most Americans are frustrated. When we look at polls to the tune of 70 percent to 80 percent are supporting most of the policies that were discussed yesterday. We'll get the official policies out today. But I think that was important to see and we've got to get weapons out of the hands of those who want to commit atrocities like what we saw in Parkland, Florida. It's inexcusable.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a different conversation, getting guns out of the mentally ill. I mean what Dagen is talking about is take the guns first and then court later. I mean, due process second. So we're talking about two different things.

MCENANY: It's the same thing, because President Trump is not talking about confiscating weapons from Americans. He's a supporter of the Second Amendment. He's a supporter of the NRA. He's talking about individuals like Nikolas Cruz -- I hate to even use the kid's name. He's a murderer. That's what we're talking about.

He's the biggest supporter of the Second Amendment there is but he's also a supporter of making sure these shootings don't happen.

BARTIROMO: Let me switch gears and ask you about the White House shakeup, latest news here.

The President's communications director Hope Hicks announced yesterday she plans to leave within the next few weeks. President Trump reacted to the resignation in a statement, writing this in part, "Hope is outstanding and has done great work for the last three years. I will miss having her by my side. But when she approached me about pursuing other opportunities I totally understood."

Kayleigh -- what's your reaction to this? Is this because of that testimony the other day you think where she said sometimes she has to say white lies to protect the President?

MCENANY: No, it's not because Hope had told many people before that testimony that she was leaving. So several people knew. It had nothing to do with the testimony. She was looking at other opportunities for a very long time. She's a valued member of this administration.

But Maria -- three years working nonstop, you know, 18-hour days in many cases, that's a long time. So it's perfectly reasonable that she would want to move forward. It really had nothing to do with the testimony.

BARTIROMO: The timing is -- I mean she's a communications expert, right? I mean to come out the day after the testimony and say I'm stepping down to pursue other opportunities, sounds a little sketchy there.

MCENANY: Well, the timing is what it is --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: I'm wondering if the Democrats -- I'm wondering if the Democrats set her up. I mean they kept asking apparently in the testimony, did you ever lie for the President. Have you ever told white lies for the President. And then she acquiesced and said yes, like things like, you know, he's in a meeting when he's really not in a meeting. And then immediately that quote of "I tell white lies" was leaked.

So once again we've got the leakers out in force on the left. So was that part of it, do you think?

MCENANY: Maria, that's exactly right. I do think the Democrats set her up. You know, she -- Hope's goal was complete honesty in this testimony. She took great pains to ensure she was providing accurate answers. And so accurate to say, you know, yes, maybe one time I said he was in a meeting when he actually wasn't and the Democrats ran with it. I think that's spot-on.

Hope is a valued member of this administration and we thank her for her service at the Republican Party.

FREEMAN: Yes. Just to add a little context there, often I think as we talk to public relations people, representing politicians, the little white lie is standard for instance, when they say yes, my boss very much enjoys talking to you.

MCENANY: That's right.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point -- James. You're right.

MCENANY: Yes. And I'm sure he doesn't enjoy talking to much of the mainstream media who is on an effort to get him.

BARTIROMO: Kayleigh -- what's with this war of words between Attorney General Jeff Sessions and the President? Of course, the President tweeted out yesterday, questioning Sessions asking the inspector general to investigate potentially massive FISA abuses. Sessions fought back saying in part that he will continue to do this work in a fair and impartial manner according to the law and constitution as long as he is attorney general.

Why doesn't the President just go directly to Sessions and confront him rather than calling him out on Twitter?

MCENANY: I'm sure he has. But the President's frustrated, you know. He appointed an attorney general and on many of these investigations he's having to recuse himself or step down. And the Justice Department isn't functioning as President Trump would like it to function.

You know, these FISA abuses are serious. They're real. We have a Department of Justice with prosecutorial power and President Trump wants them to do their job and look into it. So that's why. He's out there and he wants to say it publicly that he wants the DOJ to step up and put pressure on them.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Kayleigh -- good to see you. Thanks so much.

MCENANY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Kayleigh McEnany joining us there.

We've got this breaking news. The President just tweeted this and we want to get this out. He says "Our steel and aluminum industries and many others have been decimated by decades of unfair trade and bad policy with countries from around the world. We must not let our country, companies, and workers be taken advantage of any longer. We want free, fair and smart trade." That's from the President.

James Freeman -- I know you have comments on that. We'll get back to that after this short break. Back in a minute, everybody.

Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Now this, Broadcom making an appeal to Qualcomm shareholders to support the proposed merger.

Lauren Simonetti with all the details now -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well Broadcom, Maria, is continuing to pursue a proposed merger with rival Qualcomm. Broadcom now urging Qualcomm shareholders to vote for all six Broadcom nominees at the upcoming shareholder meeting which is next week.

Broadcom recently lowered its hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm after Qualcomm raised it's own bid for NXP Semiconductor. There was a best and final offer of $121 billion -- that was on Monday.

Take a look at Broadcom shares, down a third of 1 percent in the premarket. Qualcomm shares in the pre-market are down just fractionally.

So we'll continue to watch this story for you which could be the biggest tech deal we've ever seen.

Check this out. Stunning video from the San Francisco Police Department, officials showing us the body camera video. Seven officers firing at least 65 times -- 65 times within 15 seconds at a suspect that's holed up in an RV on a residential street. The suspect was ordered to come out several times but he fired two shots instead. Listen.

Scary stuff. The suspect was linked to a homicide as well as a carjacking. Amazingly in that situation nobody was hurt.

Best Buy is moving to cut costs as more of us shop online. The company closing its 250 mobile phone stores in the U.S. by June. Best Buy says it will continue to sell cell phones online and in these big stores.

They also just announced quarterly earnings. Revenue of $15.3 billion better than expected. And look at this -- shares rallying 5.5 percent in the premarket.

Well, this is a fun story. The Utah legislature taking a page from schoolhouse rock. Lawmakers explaining the lawmaking process, how a bill becomes law with some help from the Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: In a legislator's mind an idea is raised.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: In the law book is where they spend most of their days.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Drafting out, maxing out, hardly relaxing -- all cool.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And all introducing bills inside of house chambers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Who says politics wasn't cool. That video seen tens of thousands of times since it was tweeted out yesterday. So there you have it.

BARTIROMO: I love that. That is so great. Thanks -- Lauren.

Coming up, another case of big tech bias -- YouTube caught removing conservative channels from the Web site. Why the company claims it was all a mistake by its moderation team.

And then the essence of Einstein, how Levi's claims it bottled the scent of the genius -- next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Breaking news this morning. E.U. tech crackdown -- the European Union has issued new guidelines for technology companies saying that they must remove terror and illegal content within one hour after it's flagged by authorities.

Joining us right now to talk tech is Kairos founder and CEO Ankur Jain. Ankur -- good to see you.

ANKUR JAIN, FOUNDER, KAIROS: Thanks. Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us.

We were just talking in the commercial break about a bigger technology regulatory hand. Are you expecting the rules and regulations to get stiffer for tech?

JAIN: Yes. I mean look, it's a tough spot right now, right. Because technology companies in many ways have more power and influence on our lives than even governments. And yet we don't have the same kind of accountability structure that governments, you know, conceptually do.

And so I think one of the things you're going to see now over the next couple months or the next year at least is either governments are going to regulate tech or tech has to regulate itself.

Unfortunately, I don't think we've seen that level of responsibility yet from the tech companies.

MCSHANE: How would a company -- say you're a tech CEO and we've dealt with this here in the U.S. too, it's not just Europe where we've had hearings in Washington about it.

BARTIROMO: Well, remember Microsoft.

MCDOWELL: Right, right. Yes, to go back that far. But now, just in the present day, as we're looking at these things, if you're seeing it come at your company, to your point about regulating yourself, how do you step up and get out ahead of (INAUDIBLE)

JAIN: There's obviously a proactive and reactive side.

MCSHANE: Right.

JAIN: I think the biggest challenge right now is when you look at how much the tech companies shape the content and information that we all consume as citizens, obviously that has a tremendous effect on our political environment, our social environment, et cetera. The challenge is, there's no easy solution to just say here's the rules and we go because there's so much gray area.

But I think having even a third party group that's outside of the tech business with a set of rules, like any media company, like Fox or any group has a set of clear guidelines.

BARTIROMO: Like the business council in business.

JAIN: That's right. The problem is, it's a group of entrepreneurs trying to figure out what the right thing is for everybody else and frankly it's not fair to the founders to know all the answers -- right.

MCDOWELL: Right.

JAIN: But it's also not fair to the society to expect no regulation or no support on that side..

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But I just feel like that they continue to -- these technology companies, particularly these social media companies, continue to over- step. And at first it's oh, we rolled out the Facebook Live feature. We didn't know how people would abuse it with live suicides or violent crimes.

But this past week people on Facebook started getting this message about facial recognition. I don't know if you saw it.

JAIN: I did.

MCDOWELL: Hi, we're working on making Facebook better, we're adding more ways to use facial recognition. You can find photos you're tagged in but haven't been tagged. And it said, you can turn it on at any time. They said it was off, which applies to features we may add later.

So they were acting like it was an opt-in. Mine was an opt-out. It's a huge -- I had to go in there and it was already on, and again, I just feel like that they act like they're noble and doing no evil. But they're being reckless and they know what they're doing.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. And then there's this whole pushback on any conservative ideas. You know, why is Peter Thiel leaving San Francisco and moving his whole business to L.A. because he says that there's constant pushback and inability and unwillingness to hear any other diversity of ideas.

Look at YouTube, moderators employed by YouTube to spot fake news and misleading and extreme videos. They say it was a mistake but they removed numerous conservative content channels. What's going on with tech?

(CROSSTALK)

JAIN: Yes. Look -- It's not just conservative views. I think one of the challenges right now is that it's become such an echo chamber of all ideas. And so I think what you're going to start to see is some of the best tech minds moving out of just Silicon Valley. I think you're seeing New York already boom.

BARTIROMO: You came to New York.

JAIN: I moved to New York. You're seeing Peter Thiel and others moving to L.A. I think the more we start to see the proliferation of technology companies be outside of the one geographic area, it will change, right you have different perspectives, different views.

We've talked about this last month. When people in the Valley start to think that the biggest problem in the world, I think we talked about that $4,000 treadmill last time I was here, there's a disconnect with some of the reality challenges there. But you still want the best and brightest minds to have the freedom to push the limits of innovation. So it's finding that right balance.

FREEMAN: Ok. But I'm not questioning whether social media companies have discriminated against conservative views. Do you see that or do you think this is an honest mistake? A drafting error on the algorithm?

JAIN: Look, you have individual bad actors in the system. That's the challenge, right. I think as a company no executive would condone that kind of behavior or allow that in advance, right. But like the Twitter if you guys remember when the one rogue Twitter employee shut down President Trump's account --

MCSHANE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Right.

JAIN: The challenge for this right now is that when it comes to major decisions you need to operate fast and at scale to give people the autonomy to do that but then you end up with these bad actors.

And so I think as we start to see the regulation and the penalties for the bad acting, it will force the companies to find kind of fail-safes for these kind of issues.

BARTIROMO: It's a good analysis. Ok. Tell us about your new business -- the future of renting.

JAIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Rhino -- you launched it yesterday. It's the newest launch from Kairos. You found a solution for security deposits that you say were debilitating for so many apartment renters.

JAIN: If you remember at Kairos, we're trying now to find new innovation to help everyday folks. I think that's one of the areas that unfortunately not enough technology companies are focused on.

And when you look at the cost of renting today, people are spending upwards of 60 percent of their income on rent. And so our goal was, there's two parts, how do we reduce the upfront burden for people moving into a new place and how do we reduce the recurring monthly costs.

And we started with the former. So with Rhino, which launched yesterday, starting in New York 23,000 renters are going to be able to get back thousands of dollars from their landlords that was locked away for as long as they rented.

BARTIROMO: Because it was a security deposit.

JAIN: That's right. You put up -- I mean there's $40 billion that renters have locked away that they don't ever really get back because it goes from one apartment to the other. And then meanwhile, 50 percent of Americans can't even afford a $400 emergency expense.

So starting now, people will be able to file a claim, get back the deposit, it's a small $10 monthly insurance deposit to protect them and their landlord. And we think giving people back thousands of dollars, you've got your tax rebate and you have Rhino -- right.

BARTIROMO: That's great.

FREEMAN: But if people are paying 60 percent of their income to rent and they don't have the savings so they need to finance the deposit -- isn't that an argument that we need to pay less for housing?

JAIN: Well so if you remember at Kairos we're trying now to find new innovation to help everyday folks.

I think that's one of the areas that unfortunately not enough technology companies are focused on and when you look at the cost of renting today, people are spending upward of 60 percent of their income on rent.

And so, our goal was, there's two parts, how do we reduce the upfront burden for people moving into a new place and then having to reduce recurring monthly cost and we're starting with the former.

So, with Rhino which launched yesterday, starting in New York 23,000 renters are going to be able to get back thousands of dollars from their landlords that was locked away for as long as they rented -

BARTIROMO: Because it was a security deposit?

JAIN: - that's right, you put up - I there's $40 billion that renters have locked away that they don't ever really get back because it goes from one apartment to the other.

And then in the meanwhile 50 percent of Americans can't even afford a four- hundred-dollar emergency expense.

So, starting now people will be able to file a claim, get back their deposit, it's a small $10 a month insurance policy that protects them and their landlord, and we think giving people back thousands of dollars, you've got your tax rebate and you have Rhino.

BARTIROMO: That's great.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: But if people are paying 60 percent of their income to rent -

JAIN: Yes.

FREEMAN: - and they don't have the savings so they need to finance the deposit -

JAIN: Yes.

FREEMAN: - isn't that an argument that they need to pay less for housing?

JAIN: Well it's - first of all there's - there's choices (INAUDIBLE) -

FREEMAN: I know it's -

JAIN: - (INAUDIBLE) -

FREEMAN: - not for fun but-

JAIN: - I mean, but it's also you don't want to finance the deposit.

I don't think people should be taking on more debt right now, that's part of the problem, right.

Is we don't think people should have that financial burden in the first place so with Rhino there is no debt, there is no loan, you're basically buying a small, affordable, insurance policy because most renters aren't bad actors, right.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

JAIN: And there's no reason for landlords to be locking up $40 billion of people's money.

BARTIROMO: That's a great idea!

Another great idea from you Ankur.

Thanks for -

JAIN: (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: - thanks for bringing it to us.

JAIN: Thanks, so much guys.

BARTIROMO: Ankur Jain, we'll be watching; check out Rhino.

Coming up a change of heart on gun control, President Trump says it's time for lawmakers to come together on the issue. The backlash from his own party, coming up.

And then a new side to the former Pharma executive, once known as the most hated man in America, why Martin Shkreli now says he's a changed man; he's awaiting sentencing.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us, happy Thursday.

I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, March 1st; your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Stocks are under pressure right now, Futures extending earlier decline, Dow Industrials now down 90 points on top of the big selloff yesterday, we are expecting a weaker start to trading this morning.

We are awaiting a second round of testimony from the Federal Reserve chairman, J. Powell. Today he speaks in front of the Senate Banking Committee.

A rocky end the month of February, for sure, stock sliding across the board for the month, the Dow and the S&P 500 seeing their worst month of decline since January 2016, capped by yesterday's close with a decline of 380 points lower on the S&P.

European markets also lower this morning, take a look, FT 100 down two thirds of a percent, the CAC krone and the DAX Index down better than one percent.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances, Korea was closed for a holiday but the Japan market, the Nikkei Average was the worst performer, down 1 1/2 percent.

Well it is that time of the year, tax season upon us, the Treasury Department is here to help. The agency has rolled out a new tax-cut calculator, how it works, coming up this morning.

Martin Shkreli's mea culpa, he calls himself now, 'a fool,' when asking the judge for leniency in sentencing.

A new look for Lacoste, the company replacing its iconic alligator with endangered species, we'll tell you about it.

And talk about throwback Thursday, Levi's newest product will let you smell like Albert Einstein, whatever that smells like what we will tell you about it.

All that coming up this morning.

But first this, a bipartisan meeting on gun control, President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence gathered with lawmakers yesterday and weighed in on how to make communities safer, in the wake of the Florida school shooting, watch?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Take the firearms first and then go to court because that's another system because a lot of times by the time you go to court it takes so long to go to court to get the due process procedures, I like taking the guns early like in this crazy man's case.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL RICHARD "MIKE" PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: You could literally give families the tools, law enforcement, as my state has done, as other states have done, to be able to take action to remove those weapons for either a set period of time or longer to make sure that person can't be a threat.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And like many people this morning Republican Senator Ben Sasse is questioning president Trump's comments on due process, releasing a statement that reads in part, this, "We're not ditching any constitutional protection simply because the last person the president talked to today doesn't like them."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TEXT: "We're not ditching any Constitutional protection simply because the last person the President talked to today doesn't like them."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Americans for Tax Reform, President, Grover Norquist.

Grover good -

GROVER GLENN NORQUIST, FOUNDER AND PRESIDENT, AMERICANS FOR TAX REFORM & PRIMARY PROMOTER "TAXPAYER PROTECTION PLEDGE": Hi.

BARTIROMO: - to see you. Thanks very much for joining us.

NORQUIST: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: So, you're a board member of the NRA, yes?

NORQUIST: I am, yes.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on this?

NORQUIST: Well, let me speak for myself because the NRA has spokesmen.

When the president said, "Taking people's property without due process was another system.'

He's quite right, it is another system, it's not the American system and he has been very consistent in his campaign, in his commitment to the American people that he would protect the Second Amendment and that he would fight for lower crime by making it easier for people to have "concealed carry" reciprocity across state lines.

There are a lot of things we can do to reduce the damage that somebody like this can do; he broke several laws, he should've been arrested earlier, that would've kept him from being able to buy a gun.

It was a failure of the Florida local police department, the exact people who have been on TV saying, "Please look at something else."

So, we need to focus on things that will work.

I understand when you're sitting and batting around ideas with congressmen and senators you can say things that aren't particularly what you meant to say and that's why we have a House and a Senate, and the opportunity to move forward to make real progress, dealing with people who are a danger to themselves and others, not go after law-abiding citizens.

BARTIROMO: So, I the cameras were rolling, so you say -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - when you're just sitting around batting ideas you think he just - made a mistake when he said that?

NORQUIST: Yes. I do not -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - believe the president wanted to throw the Constitution in the trash container -

BARTIROMO: I would think not -

NORQUIST: - then the throw away comment.

BARTIROMO: - Dagen!

NORQUIST: - yes. When these thoughts stepped (ph) through, he's actually been consistent and very serious about both fighting real crime -

BARTIROMO: He has.

NORQUIST: - and protecting -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - honest citizens.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: "Take the guns first go through due process second," -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - that was a quote and he said it's essentially -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - more than once, Grover.

Number one -

NORQUIST: Yes -

MCDOWELL: - number -

NORQUIST: - I know.

MCDOWELL: - two he seemed to -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - come out against 'concealed carry' reciprocity which the Republicans have been in favor of, at least in the short run to separate that from fixing the -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - background check system and also expanding background checks at the federal level to gun shows making a universal background check.

Why do you think he did that and do you think he'll come back around on pushing 'concealed carry' reciprocity?

NORQUIST: Well he made that commitment to the American people when he ran for office and he's been very good about being consistent, saying that he's going to keep his word when he ran - when he ran for office.

The argument that we need reciprocity so that when you fly through New York they can't go through your luggage and arrest you, even you know, even if you never get off in New York, they've been going after people who have hunting and other gear in their carry - not in their carry-on luggage but in their checked luggage.

So, it's really outrageous what has happened, we need to protect these rights for all citizens.

And the president's made that commitment and he will keep that commitment.

MCDOWELL: But he was also - but he was also against -- he was for -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - an assault weapons ban years ago?

NORQUIST: Right.

MCDOWELL: He was -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - for it!

BARTIROMO: I think -

NORQUIST: He made a promise -

BARTIROMO: - the president wants -

NORQUIST: - (INAUDIBLE), yes.

BARTIROMO: - wants to show so much that he's a moderate and wants to effect change -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - that that's - I think that's why he's trying so hard to come across as look, 'I'm here and I'm not going to be handcuffed by any rules that were in place before. I want to look at this with a fresh eye.'

MCDOWELL: But as a -

NORQUIST: Yes, yes.

MCDOWELL: - but as a member of the NRA, I want to add - I want to push back on what we heard from the president because anybody who has listened to liberals over the years, Grover, they don't want to just take away semi- automatic sporting rifles.

They want -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - to take away semi-automatic handguns in this country, handguns commit - they are involved in most of your firearms death in this country -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - that's why people who are proponents of the Second Amendment and who honor it, that's why they're concerned by this.

BARTIROMO: Isn't it 80 percent Dagen?

MCDOWELL: It's - the vast majority of firearm deaths in this country are actually by suicide -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCDOWELL: - and it's less than a thousand homicides are committed or firearm homicides are committed by long guns.

MCSHANE: Let me just make one quick point in this, is that we've seen this before.

I mean what we're seeing - but I don't know about taxes but definitely on immigration, that we've seen all of this before, the president makes a point like this and you know, what's interesting, it's an interesting discussion to have but I don't know how much it matters -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCSHANE: - in a - in a forum like this -

NORQUIST: Yes.

MCSHANE: - because the - you know, whatever legislation is put forward, again, that -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCSHANE: - exactly what happened on immigration.

It was really the president who stood in the way at the end of the day on the bipartisan compromise kind of reversing himself with the comments that he made in that meeting.

And he could easily reverse himself on -

BARTIROMO: And -

MCSHANE: - the comments he made yesterday.

BARTIROMO: - and it was Kevin McCarthy who said," Wait Mr. President" -

MCSHANE: Right.

BARTIROMO: - yes, in that -

MCSHANE: (INAUDIBLE) -

BARTIROMO: - immigration -

MCSHANE: - (INAUDIBLE) -

BARTIROMO: - I remember the meeting -

MCSHANE: - it could be like -

BARTIROMO: - exactly.

MCSHANE: - a replay.

BARTIROMO: You want to say something on this?

FREEMAN: Yes. He tweets and says a lot, you want to look at the results.

So, I guess so, I wonder from Grover, how do you think this ends up?

Is it just focused on keeping the mentally ill from guns, what comes of all this?

NORQUIST: Right. That's a very interesting question because having people who have mental health challenges that makes them a danger to themselves and others, that should've been in NICS (ph).

And it was the Democrats who kept it out, back in the 1990s, the National Rifle Association and Republicans thought it was a good idea but the other guys thought it was stigmatizing people to tell this young man in Florida, you - we think there's a problem with you.

You don't want to hurt his feelings, that's the Democrat problem. For decades we've lived with their mistake both the National Rifle Association and Republicans have always been willing to change that and the Democrats are trying to tell you to look someplace else.

Let's fix that problem and let's -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - not have gun free zones that make students a target because parents and administrators don't have the ability to 'carry concealed' in schools, to make them safer.

We want safer schools, the left just wants gun control; that's why the conversation is so odd.

We're talking about how to make school safe -

BARTIROMO: Right.

NORQUIST: - and they just want to steal people's guns and they've been at it for decades so we kind of -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NORQUIST: - know where they're going.

BARTIROMO: And that's a conversation right now, gun control, even though we know how many times the -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - signals and the signs were there, particularly about Nikolas Cruz -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - and there was a massive failure on the part of the FBI and the local police.

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We can't have you on without talking about tax reform and growth, Grover.

So, I've got to ask you -

NORQUIST: That's what I assumed that we were talking -

BARTIROMO: Sorry -

NORQUIST: - about here.

BARTIROMO: - about that Grover. You know, we have to get into the -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - issue of the day.

Let me ask you about your thoughts on growth.

Companies are reportedly buying back their stock at a quicker pace following the cut in corporate taxes.

"The Journal" says -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - that share buybacks from US businesses has exceeded $300 billion in the past three months.

What do you think about that?

And also, look at this, Atlanta Fed going from 5.4 percent growth, now they are at 2 1/2 percent growth, that they're expecting.

We also saw our GDP number that came down from the third quarter, now we're talking about growth of 2 1/2 percent.

Has your expectation changed of economic growth of four percent in '18 and where we are right now?

NORQUIST: No. I think we're looking very - moving forward very well.

The really good news is that companies are doing stock buybacks.

Why does that matter?

That means the companies are looking at bringing billions of dollars back from overseas and they say, 'what's the best way I could spend a billion dollars, buying another company, starting a new line of business, or is our business is so good that we want to invest in us.'

Now that money doesn't disappear, they buy those stocks from somebody and the new investor reinvests that money to his or her highest and best value.

So, the money doesn't disappear in a buyback it moves between investors and it's a company saying, 'we think we're the best game in town.'

I want to be invested in a firm whose management thinks the best thing you can do with a billion dollars is invest it in yourself because they think the future looks so good.

FREEMAN: We should note in that Journal story on - from the new side of our paper, it did note that a lot of CEOs along with planning buybacks also talking about more capital investment Grover, which is -

NORQUIST: Yes.

FREEMAN: - really that's going to be the test of this tax reform right.

It's higher investment because we're - we're rewarding more investment in the United States.

NORQUIST: We're bringing more capital in from overseas and more from the United States per worker, that gives you productivity increases, that gives your higher wages.

BARTIROMO: All right site sounds like you're still positive on this tax plan Grover?

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Good to -

NORQUIST: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: - see you sir. Thank you so -

NORQUIST: Yes.

BARTIROMO: - much.

Grover Norquist there.

Stay with us, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New questions this morning about why the FBI let a suspected hacker flee the country.

Lauren Simonetti with the details. Lauren?

SIMONETTI: "The Daily Caller" is reporting that the FBI apprehended the suspected hacker as she was trying to board a plane to Pakistan, carrying what appeared to be an illegal amount of cash.

Here's her husband, Imran Awan, he's awaiting charges on trial of fraudulent procurement as well as bank fraud but he's also suspected of hacking the computers of numerous House Democrats. He's due back in court next Thursday.

Well self-proclaimed "Pharma Bro" Martin Shkreli is now asking the judge for mercy and admitting to being 'a fool.'

The judge ruled this week that Shkreli was responsible for $10 1/2 million dollars in losses in its securities fraud scheme, Shkreli reading a letter that he wrote, "I was wrong. I was a fool. I should've known better. I have learned a harsh lesson. The trial and six months in a maximum- security prison has been a frightening wake-up call. I now understand how I need to change."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TEXT: "I was wrong, I was a fool. I should've known better. I have learned a harsh lesson. The trial and six months in a maximum security prison has been a frightening wake-up call. I now understand how I need to change."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: He was convicted of cheating investors in two failed hedge funds back in August. He remains in jail and faces up to 20 years in prison; he is (ph) sentenced March the 9th.

Well Lacoste is throwing the power of its brand behind endangered species. The company making a limited-edition polo shirt that replaces the iconic crocodile logo, the alligator, with 10 endangered species including the California Condor, the Javan rhino, and the Sumatran Tiger.

Sales will go towards conservation efforts.

And how to smell like a genius!

A perfume company New York claims they've come up with the scent of Albert Einstein, here's the catch, you actually have to buy a replica of the Levi's brown leather jacket that he wore.

The - he - Levi's acquired the original jacket two years at action for more than a hundred and fifty thousand dollars and now the perfume and the jacket can be yours for 1,200 bucks; interesting!

BARTIROMO: Well it can't - it can't possibly still smell!

SIMONETTI: Or it could but -

BARTIROMO: I mean -

SIMONETTI: - I don't think we want to smell like whatever it does smell like at this point.

BARTIROMO: - OK.

Smell like a genius!

SIMONETTI: I'll just go you know, stand by you guys on the panel, you'll smell like a genius.

BARTIROMO: Thank you, Lauren.

Still ahead, growing a dream. I'll talk with country star and Army Vet, Craig Morgan about his new dream project, "The Gallery at Morgan Farms" in his new series.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: That was great. It was a clip from, "Morgan Family Strong," the new series featuring Country Music Star and US Army Veteran, Craig Morgan and his family at home, on tour, and coming together to build their dream project, "The Gallery at Morgan Farms."

It premieres tonight, 9:30 p.m. Eastern on "Up TV."

Joining me right now is a man himself, and his daughter, Craig and his daughter Aly Morgan Beaird.

(BEGIN AUDIOTAPE)

Great to see you both - guys. Thank you so much for joining us.

CRAIG MORGAN GREER, COUNTRY MUSIC STAR, AWARD-WINNING TV HOST, "MORGAN FAMILY STRONG" STAR & US ARMY VET: Thank you.

ALY MORGAN BEAIRD, SINGER, SONGWRITER, MUSICAL ARTIST & "MORGAN FAMILY STRONG" STAR: Thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations. Tell us about "The Gallery at Morgan Farms" Craig?

MORGAN: It's - it's funny because it's not what you would think, the - we've - we've had so many people email us on Facebook was asking when we'll have our tomatoes out and those kinds of things.

It's not that type of a story, it really is a gallery, we feature art, artistic pieces, artisan pieces; all of the wood pieces I do myself and it's all -

BARTIROMO: Wow!

MORGAN: - handmade from repurposed, reclaimed -

BARTIROMO: Fantastic!

MORGAN: - (INAUDIBLE) wood.

And I tell people we don't just sell bowls and spoons and centerpieces we sell stories.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: Every piece of wood has a story, we know where it came from; some of the pieces are - that are featured are made from a tree that Jim Ed Brown, Country Music Hall of Fame, Grand Ole Opry member, he planted that tree. It died, he had to cut it down and I got some of the wood and I made something out of it -

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) -

MORGAN: - thanks to his daughter.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

And how do you like working with your father on this?

MORGAN BEAIRD: Oh, it's awesome.

The fact - you know, running a family business is really cool anyway but running a family business in light of his career makes it a little more challenging.

But it's really cool, everything in the store is made by somebody in the family and that's - it's really cool that we can bring our talents together and distribute them.

BARTIROMO: Which is why it's - it's getting such a great reception.

So, Morgan Farms came together around the tragic loss of your son?

MORGAN: It did.

BARTIROMO: Craig, tell us about that, Jerry, rather than turning to music, you turned to woodworking?

MORGAN: That's a fact.

Music is a big part of my life obviously but I don't know there's something - there's something very spiritual about us, time with yourself, with a knife and a piece of wood, just whittling something out or carving out or -

BARTIROMO: It's therapeutic!

MORGAN: - it is very therapeutic -

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MORGAN: - you know, a lot of our veterans make walking canes, they have a program at Fort - BARTIROMO: Wow!

MORGAN: - Campbell and they make - they carve out different things on walking canes.

And I don't know why but that's what I went to.

We had this idea and I knew that it was important in light of this tragedy that my family focus on something, we - aside from our faith and we are very, very spiritual family and very tight-knit family but I knew we needed focus on something else collectively.

And so, I created the brand 'Morgan Farms' and between Alex and myself we started this brick-and-mortar store; the two of us started it and we're the two doing the least amount of work.

MORGAN BEAIRD: That's true (ph).

BARTIROMO: And you can get this wine there?

MORGAN: You can order the wine off Lot18.com -

BARTIROMO: OK.

MORGAN: - we have a - we have a set up where you can order it through - from the store, through the store but look you can do it at your house is well, it's easier.

BARTIROMO: You should - you know, having a family business is fun to start with but working day-in and day-out with the family, I mean it's got to be important to you to actually see this is not just fun but you're actually creating profits and it's a business.

MORGAN BEAIRD: Oh, for sure and I think some of us keep that in mind more than others you know.

But it's been fun to kind of learn how to run a business and then how to run a business together; it's two totally different things and so you know, sometimes the bills gets pushed aside and you get it last day, you've got to run those, to get them paid (INAUDIBLE).

MORGAN: (INAUDIBLE) pay (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: But you still got - you still got the music career, alive and -

MORGAN: We do.

BARTIROMO: - strong.

MORGAN BEAIRD: Yes.

MORGAN: Yes. I'm very blessed with the - with the career that I've had - still having the music business; in the process of working on a new music right now, just got out of the studio last week, working on a new album so.

But it's exciting, there's a lot going on and I'm - I'm very fortunate to be able to share it with my family.

BARTIROMO: We love this, Craig, Aly, great to see you both. Thanks so much for joining us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

Aired 4-5p ET2018-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:57:09ZLexisNexisGunman Shot Dead In France After Rampage Kills Three People; ISIS Calls France Attacker A Soldier, Offers No Evidence; Trade War Fears; Trump Appoints New National Security Adviser; Trump Appoints New National Security Adviser; Trump: Will Never Sign A Bill Like That Ever Again. Aired 4-5p ETLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

[16:00:17]

HALA GORANI, CNN HOST: Hello and welcome, everyone. I'm Hala Gorani live tonight from Paris. France is dealing with yet another terrorist attack on its soil. Three people are dead after a series of attacks in Southern France on this Friday.

It culminated in a four-hour standoff at a supermarket before police shot the gunman dead. He is named as a 26-year-old Redouane Lakdim. Here is what we know. On Friday morning, the attacker hijacked a car killing one person inside the car and injuring another.

And then not far from that, he shot a group of police officers, who are out jogging in the town of (INAUDIBLE). The car tried to run officers down. One person was wounded and then the gunman drove to a supermarket (INAUDIBLE). He entered the market shouting, "Allahu Akbar."

This is all, by the way, information I'm bringing to you for the public prosecutor. He killed two people inside. He took several people hostage. A police officer agreed to give himself over to the gunman in exchange for the release of hostages and that officer entered the supermarket and then shot the gunman.

French President Emmanuel Macron returned to Paris from Brussels earlier than expected. He condemned the attack and he praised authorities on the scene.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, FRENCH PRESIDENT (through translator): Our country has been struck today by an Islamist terrorist attack. The courage of one particular senior police officer who voluntarily took the place of other hostages and who was very seriously wounded. He saved lives and he does honor to his force and his country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)
